Realmente me encanta el parecido que tiene con la pelicula de 1999,el ambiente y el sonido son impecables y aqui se puede ver el amor y talento que bloober le tiene a sus obras. Muy buen juego y creo que Blair witch junto con el remake de Silent hill. Son sus mejores obras.
8.5/10
Walking sim

[h1]The Blair Scare[/h1]

[i]Inspired by the cinematic lore of Blair Witch, experience a new story-driven psychological horror game that studies your reactions to fear and stress.[/i]

[h2]Story[/h2]
The year is 1996, two years after the events of the first film. A 9-year-old boy has gone missing in the Black Hills Forest in Burkittsville, Maryland. You play as Ellis Lynch, a war veteran and former police officer who joins the search party for the missing boy. You also have your police dog Bullet with you. Ellis suffers from PTSD, which manifests itself in various ways throughout the game, including flashbacks where Ellis has a hard time deciding what is real or not.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
Blair Witch is a first-person survival horror game. You have your dog Bullet with you, who leads you through almost the entire game. He can seek and fetch things for you, you can pet him, give him dog snacks, and most importantly he can warn you and show you where evil is hiding in the forest. I thought this was an original and cool mechanic that I had not experienced before.

You have no weapons in this game. You do, however, have a flashlight and a camcorder that you use a lot. The flashlight is basically your weapon. You use it to shine a light on the evil in the forest to kill it. In this creepy forest, there are lanky, twig-like demons lurking, who move incredibly quickly between the trees. Bullet will growl in the direction where the demons are hiding. Keep an eye on Bullet and work with him to take down the enemies. The camcorder is often used to solve simple puzzles or as a guide in certain parts of the game where you have to avoid enemies without using your flashlight.

Many people complain about the gameplay and say that this game is a boring walking simulator, and I can understand why. There is a lot of walking and talking, but I still found it mostly interesting.

[h2]Enemies[/h2]
Mostly tree monsters in the forest, and something else in the house at the end.

[h2]Environment & Scares[/h2]
Basically the whole game takes place outside in the forest, but in the end you are also inside a very dark and old, unpleasant house. The atmosphere is really good and creepy, both in the forest and inside the house. The game has some very good scares and creepy segments, but also some cheap ones.

[h2]Visual Design & Sound Design[/h2]
Visually the game looks good. Nothing extraordinary, but good. The forest looks well-made and feels scary. The enemies in the house at the end of the game looked very creepy and scary as well.

The sound design is great. Both in terms of sound effects and music. Branches and twigs breaking off in the forest, creepy music as you advance through the fog, unpleasant whispers especially at the end of the game when you are in the house, and more.

[h2]Constructive Criticism[/h2]
Some parts of the game went on for far too long. For example, when you have to carry Bullet for a certain reason, and the house at the end. They could have removed at least a third of the duration in the house. It just became repetitive.

The AI ‚Äã‚Äãfor Bullet is not flawless. Many times I did not understand what he was barking at and sometimes he just walked back and forth, confused about where to go, which made me confused. The game takes place in a semi-open world and it can be a little confusing in the forest at times. Then it‚Äôs important that Bullet's guidance works as it should. I consider this a minor issue, as it did not happen a lot and I managed to find my way regardless.

The forest enemies could have been much scarier. They‚Äôre basically super-fast living trees hiding behind other trees, but the encounters became repetitive and weren‚Äôt very challenging. Later when the camcorder was needed in the house at the end of the game, the enemies were much scarier, but it was also too easy.

The PTSD flashback scenes in the forest felt out of place and weren‚Äôt scary‚Äîlike the demon leaf balls. The final house had potential to be much scarier, but excessive flashbacks made it feel weird and underwhelming instead of frightening.

[h2]The Verdict[/h2]
Blair Witch is an interesting and unique horror experience unlike anything I have been through before. It has incredible sound design, but also has some slow gameplay parts. The game has its flaws but it's still a good game and not too long. I recommend it, but wait for a sale.

[h2]Rating: 7/10[/h2]

Wow. Just Wow. The Blair Witch game is beautiful, emotional, and deeply unsettling. While the start can be a bit confusing, once you get it right, the rest is nearly easy. The story pulls you in, encouraging wild theories and keeping you hooked. I was so hooked while playing in disc with friends. Be ready for a emotional ride across the dark and confusing forest. KEEP YOUR DOG CLOSE.

column8:
After playing Observer Redux and being blown away, I decided on Blair Witch. Heard many things about it, but I was so pleased with the depth of story and the pacing was neither too fast or too slow. Very good visuals. And finally, the thing I LOVED THE MOST was the sense of chosing where to go and having the randomness make sense like you were really there. I engaged with BULLET every chance I got and enjoyed him the whole game. I plan on buying MEDIUM soon when the price drops a bit. 
Cheers Bloober Team
column9:

I engaged with BULLET every chance I got and enjoyed him the whole game. I plan on buying MEDIUM soon when the price drops a bit. 
Cheers Bloober Team

Here, I would actually calculate the Negative or Positive outcome, because of 2 types of tension:
+ Suspense; i.e. it's in its core a very immersive game that made me both anxious (essentially Bullet-related üêï‚Äçü¶∫) and excited = [b]haunting[/b] + in terms of audio, it's very well done with the binaural recordings feat. my OPPO Enco X earphones; especially the rain sounds later on are very effective;
- Tedium/Frustration = [b]daunting[/b] at times; i.e. most of this negative tension arose from easily missing essential items (to be vague and n√≥t spoil), even when our loyal companion has the seeking-ability and helps (at times). There was [i]"This One Time, At [....] Camp"[/i] where I had basically searched everywhere and found the right spot, but I was missing an item that was lying on the ground ... In short, it's definitely more a game for people who play HOG and the [i]Hidden Object[/i]-üè∑Ô∏è may be added. For me, together with the slow-but-steady, careful gameplay approach at times, it was more make to break the suspense. Added to it, some confusing/obscure pieces.

'Summing it up' or subtracting: the Good outweighs the Bad, and the Great Bullet is the very positive B‚≠ênus ‚Äî > Satisfied to have naturally done the right müê∂ve, but [url=https://www.vice.com/en/article/the-most-terrifying-thing-about-the-blair-witch-game-it-hurts-your-dog/]beware[/url] (‚ö†Ô∏è SPOILERS ‚ö†Ô∏è) of something else than the dog; speaking of an experience that was more than I could handle too = absolutely immersive and impressive ... It leaves a Mark üò¢

column8: Big horror game junkie my whole life. Saw a beginning play through and thought it looked cool so I snatched it. Flashlight and camera games and I have an otherwise positive relationship and having a Shepard myself, to have Bullet look like my own dog was so cool. I pushed through as long as I could until I put it down for a couple days, when I got back I could barely remember where I left off or what was happening. My final review: The story line is... boring/just generally unrealistic. Characters feel and say unbelievably stupid things. A lot of people call it "walking sim" and yeah I'd have to agree, I found myself getting frustrated literally walking in circles, the walkways were at some points bizarrely placed and just overall hard to navigate. So yeah if you want a walking sim with snippets or story line here and there w/ stupid characters, this is the game for you.

El problema es que no transmiten lo que los creadores entiendo que quieren transmitir, como ser√≠a en este caso la locura o el s√≠ndrome postraum√°tico. En su lugar, lo que queda es un juego/pel√≠cula aburrido que solo tiene un fragmento de gameplay real, el de la vagoneta, donde tienes que buscar objetos y usarlos y tienes un objetivo claro, el resto, lo dicho, una colecci√≥n de escenas que bien podr√≠an ser inconexas en las que sigues un recorrido de la mano de los creadores del juego.

Por suerte Bloober ha hecho Silent Hill 2 remake, juego infinitamente superior a este, y parece que le has ido bien y ya han anunciado que su siguiente proyecto ser√° otro survival horror, es decir, otro juego con gameplay en lugar de estos aburridos walking simulators que espero que dejen atr√°s de una vez.

Em vez disso, o jogo constr√≥i uma tens√£o crescente, utilizando o ambiente, sons perturbadores e apari√ß√µes que parecem estar √† espreita, esperando o momento certo para atacar sua sanidade. Se voc√™ gosta de uma boa hist√≥ria, atmosferas densas e n√£o se importa em levar alguns sustos ao longo do caminho, prepare-se para enfrentar seus medos na floresta de Black Hills.

Some games try to scare you. This one tries to break you down.

At its best, this game shines. It plays with psychological horror and player perspective in inventive, sometimes brilliant ways. The dynamic with your canine companion is a standout. It's a rare, heartfelt connection in a genre that usually treats emotions like disposable batteries. You can pet the dog. You should pet the dog. He‚Äôs your sanity, your heart, your lifeline. It‚Äôs am important element baked into the emotional arc of the game. When it works, it really works.

But when it stumbles? It face plants hard.

Some sequences drag on far too long, bleeding tension into tedium. The psychological grip slips, replaced by mechanical repetition. Certain innovative mechanics: like repeating moments designed to simulate helplessness or disorientation go on too far and instead rob the player of agency. Instead of being with the protagonist, I felt like I was watching him from the outside, trapped in a slow-moving walking sim with a flashlight and no real say.

Then there‚Äôs the ending. I won‚Äôt spoil too much, but let‚Äôs just say: if your connection to sanity and humanity is your dog, and the dog actively hates something, maybe... don‚Äôt destroy it? Turns out that‚Äôs the trick to avoiding the darkest timeline. It's a clever subversion in theory, but in execution, it felt unintuitive and not in a satisfying, ‚ÄúOhhh I get it now‚Äù kind of way.

The military backstory could have benefited from a few more minutes of research or a consultant. I get what they were going for, the guilt, the shame, the haunting echoes of duty, but I was yanked out of the immersion more than once. A lone private doing recon? An elite team where half the guys have full beards and the commander‚Äôs title is just... "Commander"? It yanked me out quite a bit when my head tried to wrap around how that ever would have happened reasonably. 

Then there are the technical issues. I don‚Äôt mind the occasional jank in an indie or experimental title, but this went beyond. I had camera bugs that locked my view in place, crashes to desktop, full system failures, and one game-breaking glitch that forced a full uninstall, reinstall, and restart. That‚Äôs a rough experience to justify even if the narrative ambition is admirable.

And that brings me to the hard part: the binary. Recommended or Not Recommended.

Here‚Äôs the truth:
If you love narrative-driven horror games, want to try something unique, and can forgive technical flaws and you really love dogs.... then yeah, I cautiously recommend it.
But if you‚Äôre looking for a clean, smooth experience, or if technical issues and mechanical inconsistencies pull you out of a story fast, this might just be more frustrating than fulfilling.

I want to reward bold ideas. I want more games to try what this one tried. But I also want those ideas to work. So consider this a recommendation with a leash, a flashlight, and a healthy warning label.

As a fan of the original movie, I had really high hopes for this one. Well, they were fulfilled partially, at best.

Pros:
- Bullet is a good boy!
- Great atmosphere of feeling lost in the forest (sic, who goes on the search party without a map and a compass);
- Great environmental storytelling;
- Good voice acting and overall sound design.
- Great story of personal demons and redemption (or downward spiral, depends on how you play).
- Jumpscares are rare and well-placed.
- It's short.

Cons:
- No way you could find all collectibles without a video guide.
- No way you could figure out how to get a good ending in the first playthrough;
- Controls are clumsy;
- Little to no new information about the Blair witch

Verdict:
Solid 6/10.
Definitely try it if you are a fan of a franchise or if you like walking simulators with a psychological horror flavor.

PS: Play in headphones, it really worth it.
PPS: Don't check the digital artbook before p[laying, you will catch a major spoilers.

column8:
I don't usually review games on Steam, but I felt like I had to with this one.  This game is simply God awful.  I'm a big fan of the movie so I figured a game based on said movie would be worth the $5 I paid, but I regret even spending that much.   

For starters, the game has absolutely nothing in common with the movie except that it takes place in the woods.  That's it.  The game is comprised of you walking in circles with a dog (who is next to useless, and more of a nuisance than anything), and "killing" enemies with a flashlight.  There's no interesting puzzles, any semblance of an interesting story line, fun game play, etc.  to be found here.  The main "villain" of the game is flat out boring.  There's nothing terrifying about him, and later on he just becomes annoying.  The moments that you can tell are supposed to be "intense" are a snooze fest, and often times extremely predictable.  

I'm towards the very end of the game and am having a hard time finishing it.  I would never suggest anyone pay full price for this nonsense.  I

column8: Simplesmente um dos meus jogos de terror favoritos, merece mais reconhecimento. 10/10

I love this game for how user friendly it is, the mechanics aren't hard but that doesn't allow it to lose it's spookiness. For being a Blair Witch game, it shells out the story really well and doesn't deviate from the source material much as far as I'm aware. Very fun game. "Blair Witch" is a good thriller/horror video-game that succeeds in immersing us in Black Hills Forest. For anyone who is afraid of finding themselves in the woods at night, this game really does its job when it comes to graphics, atmosphere and sound design. Lets start by saying this is a new take on the Blair Witch, which isn't necessarily a bad thing. It's actually a good thing.

I highly recommend this game if you like the horror genre. It's not a typical horror game but the experience is immersive. 

Actual review is below:
I purchased this game in the year it was released back in 2019. It is a well crafted horror video game with a few enemies and puzzles. It has haunting horror elements and a lot of good well timed jump scares. The overall game play was fun and the graphics are well polished. Controls are pretty good. It has a very deep story line with many avenues to take for the final ending. I beat it once and got a few achievements during my first play game back in 2019. The first time probably took 2 to 4 hours to beat depending on how many items you find. After that I didn't play the game for about 5 years. In 2024 I got all the achievements after 2 more runs. After 22 hours of game play I can say this game is worth the money. I'm glad I purchased it when it l got released. It definitely is a good game with decent depiction of the 1999 Blair Witch Project film. 9/10 from my stand point.

column8:
I want to share my thoughts on Blair Witch, a game I thoroughly enjoyed despite some common criticisms. Many players mention bugs, the game ‚Äúnot being scary enough,‚Äù or that the dog companion feels useless. However, I had a different and much more positive experience.

First off, the game offers a fresh and compelling spin on the Blair Witch mythology. Exploring the forest felt atmospheric and immersive, adding layers to the story we know. The visuals are stunning, capturing both the beauty and the unsettling nature of the cursed woods.

Bullet, the dog, might seem like a simple addition, but I found him to be a valuable companion. He adds emotional depth and enhances the narrative, especially considering the protagonist‚Äôs struggle with PTSD. His presence isn‚Äôt just functional - it‚Äôs symbolic and ties into the themes of isolation and connection.

The portrayal of PTSD stood out to me the most. The game dives deep into psychological horror, offering a raw and unsettling experience. It‚Äôs refreshing to see mental health depicted with such nuance in a horror setting.

No game is entirely bug-free, and while there might be minor issues, they didn‚Äôt detract from the overall experience for me. Sometimes, it‚Äôs about appreciating the story, atmosphere, and artistic effort. ‚ô°

"Blair Witch" is a good thriller/horror videogame that succeeds in immersing us in Black Hills Forest. For anyone who is afraid of finding themselves in the woods at night, this game really does its job when it comes to graphics, atmosphere and sound design. 

And maybe this might sound silly, but the presence of Bullet the dog really managed to relieve some of the tension you feel in the middle of the woods in the dark.

However, I had a hard time associating this game with the Blair Witch concept as the game exploits very lightly the presence of the witch, who is much more fragrant in the films. Carver's character is the only connection to the witch's in the game, but despite the reason behind this, it still remains insufficient.

Lets start by saying this is a new take on the Blair Witch, which isn't necessarily a bad thing. I started this game with the thought that it would be similar to the 90's "The Blair Witch Project" which was incorrect. That being said I wasn't upset with this title. This was a real psychological thriller, and the choices you make through out the game do effect the ending. However, I will say the militaristic aspect of the story seemed a little out of place for me but really just provided a extra layer of weakness to the mc's mind in the grand scheme. The best part of this game imo is Bullet, the AI that this dog has is very pleasant and left me wishing Fallout 4's Dog Meat could of had Bullet's mechanics. He's very lovable with the ability to pet/feed him, comfort him when he is scared, and just bond with him throughout the game. And in the beginning its simple character design for Bullet not Ellis which I enjoyed. It took me 2 play throughs to 100% this game, my recorded time is 17 hours but some of that time was spent afk on main menu etc. Overall I give Blair Witch a 7/10, Again keep an open interpretation when getting into this, NOT a 90's clone! The graphics are really good, game play is smooth, game is more gory than scary (great scenes btw), story is pretty good and keeps you wondering, decent game to add to your horror collection.

I love this game for how user friendly it is, the mechanics aren't hard but that doesn't allow it to lose it's spookiness. For being a Blair Witch game, it shells out the story really well and doesn't deviate from the source material much as far as I'm aware. Very fun game. As a Completionest, it can be tedious at times but its really not that bad. Loved this game, I want more like it!

[h2]Story und Atmosph√§re:[/h2]

Blair Witch basiert auf der gleichnamigen Filmreihe und bringt den Spieler tief in die d√ºstere und bedrohliche Atmosph√§re des Black Hills Waldes, wo die ber√ºchtigte Blair Witch ihr Unwesen treibt. Die Geschichte folgt Ellis, einem ehemaligen Polizisten, der sich auf die Suche nach einem vermissten Jungen namens Peter begeben hat. Gemeinsam mit seinem Hund Bullet, der als treuer Begleiter dient, durchstreift er den Wald und st√∂√üt dabei auf unheimliche, √ºbernat√ºrliche Ph√§nomene, die ihn immer mehr in den Wahnsinn zu treiben scheinen.

Die Atmosph√§re von Blair Witch ist von Anfang an von Spannung und Unbehagen durchzogen. Der Wald ist dicht, verworren und ein labyrinthischer Ort, der st√§ndig das Gef√ºhl der Isolation und Bedrohung verst√§rkt. Dunkelheit und Nebel spielen eine zentrale Rolle, da sie das Gef√ºhl der Entfremdung und das Fehlen jeglicher Orientierung verst√§rken. Das Spiel f√§ngt die Horror-√Ñsthetik des Originals auf, indem es eine subtile und psychologische Bedrohung erschafft, die mehr auf Angst vor dem Unbekannten setzt als auf √ºberm√§√üige Jump-Scares.

Die Verbindung zum Film wird vor allem durch die gelebte Geschichte und die immer wiederkehrenden Hinweise auf die legendenumwobene Blair Witch hergestellt. Zwar ist das Spiel keine direkte Fortsetzung des Films, aber es ist eine sehr gut gelungene Erweiterung des Blair Witch-Universums, die durch die dichte Atmosph√§re und das mysteri√∂se Setting √ºberzeugt. Die st√§ndige Pr√§senz von paranormalen Erscheinungen und die bedrohliche, klaustrophobische Stimmung sorgen f√ºr eine konstante Anspannung, die die Atmosph√§re hervorragend tr√§gt.

[h2]Gameplay:[/h2]

Das Gameplay von Blair Witch ist gr√∂√ütenteils ein Walking Simulator, wobei der Fokus auf Erkundung, R√§tsell√∂sungen und dem √úberleben im Angesicht der √ºbernat√ºrlichen Bedrohungen liegt. Der Spieler √ºbernimmt die Rolle von Ellis, einem Polizisten, der mit seinem Hund Bullet unterwegs ist, um den vermissten Jungen zu finden. Bullet ist nicht nur ein treuer Begleiter, sondern auch ein zentrales Gameplay-Element. Er hilft dem Spieler, den Weg zu finden, reagiert auf unheimliche Ger√§usche und kann auch Hinweise zu m√∂glichen Bedrohungen geben.

Das Spiel setzt stark auf die Interaktion mit der Umgebung. Ellis kann verschiedene Objekte sammeln, um R√§tsel zu l√∂sen und bestimmte Mechanismen im Spiel auszul√∂sen. Die Geschichte entfaltet sich durch das Finden von Hinweisen, die oft in Form von Gegenst√§nden oder dokumentierten Aufzeichnungen vorliegen. Es gibt auch eine fortschreitende mentale Belastung, die sich durch eine allm√§hliche Verschlechterung von Ellis' Zustand zeigt, was das Gameplay zus√§tzlich intensiviert.

Ein gro√üer Teil des Spiels dreht sich um den Umgang mit Bullet. Der Hund kann nicht nur als emotionaler Anker dienen, sondern ist auch eine praktische Hilfe bei der Suche nach Hinweisen. Bullet kann bestimmte Dinge erschn√ºffeln, nach denen der Spieler suchen muss, oder das Verhalten des Hundes kann dem Spieler helfen, Bedrohungen zu erkennen, die ansonsten nicht sichtbar w√§ren. Bullet wird schnell zu einem unverzichtbaren Teil der Erfahrung und tr√§gt viel zur emotionalen Bindung bei.

Der Horror entsteht vor allem durch das Gef√ºhl der Bedrohung und die st√§ndige Ungewissheit. Das Gameplay setzt mehr auf psychologische Angst als auf direkte Konfrontation mit feindlichen Kreaturen. Es gibt zwar Momente, in denen Ellis auf unheimliche Ph√§nomene st√∂√üt, doch das Spiel ist viel subtiler und setzt weniger auf Action, sondern auf klaustrophobische Spannung und das Gef√ºhl der Machtlosigkeit.

[h2]Erz√§hlweise und Inszenierung:[/h2]

Die Erz√§hlweise von Blair Witch ist eine der gr√∂√üten St√§rken des Spiels. Die Story entfaltet sich auf eine langsame, aber konstante Weise, indem der Spieler immer wieder auf neue Hinweise st√∂√üt, die sowohl die Geschichte von Ellis' Vergangenheit als auch das Geheimnis um die Blair Witch l√ºften. Die narrative Struktur nutzt die st√§ndige Spannung und das Gef√ºhl der Ungewissheit, um den Spieler immer tiefer in die Geschichte zu ziehen. Es gibt eine interessante psychologische Komponente, da Ellis' geistiger Zustand im Verlauf des Spiels immer mehr in Frage gestellt wird, was die Immersion verst√§rkt.

Die Inszenierung ist hervorragend und vermittelt eine st√§ndige Bedrohung, auch wenn der Spieler keine sofort sichtbaren Feinde hat. Die Gestaltung der Umgebung ist ein zentraler Bestandteil der Geschichte ‚Äì der Wald wird nie wirklich ‚Äûgel√∂st‚Äú, sondern bleibt ein sich st√§ndig ver√§nderndes, labyrinthartiges Terrain, das sich nach und nach immer mysteri√∂ser anf√ºhlt. Der Einsatz von Dunkelheit, Nebel und sich st√§ndig ver√§ndernden Pfaden l√§sst den Spieler nie wirklich zur Ruhe kommen.

Die Interaktionen zwischen Ellis und Bullet sind emotional und gut inszeniert. Bullet reagiert auf den Zustand seines Besitzers und verst√§rkt so die psychologische Spannung. Die Beziehung zwischen den beiden wird im Verlauf der Geschichte immer wichtiger und tr√§gt nicht nur zur Atmosph√§re, sondern auch zum emotionalen Kern der Erz√§hlung bei.

[h2]Technische Umsetzung:[/h2]

Die technische Umsetzung von Blair Witch ist insgesamt solide, aber es gibt einige Schw√§chen, die das Gesamterlebnis beeintr√§chtigen k√∂nnen. Die Grafik ist ordentlich, mit detaillierten Texturen, besonders im Wald, der mit seiner d√ºsteren, beunruhigenden Atmosph√§re √ºberzeugt. Doch einige Szenen wirken visuell weniger beeindruckend, besonders in Momenten, die weniger auf Dunkelheit und Nebel angewiesen sind. Die Charaktermodelle von Ellis und Bullet sind gut, aber es gibt Momente, in denen die Animationen nicht ganz fl√ºssig wirken, was den Immersionsfaktor etwas mindern kann.

Der Sound ist ein weiteres Highlight des Spiels. Die Ger√§usche des Waldes, das Heulen von W√∂lfen oder das Knacken von √Ñsten sorgen f√ºr eine konstante Spannung. Auch die Audioaufnahmen, die Ellis w√§hrend seiner Suche findet, tragen zur Geschichte bei und verst√§rken das Gef√ºhl der Isolation. Die minimalistische Musik verst√§rkt die Stimmung, ohne sie zu √ºberladen.

Leider gibt es ab und zu technische Probleme, die die Immersion st√∂ren k√∂nnen. Dazu geh√∂ren kleinere Bugs und Glitches, wie zum Beispiel Kollisionen, die nicht immer akkurat sind, oder Szenen√ºberg√§nge, die nicht immer flie√üend wirken.

[h2]Pro und Contra:[/h2]

[b]Pro:[/b]

+ Das Spiel schafft eine dichte, be√§ngstigende Atmosph√§re, die den Spieler in den Bann zieht.
+ Die Beziehung zwischen Ellis und Bullet ist emotional und st√§rkt das Spielerlebnis.
+ Der Einsatz von Ger√§uschen, Dunkelheit und visuellen Effekten tr√§gt ma√ügeblich zur Spannung bei.
+ Das Spiel setzt mehr auf psychologische Angst als auf Jump-Scares und l√§sst den Spieler konstant im Unklaren dar√ºber, was real ist und was nicht.

[b]Contra:[/b]

- Kleinere Bugs und Performance-Probleme, die die Immersion st√∂ren k√∂nnen.
- Obwohl das Spiel eine interessante Story erz√§hlt, kann die Mechanik des st√§ndigen Sammelns von Hinweisen und der Suche nach Bullet etwas repetitiv wirken.
- Die Story entfaltet sich langsam, was f√ºr Spieler, die auf schnellere Action stehen, m√∂glicherweise frustrierend sein k√∂nnte.

[h2]Fazit:[/h2]

Blair Witch ist ein solides, atmosph√§risches Horror-Spiel, das die d√ºstere, psychologische Spannung der Filmreihe aufgreift und in ein interaktives Erlebnis √ºbertr√§gt. Die dichte Atmosph√§re, die starke emotionale Bindung zu Bullet und die subtile Art, wie das Spiel Horror erzeugt, machen es zu einem fesselnden Erlebnis f√ºr Fans von psychologischem Horror. Die technischen M√§ngel und das manchmal langsame Pacing k√∂nnen das Spiel allerdings ein wenig ausbremsen.

Wer auf tiefgr√ºndigen, atmosph√§rischen Horror steht und sich weniger f√ºr schnelle Action interessiert, wird mit Blair Witch auf jeden Fall auf seine Kosten kommen. Es ist ein Spiel, das stark von seiner Stimmung lebt und geschickt die Grenzen zwischen Realit√§t und Wahnsinn verschwimmen l√§sst.

I am not a gamer, let alone a horror fan, but this? This is something else. A depth to character and subtle puzzle solving storyline that wasn't unbearably scary, but still made me question my own sanity by the end of it. After not playing for months and coming back to it, it felt as if I'd never left the game, I was able to pick up where I left off with no effort. Excellent playability even for someone who struggles with solitaire controls.

Oh my god why the hell is there so many horror games that feels like there is a vital need for the MC and other chars to YAP all the time. It's a horror game, not a movie..... it's based on a movie even, we don't need SO MUCH dialogs... i'm being interrupted ALL THE TIME in this game for random events, random yap, random this or that, like, I would throw the radio fr fr just to spare the yaps of the searching team from the sheriff.

Like, please idk, just put me in the forest without so much YAPPING.

I'm gonna refund because it's just unbearable to have horror games thinking they have to put thousands of dialogs to be credible and to be worthy of being an amazing horror game. 
If a dev reads this: Dialogs don't make horror at all. At all. Keep it short and concise, there is absolutely no need to yap, yapping KILLS the horror, I wasn't scared ONE BIT, I pranced in the game like it was nothing, not a single horror vibe, due to this massive yap yap yap yap yap and flashbacks  my god, all that needs to go.

Si le jeu ne se lance pas, suivez le tuto ci-dessous, √ßa a fonctionn√© pour moi : 

- Press WinKey+R to open Run window. In it paste: SystemPropertiesAdvanced
- Press Ok
- Next click on Environment Variables
- In the lower frame, System Variables, press New
- And in the fields, paste these values:
-> Variable Name: OPENSSL_ia32cap
-> Variable value: ~0x20000000
Press Ok and close the Environment Variables window. Restart the computer. Try to run the game now.

column8:
Okay so this game is definitely a labor of love. It is an incredible great game and I'd highly recommend it, but of course it's not without its faults, and those faults can be very aggrivating, frustrating really. Many times you really did not know where to go next and the game really doesn't help you at all. Some could say less hand holding is a good thing, but not when you're stuck in a HUGE FOREST where the trees all look the same! They really need to add a Map, Icons, Waypoints and a TASK REMINDER system and/or Hint button! 

On a positive note the game map is huge, the story is interesting and the best part about the game as others have mentioned is your canine companion Bullet. It reminds me alot of Fire Watch! It's even got the cozy phone and walkie-talkie. For a while it was interesting walking around the forrest and doing things, however a few hours in it got pretty boring and repeatative. 

Some of the segments dragged on too long. For example at times the character would become fatigued and disoriented so the player would drag ass, the screen would become dark, the scenery would get all blurry. This happened quite a bit and for long stretches. The Bullet Dog part went on for 10 minutes!!! 

Another thing others have mentioned is how bad and loooooooong and dragged out the house / maze part was near the end of the game. This went on and on for nearly 2 hours. I fell asleep. It was confusing and way too long. Normally I'd complain that a game is too short. But not here. Like others have said, they couldn't wait for it to end. 

Lastly the train puzzle part was a big mess, mainly because throughout the entire game REQUIRED OBJECTS were mixed into the environment and hard to spot. This caused you to run around searching forever until you consulted a walkthrough. 

All of that aside this game is really very good, a ton of work and passion went into it and it shows. I would absolutely recommend it, but I would also strongly recommend an update with the improvements I mentioned. And I'd definitely clean-up, edit and shorten the haunted house sequence. 

Otherwise I really enjoyed this labor of love and very highly recommend it!

column8: Blair Witch isn't a bad game, but if you're expecting it to be closely connected to the 90s horror classic, then you might want to think twice. That's a shame, because the story, while completely different from the original, is actually quite good. As a big fan of the original film, I've always wondered what it would be like to wander through the woods, feeling constantly watched by an unknown, menacing entity. That's the experience I was hoping the game would deliver. Technically, the game is solid: the setting is excellent, the graphics are very good for its time, but I would have preferred a more responsive control scheme. As it stands, it feels a bit sluggish. Overall, I'd give it a 7 out of 10.

[h1]Blair Witch : vous prendrez bien un petit LEXOMIL ?[/h1]

Blair Witch nous plonge dans l'univers terrifiant de la for√™t de Black Hills avec une atmosph√®re soign√©e et une narration captivante... au d√©but. Bien que l'on puisse appr√©cier la vision des d√©veloppeurs et les concepts de gameplay, l'exp√©rience souffre de quelques d√©fauts qui peuvent d√©courager.

[h1]Un Jour sans fin[/h1]

Les premi√®res heures de Blair Witch sont immersives, et jouent habilement sur la peur de l‚Äôinconnu. La for√™t est oppressante, et l'utilisation de la cam√©ra VHS pour percevoir les √©l√©ments surnaturels est une id√©e int√©ressante. Cependant, cette tension retombe vite, car le jeu devient [i]r√©p√©titif[/i]. On traverse les m√™mes d√©cors sombres encore et encore, ce qui dilue l‚Äôangoisse et nuit √† l‚Äôint√©r√™t du jeu.

[h1]Dyspn√©e vid√©o-ludique[/h1]

Les m√©caniques de gameplay, bien que simples √† comprendre, se r√©v√®lent limit√©es et [i]redondantes[/i]. On alterne entre l'exploration, quelques √©nigmes et des s√©quences de tension avec des apparitions surnaturelles. Malheureusement, certaines sc√®nes s'√©tirent en longueur sans vraiment apporter de nouveaut√© ou de r√©el impact, ce qui peut rapidement ennuyer surtout ceux ou celles qui recherchent un peu plus de dynamisme dans un jeu d'horreur.

[h1]Un potentiel non exploit√©[/h1]

Si Blair Witch parvient √† cr√©er une ambiance unique et une connexion √©motionnelle avec le chien Bullet, cela ne suffit pas pour maintenir l'int√©r√™t tout au long de l'aventure. Malgr√© de bonnes intentions et une vision artistique appr√©ciable, l‚Äôexp√©rience s‚Äôessouffle trop vite, donnant l‚Äôimpression d‚Äôun potentiel qui n‚Äôa pas √©t√© pleinement exploit√©.

[h1]Pour une poign√©e de dollars[/h1]

Pour conclure, Blair Witch est un titre qui saura peut-√™tre s√©duire les fans inconditionnels de l‚Äôunivers original ou ceux qui aiment une ambiance lente et oppressante. Pour les autres, le jeu risque de se r√©v√©ler frustrant et de [i]perdre rapidement de son attrait[/i].

[i]Pet the Damn Dog[/i]

This game unfortunately has little in common with the 1999 classic found-footage horror of the same name, but throws in a nice callback every now and then so it can't hurt to brush up on your Blair Witch knowledge before playing (who was Rustin Parr again?). You're playing as Ellis Lynch, the most traumatized person on planet earth, and it's only gonna get worse. Spoilers ahead.

So, not only does this guy cause the death of 6 comrades during the Gulf War and kills an unarmed civilian woman, he then goes back to his civil life as a cop and immediately proceeds to shoot an unarmed teenager. With PTSD out the ass, he decides to go into the woods and live out his remaining days as a hermit, where he can surely do no more harm to anyone. Unfortunately, these woods are the Black Hills Forest aka. the place where the so-called Blair Witch has driven people to murderous insanity for centuries. So instead of hugging trees and eating berries he now, having become 'Carver', continues to kill 'trespassers' by the dozen, ultimately killing the 9 year old brother of the aforementioned teenager he shot dead during his time as a cop. Talk about a redemption arc...

Sounds pretty ridiculous but also straight forward enough? Well, it ain't that easy. The entire story is woven into a tapestry of confusing time loops and unless you read all the documents, experienced all the different endings and watched a youtube video or two you usually wouldn't know all this. The real horror was piecing all of this together. Frankly, forget about the story, not even the devs themselves understand it.

As for the gameplay, it's mostly a walking sim intertwined with some light puzzling and very occasional stealth and/or fighting parts. Most of the time you're just stumbling through the - admittedly - very well done and eerie woods with your faithful furry companion 'Bullet', a would-be service dog that didn't make the cut (but is still a good boy). The dog mechanics are cool and all, but with Bullet by your side at nearly all times, even the scarier parts of the game do not feel particularly scary.

I don't even know what to say about the last hour or so, it feels insanely drawn out. We get it, we're in some sort of loop. Please just let me finish the game. Please.

[b]6/10[/b]

Ich tue mich ein bisschen schwer mit der Entscheidung, ob mir dieses Spiel gef√§llt oder nicht. Denn einerseits macht es sehr viel richtig gut, aber andererseits hat es Elemente, die mich hochgradig genervt haben.
Die St√§rken des Spieles liegen eindeutig in der unglaublich starken Umsetzung der Wald-Atmosph√§re. Die Weite, die manchmal regelrecht in Verlorenheit umschl√§gt, die D√ºsternis und die zum Teil fast archaische Bedrohung werden durch die sehr starke Ger√§uschkulisse sowie die detailreiche und authentische Naturgestaltung extrem stark vermittelt. Mehr als einmal entdeckt man sich dabei, seinen treuen Begleiter Bullet zur eigenen Nervenberuhigung h√§ufiger zu streicheln als man es in den heimischen vier W√§nden getan h√§tte.
Was mich allerdings massiv an dem Spiel st√∂rt ist, dass die eigentliche Story eben diese Immersion allzu oft st√∂rt. Ohne zu spoilern kann ich nur darauf verweisen, dass zu viele (und zu klischeehafte) Neben-F√§den gekn√ºpft werden. Aber vor allem geht mir auf den Senkel, dass die urspr√ºngliche Blair Witch Geschichte meiner Meinung nach total verhunzt wird. Statt die M√∂glichkeiten des Hexen-Mythos  in dieser sinistren Umgebung vollst√§ndig auszusch√∂pfen, findet man sich bald in einer zu typischen Mensch-Monster-Story wieder.
Zudem hat es Bloober diesmal gegen Ende hin mit seinen typischen Mindfcuk-Elementen √ºbertrieben. Zum Teil hatte ich das Gef√ºhl, man wollte einfach nur die Spielzeit krampfhaft strecken. Ein Mindfcuk ist nur dann effektiv, wenn er kurz und pregnant ist. Wenn er allerdings eine gef√ºhlte Ewigkeit andauert, setzt irgendwann die √úbers√§ttigung und schlie√ülich die Langeweile ein.

Ich kann das Spiel also nicht vorbehaltlos empfehlen. Wenn es einen anderen Titel h√§tte, w√ºrde ich dem Spiel vielleicht sogar positiver gegen√ºberstehen, aber alles in allem gab es doch zu viele Passagen, die ich richtig stark fand, um es negativ zu bewerten.

Insgesamt von mir eine 6/10.
EL JUEGO ES MUY BUENO ENTRETENIDO NADA LINEAL ME QUEDO CON MUCHAS DUDAS DEL FINAL PERO RECOMENDADO

I got this game on a decent discount and at a low price of entry I really enjoyed it. It's short, and doesn't necessarily use its source material to its full potential, but I enjoyed it as a decently well produced horror adventure with some cool moments and good sound design.

Most horror games start out strong and finish weak, whereas this game sort of does the opposite; it's got a fairly weak opening but once it ramps up toward the end, things get much more atmospheric and the story becomes more interesting.

There are multiple endings so you could feasibly try out different approaches to see how it changes the game, so there's a bit of replayability there for next halloween!

column8:
This is such a missed opportunity. Had some real promising mechanics and ideas that go no where and get wasted. 
First of all it's not even "survival horror." It's just a glorified walking sim. There's no inventory or resources to manage, few if any "puzzles," and im using that term very generously, and only 3-4 monster encounters with a laughably basic battle mechanic of just looking in their general direction with a flashlight. Oh but to make it worse, fighting the threats trying to kill you leads to the bad ending, with no indication of the sort. In fact the game instructs you to do it after the first encounter, and your doggo companion even guides you to fight. But nooope, that's WrOnG tO dO. Also wrong to do? Collecting collectibles. Namely the ones specifically inside totems that your dog worries over and wants you to destroy. Help the dog and gain a collectible even once? Youre forever locked into the bad ending... And as if the "good" ending is even good, with the message of the game being "just ignore your worries and eventually kill yourself because youre the problem." Great take away game.
The story is super needlessly confusing. I LOVE Blair Witch and one of my favorite aspects of it is making you question what is real or what is madness. But this game never establishes a baseline for reality, almost instantly rushing into nonsensical odd happenings without even explaining any character's backstory or relationships. And the poor main character, it's like they couldn't decide what tragic history to give him, so they completely ruined his life to ensure something is always constantly messing with his mind. He's a war vet with PTSD. Oh but also has survivors guilt as he accidentally got his team killed. Oh and he also may have killed an innocent bystander to save himself. Oh and he's an ex cop that shot an unarmed robber. Oh and he's been through a break up recently. And none of this adds anything except for more confusion and longer cutscenes to try and explain things through cheap jumpscares.

Overall it wasn't a complete waste of time, and had some interesting ideas, concepts, and moments. But ultimately it's just not scary and not fun.

column8:
Slowly, you begin to uncover the traumas that haunt the main character, and as the story progresses, their contours materialize and distort her perception. The only constant you can safely lean on is your faithful companion, whose presence keeps you grounded in the reality of the world around you.

 The game has a stunning graphics, a breathtaking atmosphere and an ambiance that undercuts the emotions the game can evoke in you at times: anxiety, despair, confusion....At last you will find yourself teetering on the edge between reality and fantasy, the line of which is gradually fading, and the further you go, the harder it is to discern which plane you are currently on.

This felt so barely Blair Witch, like a post-reskin to brand and market it for better sales, when it would've felt like a better game if it created its own lore instead of desperately straining to force Blair Witch vibes into another idea.  Seriously, the only stuff that makes this Blair Witch is the standing in the corner thing (which is beaten to fucking death here), the forest and the time loop stuff.

As a big fan of the original movie and the 2016 reboot, this had NONE of the movies' vibes at all.  Instead it has a strange and uncomfortable main character who's a murderous combat vet and a shitty cop who we're supposed to feel sorry for because he has PTSD and a sympathetic innocent dog sidekick.  I have NO idea why Bloober decided to go this weird route, especially once you're made aware of the things he's done before the game even starts.

Add to that boring faux "combat" and stealth, an incredibly frustrating and lame final house segment; a fucking silly serial killer plot, this whole game is just a boring mess of bizarre and frankly stupid ideas.

I was pleasantly surprised by the depth of horror and atmosphere this game offers. While some players may find certain sections a bit tedious, the finale of the story truly makes the journey worthwhile. My only criticism is that I anticipated a more grounded experience, free from supernatural elements; I was hoping for an exploration of the forest that focused solely on the natural environment, devoid of any paranormal occurrences or flashbacks.

Blair Witch, Un paso adelante y dos atr√°s:
Ante todo aclaro que a la hora de jugar este juego no he visto nada de las pel√≠culas de Blair Witch as√≠ que no puedo opinar por el lado de c√≥mo es como adaptaci√≥n sino desde como es el juego en s√≠.
Este juego es algo complicado de abordar, la verdad no es bueno pero tiene al menos alguna que otra cosa rescatable: Rescato el hecho de que implic√≥ aunque sea un poco salir de las experiencias completamente pasilleras con escenarios aunque sea un poco m√°s abiertos, en este sentido han logrado una ambientaci√≥n muy buena de bosque espeso y oscuro y gr√°ficamente el juego era s√≥lido para su momento. Tambi√©n rescato la mec√°nica de la c√°mara entorno a afectar el entorno en tiempo real viendo videos, dio para un par de puzzles que estuvieron buenos. Si bien no es ‚ÄúThe last Guardian‚Äù, Bullet el perro que nos acompa√±a cumple y es razonablemente vivo e interactivo salvo en ciertas ocasiones que se bugea. Pero fuera de eso es una buena forma de guiar al jugador y salirse un poco de que las experiencias de terror sean completamente en solitario. Tambi√©n usar el celular y la radio se usan bien en lo que respecta para interactuar en la trama y poder cada tanto llamar o enviar mensajes.
Ahora bien, lo malo del juego recae en general una tensi√≥n muy meh y en mec√°nicas que m√°s que tensas son una molestia. Son absolutamente una broma algunas de las amenazas que nos plantea el juego con sus tenebrosas ‚Äúbolas de hojas oto√±ales‚Äù y ‚Äúbichos que se escapan si los iluminas‚Äù que no intimidan en lo m√°s m√≠nimo. Y despu√©s ocasiones en la que el juego fuerza mec√°nicas de vista limitada, que en papel podr√≠an estar bien, pero desde su ejecuci√≥n se sienten que todo el tiempo estas forzando moverte de manera incomoda, m√°ximos ejemplos de esto son secciones como de la niebla o la √∫ltima secci√≥n de la casa.
Otra cosa muy irritante son algunas secciones que hacen loop constantemente de escenarios que se hacen tardar una eternidad, encontrar todo el tiempo elementos que no sirven para nada, el juego puede llegar a bugearse en momentos importantes. Tambi√©n al activar una opci√≥n gr√°fica en la m√°s alta romp√≠a la visualizaci√≥n de los videos de la c√°mara, el juego realmente a veces pon√≠a a prueba mi paciencia con estos problemas.
Narrativamente no necesariamente es una mala idea, pero el juego me genera la sensaci√≥n de que no sabe empalmar bien el bosque y la bruja en relaci√≥n a los traumas del protagonista veterano de guerra y hay varias partes que realmente no significan mucho. Las variantes de c√≥mo sacar distintos finales no solo se sienten arbitrarias sino que adem√°s las diferencies entre finales son completamente paup√©rrimas, siendo de ese tipo de que cambia una cinem√°tica ligeramente m√°s que un final distinto trabajado.
Para empeorar las cosas el juego abandona el mejor elemento que tiene que es el bosque en el √∫ltimo tramo del juego y nos hace andar por pasillos que se sienten eternos y tambi√©n algo redundantes.
La verdad no puedo recomendar el juego, sin embargo capaz fan√°ticos de este g√©nero al menos le pueden sacar un poquito de jugo con la ambientaci√≥n y momentos puntuales de gameplay. Pero es una experiencia terriblemente irregular e irritante.

column8:
Blair Witch

Eins sei vorweg gesagt, es hat nichts mit dem Film aus dem Jahre 1999 zu tun, als 3 junge Studenten in den Wald gingen, um die Hexe von Blair zu suchen und verschwanden. Das Spiel enth√§lt aber einige Passagen bzw. √Ñhnlichkeiten. Trotzdem sollte man nicht dauernd an den Film denken.

Ich hab gerade eben mein ersten Durchgang fertig gemacht und hab ein Spoilerfreien Guide f√ºr die Sammel Items benutzt, da ich ungerne Spiele 3-4x spielen m√∂chte. Zudem sind einige Errungenschaften ohne Guide kaum machbar. Nicht, weil es schwer ist, sondern, weil man nicht wei√ü, was zu tun ist.

Das Spiel beginnt recht gut und die Wald Atmosph√§re ist beeindruckend. Man hat schon am Tag ein mulmiges Gef√ºhl. Mit dabei ist unser Hund "Bullet". Unser Ziel ist es das Kind Peter zu finden, was hier verschwunden ist. Nach kurzer Zeit kommen auch schon irgendwelche Waldwesen, die wir mit der Taschenlampe wegklatschen.

Aber leider dreht sich das Game schnell um 180 Grad und pl√∂tzlich geht es mehr um uns. Wir waren Anscheinend ein Soldat und haben was getan oder erlebt. Diese Erinnerung folgen uns und das letzte St√ºck im Spiel besteht irgendwie total aus einer Reihe von vielen Psycho Sachen, die uns nach und nach an den Kopf geworfen werden. 

Ich hatte am Ende echt kaum Lust mehr zu zocken. Es war sehr nervig. Der Anfang war echt toll, sch√∂ner Wald, dann Dunkelheit und nur die Lampe. Daher gebe ich mein Daumen runter und sage "Nein" zum Spiel. 

Ich werde es aber noch einmal spielen, da man f√ºr alle Errungenschaften min. 2x Durchspielen muss. Wer ohne Guide spielt aber alles haben m√∂chte, muss sogar 3x spielen. Weil man im ersten Durchgang nicht alles selbst finden wird. Ich dachte schon beim Guide so "Wtf, wie sollte man das so raus finden?" Zum Gl√ºck ist der letzte Durchgang der schnellste, da man nichts sammeln muss, au√üer halt Story bedingte Sachen - trz gibt es einiges zu beachten, wenn man alle Enden erreichen will.

I would give this game 3 out of 5 stars. It was really dark which I suppose is supposed to add to the horror factor but it makes it kinda hard to play. I got lost a few times and wasted a lot of time wandering around in the woods, but I guess that would be on par with the movie! I don't know how anyone could get the "happy" ending on this game, but it does kind of make you want to play again just to see if you could. I agree with some other reviewers about the ending getting monotonous, but it wasn't too bad. Overall, if you can get this on sale and you liked the movie, I would buy this!

Este juego es una completa BASURA, tiene una cantidad de errores basicos impresionante.
1) Si tenes un CPU Intel de d√©cima generaci√≥n o m√°s reciente te vas a encontrar con un error al iniciar el juego, el error es del OpenSSL. Se soluciona facil instalando su ultima version, aun asi, esto se podria haber evitado si el desarrollador hubiese usado una version en la que no tenga este error al instalar el juego.
2) Tiene errores al guardar partida (forma manual/automatica), el progreso se te puede guardar como no. Hay muchos quejandose que el progreso nunca se les guarda. Probando y a mi algunas veces se me guardaba y otras no(Mientras avanzaba de zona)
3) No te cuentan los logros, de ningun tipo. Ni de los coleccionables ni de la historia...
Hace mucho que estan estos problemas y todavia no los solucionaron... para lo unico que sirve este juego es para sacarle los cromos.

column8:
Ok... I am a horror girly but for the life of me, I cannot play horror games. I just get too scared and end up closing the game, to never return to it again. 

Until now!!!!

With Bullet in my corner, I feel like I can literally tackle ANYTHING (within reason, NO ZOMBIES!!)

I am really enjoying everything about this game so far. Love the classic Blair Witch tale. It is the perfect balance between horror, exploration and story. I am just grateful that I don't have to navigate it alone. Adding the dog companion to accompany you and  help you along the way was a pleasant, unique twist that I have not seen in other games of this genre before. 

And you get to customize how he looks and feed him treats...awwhhhhhhh >.<

Genuinely cannot wait to launch this game back up again to complete the story with my pal, Bullet <3 Here‚Äôs to hoping we both make it out of this forest alive!

column8: I got the game for $6 on a big sale. At the price point the game is worth it, at full price I would wait. The game is more of an interactive story then a game. Most of the game you are going from point to point following a set path, be it marks on the ground, your dog or the only path a head of you to get more of the story to play out around you. There is some very easy puzzles to solve. The game does have different endings but on your first play through you really have no idea as its never hinted at or explained how to come about different endings. I did enjoy the story and walking through it but if you are looking to play something and not experience something I wouldn't get this one.

column8:
Blair Witch es una experiencia inmersiva que sorprende gratamente a quienes buscan algo m√°s que simples sobresaltos. A diferencia de otros t√≠tulos del g√©nero, aqu√≠ el terror no depende de la cantidad de sustos por minuto, sino de una construcci√≥n atmosf√©rica impecable, donde el bosque se convierte en un personaje m√°s: opresivo, denso, y casi palpable.

El juego logra conectar emocionalmente a trav√©s de una historia personal que se entrelaza h√°bilmente con el mito original. No es necesario ser fan de la saga cinematogr√°fica para sentirse atrapado en esta narrativa oscura y psicol√≥gica. El uso del compa√±ero canino, Bullet, no solo es original, sino que tambi√©n aporta un v√≠nculo emocional genuino que a√±ade peso a las decisiones del jugador.

A nivel t√©cnico, destaca el dise√±o de sonido, que juega un rol fundamental en la creaci√≥n del suspenso. Cada crujido, cada eco entre los √°rboles, est√° pensado para mantenerte al borde. Si bien hay algunos detalles t√©cnicos menores que podr√≠an pulirse, en nada empa√±an la experiencia general.

Blair Witch es una grata sorpresa dentro del g√©nero de horror psicol√≥gico, con una historia s√≥lida, una ambientaci√≥n absorbente y una jugabilidad que sabe mantenerte en tensi√≥n sin recurrir a lo obvio.

Nota: 8/10. Un viaje oscuro y emocional que merece ser vivido.

column8: BUEN JUEGO

I came across this game by accident while looking for something to buy at a lower price. At first glance, it seemed interesting, and I decided to buy it. But how wrong I was! As I played through the game, I realized that it was boring, long, and routine. All I wanted was for it to end as soon as possible.
The game is shrouded in darkness and mystery, and no, not because it is cool, but because they don‚Äôt explain anything. You wander through the forest, see trees on the left, trees on the right, trees everywhere ‚Äì nothing is clear, nothing is explained. The only things I liked were the high-quality graphics and the ending of the game. And no, I liked the ending not because it was interesting and cool, but because I realized that I didn‚Äôt need to play this game anymore.
In general, I don‚Äôt recommend buying this game ‚Äì it‚Äôs better to buy ice cream. This is just my opinion.

Blair Witch: You play as a guy lost in a cursed forest, desperately searching for someone while slowly losing his sanity. Prepare to wander in circles, question your IQ with puzzles, and fight monsters that disappear like emo kids in sunlight. Meanwhile, your character‚Äôs PTSD dials up the creepiness to max.

Your dog‚Äôs either a lifesaver or completely useless, with no middle ground. He also loves to randomly spawn next to you, scaring the life out of you with sudden barks.

It‚Äôs like a camping trip, but with extra trauma and zero chance of actually finding who you‚Äôre looking for. Overall, a solid 8/10‚Äîhad a blast!

Might work for others, did not work for me. Feels like a forest walking sim with an unbearable mc and a buggy dog - I thought that he had something for me and tried to search around for 20 minutes until I realized that he was just simply stuck and bugged out. 

I however do adore the tape mechanic, it's well thought of and made a sense of wonder when first discovered. Soundtrack is good. Playing with your phone is fun!

I might still play around and grind the achievements, but as a horror game I can't recommend this.

column8:
It's not horrible, but it's not good. It fails on the horror front, and the puzzles range anywhere from so easy that there wasn't any point of there being a puzzle in the first place, to absurdly cryptic. 

And the same can be said for the level design. It ranges from a linear path that you can't deviate from - to an open forest with no distinguishable marks. Which you would think would add to the horror element. But it doesn't. It just becomes a chore walking for 10 minutes, not knowing that there's a very specific yet indistinguishable tree you're supposed to look up at, then walking back another 10 minutes to find it. At a certain point, this becomes one of those "look up a guide every few steps" kind of games. It's not difficult by any means, the puzzles/progression are just far too crytpic.

On the topic of cryptic, there are some flat out bad design choices. At one point, you come across someone you can interact with them. At this point in the game, it has become obvious to interact with every single story object you find to progress. However, interacting with him kills him and inadvertently adds towards you getting the bad ending. There is absolutely nothing that would indicate you're killing him, and you're punished for doing what has been the fundamental for progressing the entire time.

The game heavily relies on using your pet companion, Bullet, as a somewhat guide. You're introduced to mechanics such as having him search for items, and to show you where to go. It feels like this element is almost completely stripped from the game as soon as it's introduced. There are only very key moments in very specific scenarios that you can actually utilize him. Other than that, he consistently gets lost or ignores commands completely. Maybe they were going for the realism aspect of a dog being disobedient. But then again, Bullet is a good boy. I have a hard time believing he would ever pull such nonsense. Bullet good. Bullet AI bad. 

The monsters are very "meh". They aren't particularly scary, and the "combat" is just a chore. Shine your flashlight on them while they zip around like a schizophrenic toddler on adderall. The few moments you get to see them while they don't have a case of the zoomies, they look serviceable enough. Nothing particularly dread inducing, but they're fine.

At a certain point, it feels like a sunken cost fallacy. It is no longer particularly enjoyable to play, but you figure you've already seen this much so you might as well see where the story goes. And that's where I can give it some praise. The first 10% or so of the game felt promising, then it becomes almost all filler, and the last 20% is where it truly turns into something worthwhile. The last part of the game it starts to become much more coherent. The pacing leaves enough room for tension, but simultaneously like you're making progress. The horror aspect is there, finally giving some uneasy feeling that isn't tedious. The progression is much more rewarding. It has a good balance between needing to put thought into what to do next, without being so cryptic you have to rely looking up a guide every few minutes.

I got this game for $5 on sale. And for that price, I say it's worth it enough if you're really into horror. The graphics are good, and there are certainly elements of the game that are enjoyable. It has a strong enough opening, and towards the ending it becomes a very decent game. But the cryptic puzzles and monotonous gameplay that span a majority of the game, combined with the seemingly broken companion AI sadly take away far too much to really say it's worth drudging through the time it takes to get there. It ultimately feels like too many ideas were thrown into the mix, with very few of them actually being fleshed out. It's not a horrible experience. It's not a great one. It's just kind of there.

I‚Äôve got some mixed feelings about it. On the spooky scale, it definitely delivers. The atmosphere is creepy, and there are plenty of moments that made me jump. However, there's a bit of cheesiness that comes with it, which kind of takes away from the overall horror experience.

One of the main mechanics, the video recorder, isn't well explained at all. I found myself having to do research just to figure out how to use it properly. That was a bit of a buzzkill, to be honest.  I feel like it should be explained more thoroughly. 

Now, let's talk about the technical side. If you don‚Äôt cap the FPS, the game can run at an insane 500fps. This can seriously overload your computer. I have a pretty beefy setup with 64GB of RAM, and even then, the game was hogging 90% of my video RAM and overall system resources. That's a huge issue that really needs addressing, or at least a notice that you should definitely cap. 

As for the graphics, they're okay. They look pretty fuzzy and outdated, which is a shame because the game has so much potential to be visually stunning. Despite this, the game does manage to create a very atmospheric and eerie setting. It‚Äôs just that with some updates, it could be so much better and genuinely scarier. I think it would have been scarier, if the game was in ps1 or ps2 style.. like a silent hill. 

Overall, The Blair Witch Project game is okay. It‚Äôs spooky and has a great atmosphere, but there are several areas that need improvement. With some updates, especially on the technical side and graphics, it could be a much more terrifying experience.
I recommend it because it typically goes on sale, and is perfect to play in Spooktober.

column8: Tolle Story gefiehl mir sehr gut

Just a nice horror game. At times confusing locations and closer to the end you think "when will this end", despite the game being way shorter than other games of this kind. 

It feels kind of incomplete, not from the sense of game mechanics, but from the story. Basically, you will run a million miles in a repetitive forest, finding hints that your friend is struggling, then having two short interesting moments and thereafter the ending proceeds. The ending that is by the way classic for horror games, and is relatively long, because you already get the idea for the non-existent "twist" just right after the ending starts (or earlier, if you played other horror games before). So it just generally feels like "why did I wander in the forest for eternity just to get these two thingies and for the game to end then?". 

It is still a good horror game, kind of how you're watching a random movie when you're having nothing to watch. You play it one time, but it is unlikely you will return, and after a week you forget everything about the game. Regarding price, definitely get it on sale. For 30 euros you can get a high-level game that doesn't consist of running through the forest ad infinitum.

For those who see people getting stuck in the forest, this location is indeed hard and I was there for maybe 1-2 hours. Basically you go in one exit and arrive to the other side of the forest, kind of a loop, until you find one micro detail to proceed. It was the most annoying part but manageable without external help.

You play it one time, but it is unlikely you will return, and after a week you forget everything about the game. Regarding price, definitely get it on sale. For 30 euros you can get a high-level game that doesn't consist of running through the forest ad infinitum.

For those who see people getting stuck in the forest, this location is indeed hard and I was there for maybe 1-2 hours. Basically you go in one exit and arrive to the other side of the forest, kind of a loop, until you find one micro detail to proceed. It was the most annoying part but manageable without external help.

The pop culture classic 1994 film The Blair Witch is a difficult film to base a game on. Its hand held camera filmed style has influenced a generation of games and films. So making a game set on the license is tricky without falling into cliche. However the game succeeds in keeping things fresh and full of twists while keeping the mysterious and disturbing atmosphere of that original film. There is barely any HUD. No compass or sense of direction and the players only guide and aid is their dog Bullet. this makes for very cool and innovative gameplay where how you treat Bullet effects the many endings of the game. Impressively the devs respect the lore around the Black Hills Forest, The Blair Witch herself and the murders, but they add their own flair and build on the lore in unexpected ways. Definitely recommended if youre a fan of the cult classic and enjoy horror games that arent just jump scares and have some layer and depth to them.

Only experience of the Blair Witch universe is the original found footage movie, not seen the 2016 version but from what I understand this is based around that? Actually enjoyed my playthrough of this, though much shorter than I thought it would be and the final sequence was a bit too drawn out to a point that I thought it would never end which killed it a little for me, but beyond that I liked what it brought to the table, and the fact it has multiple endings based on several choices you make through the game is quite interesting and makes you actively think about what to do at the right time to affect the overall outcome.

There is an autosave system and a way to manually save but its a kind of dud save system since the manual save just saves a hard copy of the last autosave point as it constantly overwrites 3 seperate autosaves, so you only MOSTLY have to live with your choices, but often those choices you make aren't always immediately apparent which makes you think about every little thing you do, its actually kind of brilliant in a way.

Visually quite a stunning game, the forest looks dense and 'real' with a semi-open map along a linear path. For a shorter game the pacing doesn't feel rushed at all, in fact it felt just right most of the time. The sound design and voice acting is top tier, the atmosphere often feels tense but not necessarily scary, the game did have to fall back on a few cheap jump scares but they were entirely forgivable sins. The dog companion is of course a brilliant addition and works as an excellent guide through the game without the use of immersion breaking visuals like giant arrows or 'yellow paint syndrome'.

Just remember, you look after Bullet, Bullet look after YOU!

Solid 8/10 from me

column8:
The use of the dog is a great idea, but ruined by it being a bad NPC that breaks occasionally. It walks in short bursts with limited options of what you can actually do with it. It doesn't feel like a dog. Half the time you are trying to find the dog if you even look around slightly. 
The enemies are laughable and there is no real tension. Shine your light at them and they go away. 
The only thing that worked well was the puzzle aspect (rewinding time using tapes and finding clues in them)
Overall it isn't a great game, but it passes some time I guess?

column8:
I had already played this game on Xbox before and the replay on PC was just as memorable now as it was back then. This game focuses and relies heavily on its story, which is one of regret and ghosts from the past, and works wonders in the Blair Witch setting. Maybe it's not a good Blair Witch game, but I definitely consider it a very good horror game. And the last chapter? Some of the most creative Psychological horror stuff I've seen in a while. 

The only place this game is a bit lacking is gameplay, mostly revolving around puzzles and fighting monsters, as well as getting collectables, the camera puzzles are cool as well and adds a fun twist that links the Blair Witch found footage style to game mechanics. 

If you're a player who enjoys Story driven games, this is a MUST PLAY, but if you prefer gameplay driven games and still wanna give this a try, then maybe wait until its on sale. 

This game has found a place in my list of favorite horror games of all time, right up there with Outlast and SOMA.

Also, this game has a dog. Bullet is a very good boy. You wouldn't want to disappoint Bullet, would you?

"Blair Witch" started off promising but quickly devolved into a buggy and frustrating experience. Numerous glitches interrupted gameplay, leading to frequent reloads and loss of progress. The game often felt like a walking simulator, with minimal interaction and clumsy jump scares. The story, loosely based on the weakest Blair Witch movie (2016), was disappointing, and the only redeeming features were the graphics and dog mechanics, which were underutilized. Overall, it was not a good or scary game and didn't do justice to the Blair Witch universe. The game had a lot of references to the films, including the famous house in the ending, but this wasn't enough to save it from being a lackluster experience.

Detailed Ratings with Pros and Cons
Graphics: 9/10

Pros: Visually impressive with detailed forest environments, weather effects, and well-made character animations.
Cons: None significant; the graphics are a strong point of the game.

Sound: 8/10

Pros: Good sound design, voice acting, and music enhance the creepy atmosphere.
Cons: Some voice acting, particularly for the main character, could be better.

Gameplay: 4/10

Pros: Innovative mechanics like using tapes to manipulate objects.
Cons: The game is plagued by bugs, feels repetitive, and offers minimal interaction beyond walking.

Story: 4/10

Pros: Contains references to the Blair Witch films and has some interesting moments.
Cons: The story is shallow, disjointed, and does not add much depth to the Blair Witch lore.

Replayability: 3/10

Pros: Multiple endings are available.
Cons: Endings do not vary significantly and the game‚Äôs repetitive nature discourages replay.

Difficulty: 3/10

Pros: Some puzzles and combat mechanics.
Cons: Puzzles are trivial and combat is simplistic; difficulty mainly arises from bugs.

Performance: 3/10

Pros: None significant.
Cons: Significant performance issues including frame rate drops and numerous technical glitches.


Controls: 5/10

Pros: Generally responsive.
Cons: Inability to rebind keys, which is problematic for players with disabilities.

Innovation: 6/10

Pros: Interesting mechanics like using tapes to manipulate the environment.
Cons: These mechanics are underutilized.

Immersion: 7/10

Pros: Successfully creates a creepy atmosphere due to sound and graphical design.
Cons: Immersion is often broken by technical issues and repetitive gameplay.

Value for Money: 4/10

Pros: Contains some interesting and atmospheric moments.
Cons: Too expensive for its short length and overall quality.

User Interface (UI): 4/10

Pros: None significant.
Cons: The UI is clunky and not user-friendly.

Scary Factor: 4/10

Pros: Some psychological horror elements and occasional jump scares.
Cons: Not very scary; relies on atmosphere rather than genuinely frightening moments.

Atmosphere: 8/10

Pros: The game excels in creating a creepy, immersive environment. The forest is dark and foreboding, adding to the tension.
Cons: The atmosphere is often undermined by bugs and repetitive gameplay.

Level Design: 7/10

Pros: Varied environments within the forest, good use of light and shadow, and effective weather effects. The famous house at the end is a notable highlight.
Cons: Some parts of the level design feel repetitive, and certain flashback scenes are out of place.

Overall Rating: 4/10

Despite its beautiful graphics, level design, and atmospheric elements, "Blair Witch" fails to deliver as a good or scary game. It is primarily a walking simulator plagued with performance issues and a shallow story, making it hard to recommend at full price. Fans of the Blair Witch universe might appreciate the references and atmosphere, but overall, the game does not live up to its potential.

Impossibilit√© de reconfigurer la moindre touche, le jeu est adapt√© aux claviers QWERTY, donc pr√©voyez une manette ou devoir bidouiller, tout simplement honteux de pas laisser la possibilit√© de changer les touches en 2019 date de sortie du jeu.

Le cot√© faussement labyrinthique est mal fait, on avance b√™tement et tr√®s facilement ou on tourne en rond car on est parfois dans le noir complet, et le sc√©nario on le voit venir a dix kilom√®tres, rien de surprenant d'original ou m√™me de captivant.

column8:
I'm recommending against this game for one reason only.  There is a pretty common bug, apparently, and one that affected me in the final chapter.  The bug I'm talking about is the video camera breaking and you can no longer watch tapes on it.  It's just a black screen.  In order to progress in the final chapter you need to watch two tapes.  This bug made that impossible.  I quit, reloaded the game, and it was fixed but lost about 45 minutes of progress during the absolute worst part of this game.

The final chapter is terrible.  It's a miserable experience.  It's over an hour long and I don't want to spoil anything but I also don't want people to waste their money on this game.  It's just utter garbage.  

If it weren't for the bugs and the final chapter I would 1000% recommend this game.  I thought the ambience during the first 50-75% of the game was amazing.  The forest is really well done and so are the little things that happen in it that give you the sense that things are going on around you.  The ambient noises and every so often you swear you see something out of the corner of your eye.. really well done... but my GOD the bugs and the final chapter killed it for me.  

If it was JUST the final chapter even then I'd say get it on sale, but some bugs are absolutely game breaking and you cannot save your progress beyond the auto-saves.  Even if you manually save, you'll go back to where the last auto save happened.  Unless they want to fix the bugs (and this is a 4 year old game so... that ain't happening lmao) don't waste your money and try some other game instead.

Also it's not really a blair witch experience.

As a big Blair Witch fan is not a good game by any means. Is vaguely based in the weakest entry (Blair Witch 2016) and its just a walking sim with exploration and some clumsy jump scares. 
The story is a dissapoiment to say the least and the only saving grace are the graphics and the dog mechanics (and underutilized). The older resident evil style entries made by Terminal Reality were so much better than this... Sigh
Another Bloober Team fiasco. I hope Silent Hill 2 is better.

column8:
Developers ask you to post a review after completing the game, so here you go. I expected a somewhat realistic setting and story with some nuance of supernatural. Instead, you get a psychedelic mess with ending chapter that doesn‚Äôt deserve to be more than 5 minutes long, lasting and hour(!!) I was sitting there in absolute disbelief, how could someone make it so bad. Again, instead of interesting story and a satisfactory ending you get talentless developers who couldn‚Äôt write and interesting story, and instead decide to throw an hour-long psychedelic sequence in a 4-hour game to wrap things up. Horrible. 

As a side note you need a guide to have a good ending or play a second playthrough which this game absolutely doesn‚Äôt deserve. If you want all achievements you need to play it three times, and I ask you to not even bother or buy the game which costed me 1,5 euro.

This started out quite promising the first night I had a proper go at the game. I reached a point, saved and returned the next day.. to a buggy mess of a game. I got stuck in the scenery so had to reload and lost 15 minutes gameplay. When I returned I kept getting led back to to the same point with an eye symbol that I was not able to interact with. I wondered around for another 30 minutes getting nowhere. Frustrated quit out. Reloaded to give it another try. This time i could interact with with the eye symbol, ok it was another bug, move on. Shortly after, I pick up of the witch sticks or whatever they are again which reveals a photo... and I cant put it away, cant move. No option but to exit again. Probably for the last time. Im not sure how people have racked up 5 to 8 hours in this. Im in no mood to start the game over so I guess thats it.

Decid√≠ probarlo para ver si pod√≠a encontrar alguna forma de liberarme de las cadenas del pasado que me ataban. Al principio, parec√≠a una simple distracci√≥n de mis problemas, pero pronto me di cuenta de que el juego estaba desenterrando recuerdos enterrados en lo m√°s profundo de mi mente. Cada sombra en el bosque, cada sonido inquietante, parec√≠a sacar a la luz viejas heridas que hab√≠a tratado de olvidar. Blair Witch se convirti√≥ en un espejo de mi propio dolor, reflejando los traumas y las angustias que me hab√≠an perseguido durante a√±os. Ahora, mientras contin√∫o mi viaje a trav√©s de los oscuros bosques del juego, s√© que cada encuentro con lo desconocido me lleva m√°s cerca de la verdad sobre mi pasado, pero tambi√©n m√°s cerca del abismo de la desesperaci√≥n en el que he vivido durante tanto tiempo.

Unfortunately I have to agree with the negative reviews. The story is too predictable, and after a promising start it falls short of expectations, and gets really boring in the 2nd half. The last chapter is waaay too protracted (and disorienting), and both endings are underwhelming.

The dog is a cute addition, it's a pity that the AI is rather poor. I encountered the same bug multiple times; the dog got stuck in parts of the environment, so I had to reload a previous checkpoint.

Overall not bad, but pretty mediocre, buy it only on sale.
column9:

The dog is a cute addition, it's a pity that the AI is rather poor. I encountered the same bug multiple times; the dog got stuck in parts of the environment, so I had to reload a previous checkpoint.

Overall not bad, but pretty mediocre, buy it only on sale.

THE GAME was pretty goo d I'd say, i had few jumps in playing the game LOL. The only thing was the house was so long, I thought I was just lost or it kept restarting at first, but it just took some pushing to get through.
Even with the long push the house was full of jump scares and kept me at the edge of my seat Witch also made it my favorite part of the game. Overall the game went very smoothly, I didn't get too stuck on it or have any problems, some parts though I did get lost for a bit but nothing too bad. THANK YOU GUYS for the great game I would love to see what you guys have cooking up in the lab in the future.  My live game play of the game is here- https://youtube.com/live/H_y0UsIJ2Ts

column8: another game down from these devs. i didn't even know this game existed until recently but i am glad i picked it up. blair witch was one of the old classic horror movies i watched with a friend and was convinced that it was actually real. they made it seem like it and even the actors in some parts had to formulate because they genuinely lost things. overall watching the movie never made me want to step foot near a forest when i was younger. this story was great, the gameplay is decent and having bullet around was nice. it unfolds pretty nicely for a 3 dollar game, the graphics are good, sound design is solid and it gives a good experience and goes into the lore of what blair witch is all about. if you were a fan of the OG movie, definitely give this game a go. i got a key for $3, worth every penny.
