So many weird storylines, interactables, collectables, locations and a doggo? You can already in your mind see how there must be a good ending if you collect everything and the doggo lives etc etc, or a super bad ending maybe, and then some endings where depending on which choices/interactables more info gets revealed. But AFAIK: The sherrif just dies no matter what. The kid's fate is out of your hands. Your dog's fate is somewhat in your hands maybe, but it has to die for the plot. The war, family, hospital plot is just flung at you no matter what, same with the loon. And the only ending that is different requires you to collect NO collectibles and not defend yourself from the monsters... Like how is this organically conveyed??? Its not like the first time you find a totem your char goes "Prolly shouldn't mess with this" and give you the option of putting it back down. Or carry the doggo past the scary effigies. Or even signal that the monsters dying is a bad thing. This is as if you discover a secret ending to Mario if you break no blocks, and collect 0 coins during the playthrough, and only kill bosses. HOW IS THIS ORGANICALLY CONVEYED.

The game is loops on loops on loops, the building, the forrest, the gameplay, even the game's story itself is a loop. (don't think about it because you kidnapped the kid but then also went to search for the kid but spend days weeks months in there but the kid was back after 3 days?) With a story way more complex than need be with too many threads. Gameplay that is just too long at the end that I cannot imagine myself replaying it. However. This game has some really cool moments, and I think the dog mechanic is a thing that could be improved and did add something interesting to a horror experience. Being alone is scary, being with something you care for and want to protect is even scarier. The phone and collectibles influencing your end could be a VERY cool, but instead its a binary "normal gameplay"vs "hyper specific quota" ending. [/spoiler]

It feels like as if the writer wanted a different IP. The level designer had too many ideas and didnt wanna cut any. And the gameplay vision just wasn't there 100% I Like this game. I truly do. But this is a cake with chunks of raw dough, 10 different frostings and a theme that just makes you go "but why?".

Pick it up on a sale if u love horror.

column8: No te podes culear a la bruja

The game is not nearly as scary as I thought it will be and that, I am a little disappointed about. Definitely nowhere near its source material, the original Blair Witch film. 
The visuals and sound design are good and the story and characters are not bad either. Although, I do think that a little less music, a little less dialogue and a little less story might have made this game much better than it is. Somehow, even though our protagonist's backstory and its relation to the events in the game is not badly written, it definitely waters down the horror aspects of the game. Honestly, despite the great visual environment, it never matches up to the uncomfortable terror that the film excels at creating, primarily because the film makes you feel more immersed in your experience rather than explaining much about why all this is happening to the character that you are playing in the game. Horror games work better with less meaningfulness I think.  
Our dog companion, Bullet, is really cute. Though, while he is a great character and one of the best things about the game, his presence definitely makes the atmosphere of the game far more comfortable and safe than it should feel. His absence, in some ways, at least, might have made the game a little more terrifying. 
The main antagonist is okay. But he does talk too much and overshadows the main character of the franchise - the blair witch - in every way, unfortunately. Also, not a particularly scary or originally written character anyway.
It is a decent game and clearly a lot of effort has been put behind it but I would recommend buying it if on sale. Although, if you do like horror games with more emphasis on story, character and dialogue, this might be a good choice of game, irrespective of price. Definitely better than Alan Wake fare.

column8:
The whole game is basically just a big psychodrama. Apart from that, it lacks fantasy content or other meaningful lore.
Fights, if you can call them so, consist in circling over and over until your light hits the monsters. 
The pace is very slow, there are little to no puzzles or things to do or to understand, other than the path forward and where objects are located.
Some sceneries are quite well-done, but sometimes the forest looks like an undifferentiated mass. Since the game was released in 2019, the vegetations (particularly in the fog) could have been done better.
The game feels like a set of very, too lenghty movie scenes. 
Maybe I would have enjoyed this story more had it been presented in a short film, for example in a 30-minutes-long film.
I believe some people might like this sort of games, but I do not.

column8:
Habe mir √ºberlegt das Spiel in der H√§lfte abzubrechen, es aber dann doch durchgezogen und es hart bereut.

Vorab das positive zu diesem l√§cherlichen Walking-Simulator:

-Grafik ist sch√∂n, daf√ºr aber dank schlechter Optimisation auch Hardware-lastig. Hat mich jetzt nicht so gejuckt, weil mein PC ganz stabil ist, aber wer mit seiner aus dem letzten Loch pfeifenden GTX 1070 daher kommt soll halt keine 144 FPS erwarten.
-Atmosph√§re im Wald selbst ist sehr gut, da k√∂nnen sich einige Spiele was abschauen
-mehr gutes gibt es nicht.

Die Story im groben:

Wir spielen einen Veteran mit PTSD und Geltungsdrang der auf dem schnellsten Weg zum Wald ist, weil sich ein kleiner Bub darin verlaufen hat und er der Polizei bei der Suche unterst√ºtzen will. 

Alle, sogar seine verflossene Alpha-Karen-Freundin mit der wir st√§ndig ungewollten Kontakt aufnehmen m√ºssen, zweifeln daran, dass er diese Suche nach dem Kind mental √ºberhaupt verpackt, weil der d√∂dl halt gleich noch ein dickes Kindheitstrauma mit sich schleift. Nat√ºrlich geht alles schief und er hat seine erste Panikattacke keine 3 Minuten zwischen den B√§umen. 

Ab dann dackelt man seinem Hund hinterher (dazu sp√§ter mehr) und versucht das Kind zu finden, obwohl man sich schon lange selbst im Wald verlaufen hat. Aber das ist egal, weil der Protagonist so einen harten Geltungsdrang hat, dass er um das Kind zu finden lieber 10-mal selbst sein Leben lassen w√ºrde. Voll verst√§ndlich.

Highlights der Story sind schlechte Puzzles und wenig Horror gepaart mit absolut oberfl√§chlichem und schlechtem Storywriting. Selbst das Ende mit Plot Twist ist weder Deep noch unvorhersehbar‚Ä¶

Meine Lieblingstellen waren entweder die Szene in der man √ºber 5 Minuten durch immer wieder denselben Korridor l√§uft, weil die Autoren selbst nicht mehr wussten was sie als n√§chsten machen sollen ODER das Ende welches in einem 140m¬≤ Haus auf 2 Etagen spielt welches sich gut 60 Minuten zieht und immer wieder neue Formen annimmt. Keine Ahnung wie ich es geschafft habe zu dem Zeitpunkt das Spiel nicht zu deinstallieren‚Ä¶

Der Horroraspekt ist abartig l√§cherlich. Habe von dem Game echt was zum F√ºrchten erwartet, aber bis auf die grusel-Atmosph√§re im Wald passiert da nix. Mit Jumpscares wird sich sehr zur√ºckgehalten, was ich aber gut finde, da dass sch√§biger Horror w√§re. 

Es gibt ein paar Momente wo man sich gegen Monster verteidigen muss, welches einfach mit der Taschenlampe gedeixelt wird. Eins zu eins aus Alan Wake geklaut.

Jetzt kommt eines der gr√∂√üten Mankos im Spiel welches sehr subjektiv ist. Ihr m√ºsst euch die ganze Zeit um ein schei√ü Vieh k√ºmmern. Durch die PTSD habt ihr einen Service-Doggo bekommen, welcher als Key-Element in der Story UND Gameplay dient. Ohne das Vieh geht nix, weil wir ihm quasi die ganze Zeit hinterherrennen m√ºssen. Dieses abartige Schei√ü-Vieh ist so gut umgesetzt worden, dass man fast Lust bekommt sich in Auto zu setzen und auf den n√§chsten K√∂ter drauf zu halten den man auf der Stra√üe sieht. Er kostet einfach Nerven und gibt einem die ganze Zeit das Gef√ºhl mehr Klotz am Bein anstatt eine Hilfe zu sein. Man hat im Gameplay sehr kurzzeitig eine Pistole und kann ihn damit nicht verschie√üen, 0/10 Sterne. Au√üerdem macht es total Spa√ü sich um den kleinen Schei√üer k√ºmmern zu m√ºssen, da welches von den 3 Enden man bekommt abh√§ngig davon ist, wie man die T√∂le behandelt hat. Sehr innovativ! - in die falsche Richtung halt.

Die Steuerung ist Schmutz. Keine Ahnung ob es daran liegt, dass es f√ºr Konsolenkneckos besser ist oder die VR-Version dadurch besser funktioniert, aber mit M+KB ist es einfach nur eine undurchdachte drecks Steuerung.

Der Preis juckt mich jetzt nicht, aber f√ºr welche die mehr auf ihre Kohle schauen ist die Preis/Leistung einfach nur dreist. Wer sich trotz meiner Review die M√ºrre kaufen will, solls halt machen wenn‚Äôs im Sale is oder per Key was wei√ü ich‚Ä¶

Ach ja BTW es gibt keine wirkliche Hexe in dem schei√ü Wald.

Ich kann das alles nicht mehr‚Ä¶

Ara sƒ±ra kar≈üƒ±la≈ütƒ±ƒüƒ±nƒ±z aƒüa√ßlarƒ±n arasƒ±nda belli bile olmayan ƒ±≈üƒ±ktan korkan yaratƒ±klarƒ± 7 saatlik oyun s√ºrem boyunca √ß√∂zemedim. Morq k√∂pek havlƒ±o oraya ƒ±≈üƒ±k tutuon bum. Kamera var, bi≈üiler g√∂r√ºon, takip edion √∂le bi≈üi. 3-5 kere de bugla kar≈üƒ±la≈ütƒ±m, restart atmam gerekti. Hikayesine lafƒ±m yok, ba≈üarƒ±lƒ±.
Fiyatƒ±na g√∂re eh i≈üte olan √ßƒ±tƒ±r √ßerez bir oyun.
Optimizasyonu da iyi deƒüil. RE Village max ayarlarda oynatan pc ile bu ≈üeyden d√º≈ü√ºk ayarlarda 30-40 fps almak kƒ±rƒ±cƒ±.

This game pushed me to see the original movie from 1999.   I dare say, I actually enjoyed the game a lot more, not that the movie wasn't good, far from it.    

I thought that Blooper overall did a very good job trying to stay within the bounds of the lore and staying ambiguous enough to let us form our own conclusions, whilst giving us more knowledge about the Blair Witch (more appropriately, her capabilities and the extent of potential victims).

For someone who mostly plays older games (early 2000's), I was blown away by the detail of the graphics, and I only had the settings on medium (GTX 1060 6gb).    I felt really immersed in the dark twisted forest of Black Hills.

I do somewhat agree with other reviews about the PTSD trope, however, the way that they tell the story behind this character's backstory was actually quite creative, but you will only find out if you find all of the psychiatrist notes.

(SPOILERS) Here's the layout of the story that I put together if you don't want to go through the trouble of finding them (I had to use a walk-through myself).

- During childhood, the main character Ellis, and his friend were playing in the Black Hills Forest when they come across a disheveled man/monster, and possibly a pet beast.

- His friend dies during the encounter, probably from the man.   What exactly transpired no one knows, the game never gives full details.   It is suggested though that there were supernatural elements at play from the discovered child-like drawings of trees with eyes all over, and trees shaped like creepy stick people (not the famous symbol)

- Whatever exactly happened, it caused Ellis to develop amnesia/memory loss of that event as a coping mechanism, but also caused him to require therapy for years, where these psychiatrist notes come from.

- His father, a colonel in the army, seems to have pushed Ellis to join the army as an alternative to therapy after lack of real progress (father is described as tough and emotionally distant), even though the psychiatrist thinks that what Ellis may experience in the line of duty may replace one trauma with another (to which he is correct).

To summarize what the main part of the game did portray story-wise, Ellis did something that caused the death of six comrades, (probably had an episode or something off-screen, this was the only ambiguous plot-line that I felt could have been more direct and consice).   During that event he killed an innocent bystander to stay alive.    He came back from duty to become a police officer, but shot and killed an un-armed robber at a grocery store (had another episode).    His PTSD was causing life to get worse and worse, and to help with his mental state the sheriff gave Ellis a retired police dog as emotional support.    

Ellis ultimately went back into the woods with his dog as a hermit, and from there the Blair Witch completed his transformation into her new pawn, which we find out she is able to transport him through multiple time-eras spanning a few years, to which it can be deduced that Ellis, now Carver, was the one who killed his childhood friend causing a time-loop to repeat itself until you get the good ending.


I highly recommend doing one play-through where you get all of the notes, papers, and items and go through them carefully to piece together the story.   I had a blast doing that on my end!

Altogether, I would rate this game an 8.5 out of 10.

column8: Bought during Halloween sale! I loved this game and it was well worth the purchase even at full price. I'm actually doing a second run through because it does have multiple endings based on some of your choices which I love in games for the replay ability. The graphics are fantastic and running around with a flashlight definitely gets spooky. When I thought the game was going to end, I realized that I still had hours more content and it got tricky! Lots of objects to find and I think this time around I will play with headphones since it is strongly recommended to get the fully immersive experience! The sound design was fantastic and you can hear all of the cracks, snaps as you walk - basically everything you'd imagine in dark woods if you were alone on top of the evil that lurks there.

column8: Luego de mucho tiempo probando algunos juegos de terror psicol√≥gico, definitivamente me quedo con Blair Witch, si bien es un juego que intenta ser algo similar a la pel√≠cula, no es tan asi. Sin embargo, te sumerge en una atm√≥sfera de terror e investigaci√≥n constante para saber que paso con la desaparici√≥n de Peter, a su vez, el personaje rememora su antepasado volvi√©ndolo un poco loco. Es un juego que da mucho miedo, es realmente inmerso y le dar√≠a un puntaje 9/10. Espero que lo jueguen y lo disfruten igual que yo.
barato y bueno dentro de todo safa
DE la super mierda que el la parte de final de la casa sea tan largo, y demasiados momentos inecesarios, que dure 3 minos no unos pendejos 27 minutos.

One of the best horror games I've played. I'm very picky with my horror, so if I say something is good, it's a proof of quality.

There's just the right amount of distressing tension with short safe moments in between. The pace the story advanced was good. I didn't get bored of areas before moving to the next one, although especially the forest included lots of walking in circles. Zero cheap jumpscares. Only good jumpscares that made sense with the story and environment. The parts where you had to use the camera's night vision were especially horrifying.

Never before have I had someone else's ass to protect in a horror game but my own, and it made me act completely different. If I had been alone, my first reaction would've been running away screaming, but now I had to be brave because nobody f**king touches the goodest boi Bullet and the horrors of hell itself pale in comparison with what I was going to do if something happened to him. I was even prepared to [spoiler]rather walk in a forever limbo and die from exhaustion than leave him.[/spoiler]

Bonus points for multiple endings and collectable achievements. I'm probably going to have another go right after the first and try to get the good ending this time.

I wish more horror games were like this.

column8:
Pro:
----------
- sehr gute grafische Pr√§sentation
- √ºberaus glaubw√ºrdig dargestellter Wald
- die weitl√§ufigen Abschnitte des Spiels wirken einfach gro√üartig 
- eine zum Schneiden dichte Atmosph√§re w√§hrend der Erkundungen
- glaubw√ºrdig & sympathisch inszenierter Hund 
- [spoiler]die eigenen Taten & die Beziehung zum Hund wirkt sich auf das Ende aus[/spoiler]
- sehr gute englische Sprecher
- eine ausgezeichnete Soundkulisse & ein sehr stimmiger Soundtrack
- gr√∂√ütenteils gut inszenierter Wechsel zwischen langsamen & hektischen Passagen
- selbsterkl√§rendes & stets verst√§ndliches Gameplay
- atmosph√§risch & interaktiv eingebundenes Handy & Funkger√§t
- nettes Camcorder-Gameplay

Kontra:
----------
- fehlende Einstellungsm√∂glichkeiten f√ºr Sch√§rfentiefe & chromatische Aberration
- die Tastenbelegung l√§sst sich nicht ver√§ndern
- random Abst√ºrze im Ladebildschirm 
- kontraintuitives Inventar
- ein Ex-Soldat, der ohne Kompass & nur mit einer Teelicht-Taschenlampe auf Vermisstensuche geht?!
- der Blair Witch Mythos wirkt oft nebens√§chlich
- unangenehm viel ‚ÄûGeisterbahn-Horror‚Äú 
- die linearen Abschnitte des Spiels wirken teilweise arg aufgesetzt
- fast schon unertr√§glich langgestrecktes & repetitives Finale
- sehr strenge und nicht nachvollziehbare Regeln zum Erreichen der verschiedene Enden  
- ern√ºchternde & anspruchslose Konfrontationen mit den Monstern 
- [spoiler]alberne Laubhaufenmonster[/spoiler]
- die R√§tsel & Puzzles sind kaum der Rede wert
- das Befehlssystem f√ºr den Hund wirkt die meiste Zeit √ºberfl√ºssig

System:
----------
- Win 10 64 Bit
- Ryzen 7 2700x
- RTX 2070
- 16 GB RAM
- Teufel Cage Headset

[b]‚ÄûBlair Witch‚Äú ist beileibe keine Vollkatastrophe, es ist jedoch auch kein gutes Blair Witch Spiel, denn daf√ºr fehlen meiner Meinung nach die Alleinstellungsmerkmale, um den Titel von Layers of Fear (LoF) abzuheben. Auch haben mir pers√∂nlich die ganzen kleinen & gro√üen Ungereimtheiten insgesamt den Spielspa√ü verdorben, allen voran die unnachvollziehbare Strenge des Spiels, wenn es darum geht, etwas anderes als das schlechte Ende zu erreichen und das unsagbar repetitive & in die L√§nge gezogene Spukhaus-Finale, welches im krass negativen Kontrast zum Rest des Spiels steht.[/b]

Dabei f√§ngt Blair Witch eigentlich ganz vielversprechend an, denn die ersten Spielstunden bluten f√∂rmlich Atmosph√§re. Trotz der fehlenden Einstellungsm√∂glichkeiten f√ºr chromatische Aberration & Sch√§rfentiefe wirkt die grafische Pr√§sentation sehr √ºberzeugend und man hat stellenweise wirklich das Gef√ºhl, in einem lebendigen & atmenden Wald unterwegs zu sein. Die einzelnen Abschnitte wirken √ºberaus detailliert und bis ins Late Game hinein besucht man die unterschiedlichsten Locations, die alle so gut In Szene gesetzt werden, dass das Worldbuilding & das Environmental Storytelling zum Selbstl√§ufer werden. Auch die Soundkulisse wirken einfach gro√üartig. Anf√§ngliches Vogelzwitschern und Windhauchen durch die B√§ume weicht alsbald einer erdr√ºckenden n√§chtlichen Stille, das Ganze untermalt mit dem wunderbar stimmigen & gruseligen Soundtrack. Wenn man sich erst einmal im stockfinsteren Unterholz verlaufen hat und es √ºberall um einen herum knackt, knirscht & heult, beginnt man, √§hnlich wie im echten Leben auch, unweigerlich Dinge zu sehen, die gar nicht da sind, was in einer wirklich hervorragenden Horrorspiel-Erfahrung resultiert, die man nicht so schnell vergisst. In diesen Momenten ist Blair Witch bemerkenswert nah dran an der Atmosph√§re des ersten Films.

Schon bald r√ºcken dann die psychischen Probleme des Protagonisten Ellis in den Fokus und zwar irgendwann so sehr, dass sich die ganze Blair Witch Pr√§misse oft untergeordnet anf√ºhlt. Es wird nun nach und nach immer mehr‚Ä¶ ‚Äûtypisches Bloober Team Gameplay & Storytelling‚Äú eingebaut und ehe man sich versieht, ist man von den aus LoF bekannten, sich ver√§ndernden R√§umen umgeben oder man wird durch eine ganze Reihe sehr linearer Sektionen gef√ºhrt. Ich kann gar nicht genug betonen, wie sehr mich Blair Witch in diesen Momenten an LoF erinnert, was einerseits sicherlich in Ordnung geht, andererseits aber auch irgendwie schade & unverst√§ndlich ist, denn anstatt zu versuchen, die anf√§ngliche, ganz hervorragende Atmosph√§re beizubehalten und das Gameplay darauf aufzubauen, r√ºckt die eigene Identit√§t von Blair Witch ein ganzes St√ºck in den Hintergrund, um Platz f√ºr Altbekanntes zu machen. 

Nun gut, damit kann man sich irgendwie arrangieren. Das aus meiner Sicht wirklich fragw√ºrdige daran ist jedoch, dass ich, √§hnlich wie in LoF, auch hier schnell merke, dass mir in kaum einer Situation Gefahr droht: Es kommt entweder an bestimmten Stellen des Spiels zu gezielt herbeigef√ºhrten Konfrontationen mit den Monstern oder ich kann halt v√∂llig blau√§ugig durch den Wald bzw. durch Ellis Erinnerungsfetzen stolpern, ohne das mir etwas passiert. Es gibt so gut wie kein dazwischen, keine random auftauchenden Feinde, die dann Patrouille laufen oder √§hnliches. Wenn man schon die Entscheidung trifft, gef√§hrliche Monster in sein Spiel einzubauen, warum dann die Konfrontationen so erzwungen wirken lassen, liebe Entwickler? Und warum diese Konfrontationen dann so anspruchslos gestalten? Um das Spiel nicht ZU anspruchsvoll & gruselig zu machen, damit man eine m√∂glichst gro√üe Spielerschaft anlockt? Wirklich schade ist das. 

Apropos anspruchslos: Das Gameplay an sich ist sehr seicht und auch die meisten Aufgaben & Puzzles, die man l√∂sen muss, sind so derma√üen einfach, dass sie kaum der Rede wert sind. Das ist v√∂llig okay und ich habe auch nichts anderes von Bloober Team erwartet, nur liegt hier gleich der n√§chste Crux begraben, denn um die verschiedenen Enden freizuspielen, muss ich bestimmte Dinge tun und andere sein lassen. Auch das geht v√∂llig in Ordnung und f√∂rdert den Wiederspielwert, nur f√ºhlt es sich einfach nicht gut an, wenn man mit dem Spieler so gar nicht kommuniziert, was er tun darf und was nicht und ihn lieber direkt in schlechte Ending schlittern l√§sst, weil er es z.B. gewagt hat, [spoiler]die Monster im Wald oder die Personen im bauf√§lligen Haus auch nur kurz mit der Taschenlampe anzuleuchten[/spoiler]. Sp√§ter wei√ü man, dass das ganze Spiel voll mit solch esoterisch & kontraintuitiv designten Entscheidungen ist und ich frage mich tats√§chlich, was sich dabei gedacht wurde. Und sollte ich trotz allem doch noch auf die glorreiche Idee kommen, ein derart lineares Walking Simulator Horrorspiel wie Blair Witch mehrmals hintereinander durchspielen zu wollen, immer hoffnungsvoll, dass ich diesmal alles richtig machen werde, dann erinnere ich mich halt kurzerhand an das sich ewig hinziehende Finale zur√ºck, welches meiner Meinung nach so derma√üen in die L√§nge gezogen wird, mit sich st√§ndig wiederholenden R√§umen und √ºberm√§√üig vielen forciert wirkenden Psychotrips & Jumpscares, dass mir direkt wieder die Lust vergeht. 

Zumindest zu Hund Bullet kann ich noch ein paar positive Dinge sagen, denn dieser wirkt sehr sympathisch und das Agieren mit ihm macht meistens Spa√ü. Bullet verh√§lt sich recht glaubw√ºrdig, er tollt & schn√ºffelt eifrig herum, er bringt einem Sachen und man kann ihn streicheln, ausschimpfen oder ihm Leckerlies geben. Das alles wirkt wunderbar knuffig und die Art und Weise, wie der Hund ins Spiel eingebunden wird, passt ganz gut zum sehr seichten Gameplay. Auch kann ich es durchaus verschmerzen, dass ich das Befehlssystem f√ºr den Hund die meiste Zeit √ºber kaum ben√∂tige, da Bullet sich meistens eh in der N√§he aufh√§lt und ich nur an vorgegebenen Stellen (siehe: gezielt herbeigef√ºhrte Konfrontationen) wirklich seine Hilfe ben√∂tige. Auch fungiert Bullet als emotionales Kernelement von Blair Witch und im Laufe des Spiels kommt es zu ein paar so herzzerrei√üenden Situationen, dass man den Hund am liebsten direkt in den Arm nehmen m√∂chte. 

Im Endeffekt ist es so, dass, wenn Dir Layers of Fear gefallen hat, dann wird Dir mit hoher Wahrscheinlichkeit auch Blair Witch gefallen. Ich f√ºr meinen Teil bin jedoch erneut von Bloober Team entt√§uscht worden. 

5,5/10

column8:
A surprisingly short but very beautiful looking psychological horror game with interesting game mechanics.
This game really excels in its ability to build tense athmosphere through visuals and sound that keeps you on the edge of your seat from beginning to end.
Speaking of the end: the last part of the game is (imo) a masterclass in psychological horror game design.
The game is a must for every enjoyer of horror games who is willing to immerse themselves into the atmosphere and who isnt only looking for cheap jumpscares.
PS: bonus points because you can pet da dog

Un buen juego...para los fan√°ticos de las pel√≠culas de Blair
Para lo que ofrece el juego se siente una gratificante inmersi√≥n y una excelente atenci√≥n al detalle y claro, la historia puede llegar a ser intrigante como fascinante respondiendo preguntas y creando otras acerca del universo de the blair project
Sin embargo como juego de terror puede llegar a carecer en ciertas partes del gameplay haciendo que llegue a ser una visita a la casa de los sustos... 
Aun as√≠ como fan de sus pel√≠culas he disfrutado mucho este juego y espero completarlo al 100% espero que alguien ajeno a su historia pueda disfrutar tambi√©n.

I don't particularly hold The Blair Witch Project to a high standard as much as other people since I think its allure and slightly "cult" status within pop culture was caused chiefly by how it was marketed and the whole ordeal heavily being a product of its time rather than the intrinsic value of the film, however even though not as much as Simon Barrett and Adam Wingard's 2016 attempt at yet another sequel, this one still managed to disappoint me on a lot of levels as another offspring of the franchise, despite my relatively low amount of expectations.

From the get go, it seems like Bloober took the 2016 movie as a blueprint in terms of atmosphere and tone and while I don't know if that was more of a decision resulting from publisher/rightsholder pressure but, I can definitely say that it wasn't exactly the best choice. Then there is the issue of the game running poorly in certain areas and even though it looks good overall, I don't see much else that can merit this kind of problem other than poor optimization. Coupled with one nasty, progression halting bug that required a complete restart of a certain part, I can't say stability is the game's best quality.

In terms of gameplay and structure, however -since I got to experience some of Bloober's previous games- I didn't expect nothing other than a glorified walking simulator that has a decent atmosphere with an interesting story on top and with both the good and the bad, this one can be summarized as that as well. The good consists of how they tried to spice things up with the "camcorder" and companion mechanics respectively, alongside the limited ways you can use your key items; while the bad consists how annoyingly inconsistent the AI is to flesh out said companion mechanic, controls and UI design feeling clunky to navigate respectively and lastly, enemy designs being uninspired, boring and to a degree annoying. 

The final act kinda redeems some of the game's flaws, ties the slightly interesting narrative up decently and uses perhaps the 2016 film's only interesting element mostly to its advantage, but even that whole segment goes on for far too long and ends up way too repetetive. Ironically enough, if you'll look at my playtime you'll see that it isn't that long -I'll even go ahead and say that the game is way too short actually- but still that last stretch felt all the more drawn out despite not even amounting more than a small portion of the experience as a whole. That in itself is an achievement, but just not specifically a positive one... 

At the end, this one just ends up as a bunch of half baked and poorly executed gameplay ideas getting in the way of an otherwise potentially interesting storyline that [i]crescendos[/i] into something intriguing but not quite enough to save the mess that is the rest of the game. I got it under a huge sale and advise everybody to the same because even though I had a lot to complain about, I still don't regret neither the time nor money I spent on it. Neverthless, it isn't something I can easily recommend to anybody.
column9:

Ironically enough, if you'll look at my playtime you'll see that it isn't that long -I'll even go ahead and say that the game is way too short actually- but still that last stretch felt all the more drawn out despite not even amounting more than a small portion of the experience as a whole. That in itself is an achievement, but just not specifically a positive one... 

At the end, this one just ends up as a bunch of half baked and poorly executed gameplay ideas getting in the way of an otherwise potentially interesting storyline that [i]crescendos[/i] into something intriguing but not quite enough to save the mess that is the rest of the game. I got it under a huge sale and advise everybody to the same because even though I had a lot to complain about, I still don't regret neither the time nor money I spent on it. Neverthless, it isn't something I can easily recommend to anybody.

column8:
I played Blair Witch with a friend watching through discord and we finished it in two sessions (one one hour session and then the rest in one session).
I highly recommend turning the lights off because of the immersion it adds to the experience.
We've been scared throughout the entire game.
There are three different endings plus a hidden one which I won't spoil. 
I got the bad ending but nevertheless I enjoyed every minute of it.

It's worth waiting for a sale (even though it almost never goes on sale) because it's kinda expensive for a 6 hour experience.

Where to start? As a longtime fan of the original movie, I've always wanted to try this game. But at the same time, I was always skeptical and didn't want to waste money on a game that I would be disappointed with. That's why I waited until the game was at a good discount. I bought it for ‚Ç¨5.99, which was an acceptable amount for me. After finishing the game, I can say that the developers would definitely deserve more for it, but not the full amount, which is excessive in my opinion. But this applies to most games I've ever played.

Back to the review. Despite the fact that the game is very short, I had to play it intermittently because of the frustration it caused me. I don't mean that the fault is entirely on the game side, maybe I didn't focus perfectly on it (I suspect I have ADHD myself), maybe my IQ is lower than I think, who knows?

One thing is certain. After a pretty good initial part of the game, I ended up looping around the campsite only because there was a strangely identical stone as in the video. After about 20 minutes of thinking, I gave up and went to sleep. The next day, I turned the game on again and the situation from the previous evening was repeated again.

That was the first time I asked uncle Google for help. After this failure, I said to myself "ok, I should have thought more", hopefully it will be better in the future.

Unfortunately, it happened again even though I already relatively understood what to do, and that the found video tapes affect the environment in the game.

This would not bother me so much tho, as I say part of the responsibility is definitely on my side.

What really pissed me off and at the same time it was the second time I had to turn the game off and go to sleep was the end of the game. It was absolutely unnecessarily long and annoying, and from those situations when I was about to get scared, I was only more annoyed. I wasn't scared, I was bored to death and I just wanted to finally finish the game.

I was literally screaming at the TV, "please go ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• yourself and let me finish it", "I just want to ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing see the end", "aaaaaaaaargh"...

I understood a long time ago that the main character suffers from PTSD, that he blames himself for the deaths of his fellow soldiers and his ruined relationship with his wife. It really wasn't necessary to forcefully stretch it and add completely unnecessary playtime.

I praise the developers for the elements of a totally twisted mind‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• in the form of psychic blackmail from Carver.

So here goes the conclusion. 

Is this game a masterpiece? It's not.

Is this game true to the idea of Blair Witch? From my point of view, yes, it is confusing and frustrating enough, both the forest and the witch are represented very similar to the original film, so I can say that the developers have done a really good job in this regard.

Is this game worth the full ‚Ç¨29.99? I don't think so and I'm glad I didn't buy it for that amount, but I still insist that the developers deserve more than the ‚Ç¨5.99 I paid for the game.

Will I play this game again to see the supposed different endings? Highly unlikely, but who knows, maybe I'll change my mind, I really want to give this game a fair chance and on the second playthrough I'll know in advance what to expect and maybe I'll focus more on the outcome.

PS: I saw a review that says this game deserves its place next to Amnesia or Silent Hill. I agree with the first, not by chance with the second. Silent Hill (any of the first 4 parts) is a completely different level. It can definitely be compared more with Amnesia (which is a fairly good game, that revolutionized the genre). At the same time, I don't agree that this game is on the same level as Outlast. Blair Witch is definitely better than Outlast which was a terribly boring horror game.

For developers:
In the future, I recommend getting more inspiration from games like Resident Evil and Silent Hill. Their replayability is unmatched. At the same time, I would welcome mechanics that would break the monotony of this game, such as the need to sleep or eat, more inexplicable changes in the environment instead of cycling in one location, more clues and more thoughtful puzzles. The game is a good addition to the Blair Witch franchise and you should be proud of it no matter what I just wrote. Just consider, in the future, that is, if you were to make another game based on the movie, before the release, invite beta testers who have seen the movie and have experience with top games in the horror genre. This game could have been a masterpiece given the quality control was better.

A very spooky game with a haunting atmosphere and great story featuring lore from the original film. Gameplay is like an enhanced walking sim, with collectables to find and a few light puzzles to solve but there's nothing too taxing. There are multiple endings to achieve, so consider your actions carefully.

column8: nie do opisania

What a waste.

Outside of the often repeated complaint that the game basically railroads you into the worst ending from the very start (which really does suck), it's an extremely disappointing experience.

The game actually starts out super strong. The Blair Witch IP is cool enough and a hike through the woods with these cool dog command mechanics could make for a very nice experience. The background for the main character Ellis is also very well written. The story plods along and is interesting enough to want to see it to the end. We go deeper into the woods and feel something messing with our heads while we investigate and try to find our way forward. All good. 

However, after about chapter 12 the game takes an absolute nosedive. It quickly divulges in a very linear sequence of pure scripted events. These often take so long that you'd be hankering to do anything than walk forward. And when the game does prompt you to do something, the action takes actually leads you more and more into the bad ending. The worst offender is the canyon sequence in Chapter 14 where you will be slogging through for what feels like an etenity. You'll ask yourself the question if you really need to just walk for 10 minutes without stopping or do you want to [spoiler]take the easy, less annoying option to move on with the game > Press the C-button and possibly kill your dog in the process[/spoiler]. I bet many, many people would do that last bit because they thought the sequence would otherwise never end. I hate the term walking simulator because I think it's insulting, but god there is no other term to describe that slop.

The absolutely worst thing is that the final chapter turns a very cool concept for a horror game into the same damn "Boo! Haunted House!" simulator of linear sequences that are just the very bottom of the barrel when it comes to horror games. I wanted Blair Witch, NOT Layers of Fear, Bloober Games. Yet it appears you just couldn't help yourself.

[spoiler]It really couldn't hurt to make this a game "just" about someone with PTSD who goes into a witch-haunted woods looking for a missing kid. Good ending = you found the kid in time. Bad ending = fill in the blanks. That would make for a good experience. 

But no. They just *had* to make it 2Deep4U with the psychological horror game 101 pack including scattered psychiatrist notes, voices constantly telling the protagonist he sucks and a totally honed in SECOND "I did something bad that makes me feel guilty" thing right at the end. It's such bad, clich√© writing. Such a cop out and such a garbage ending any way you slice it, it's inexcusable. 

Sometimes less is more. So sometimes, a guy getting lost in the woods while looking for a missing kid is all it takes. Maybe there is a witch, maybe it's his PTSD. But just stop there. Stop. [/spoiler]

Again, what a waste.

[Spoilers for the first hours]
Felt really weird about this game. People say it's atmospheric, but I don't really see why. You walk in circles in the woods and there are some random creature consisting of branches attacking you while you try flashlight them away? I honestly couldn't even understand what was attacking me most of the time.  Yeah, the forest looks nice, but it doesn't make the game atmospheric when it throws some enemies at you without even explaining what's going and why, all of a sudden, you're being attacked by some magical forest trees. 

The dog's animations are not that great for a game focusing on it. It makes all these weird movements, rushing forward and then circling around to get back all the time. Whimpering at some random tree that has nothing on it and then laying down on the ground as if it's quite comfortable in here and it wasn't being nervous 10 seconds ago. 

They throw a lot of stuff at you during the first hours - PTSD, missing children, some kind of magic VHS rewinding, marriage issues, strained relations with a local sherrif... But I can't really feel anything about it. Maybe it's the flat voice acting, maybe it's the writing, maybe it's just the nonsensical premise of you going alone in the woods in the dark with only a flashlight and a phone. I mean, we are in the forest, and we don't even have a compass? 

But you probably should expect a mediocre game given the original movie wasn't that much fun either.

column8:
First of all, I love dogs. So, naturally I like Bullet the dog in this game. Second, I love The original Blair Witch Project (1999) and this game is excellently beautiful in making that dreadful atmospheric horror movie comes to life. And finally on third, loved every second of this game. 

Too bad it's not working properly on Steam Deck at the time I wrote this review, but maybe someday it will be compatible. Just play it on PC or laptop and you'll get the full experience smoothly.

Yeah, like I said. This is an atmospheric horror. Some may like it while others don't. But for me, this one is pure greatness. Loving it from the start to end. With those multiple endings.
(^_^)d

El audio es excelente, da verdadero gusto escuchar los di√°logos y efectos de sonido.

This game is tragically short and un-engaging, it dangles the idea that your choices have consequences in front of you for the duration but you are in fact on a railroad, you have no real choices to make and those that you do are likely to be undermined by you picking up some inconspicuous collectable. The game rides on the coat tails of similar pieces such as PT but fails to deliver a truly unsettling experience, and the gamification leads to a story and world that is difficult to immerse yourself in. This is by no means a terrible game, just disappointing.
column9: This game is tragically short and un-engaging, it dangles the idea that your choices have consequences in front of you for the duration but you are in fact on a railroad, you have no real choices to make and those that you do are likely to be undermined by you picking up some inconspicuous collectable. The game rides on the coat tails of similar pieces such as PT but fails to deliver a truly unsettling experience, and the gamification leads to a story and world that is difficult to immerse yourself in. This is by no means a terrible game, just disappointing.

column8:
[h1][b]Un'esperienza tenebrosa nella foresta[/b][/h1]

[b]Voto complessivo:[/b] 7,5/10

[b]Grafica:[/b] 6,5/10 (Con colpi d'occhio suggestivi)

[b]Ambientazioni:[/b] 8,5/10

[b]Gameplay:[/b] 7/10

[b]Blair Witch[/b] √® un'avventura psicologica che ci porta nel cuore della famigerata foresta nera di Burkittsville, un luogo noto per le storie inquietanti e i misteri legati a una serie di eventi sconvolgenti. Questo gioco ha molto da offrire, ma anche alcune aree che lasciano a desiderare.

Partiamo dalla grafica, che riceve un solido 6,5/10. Sebbene ci siano momenti in cui l'atmosfera oscura e disturbante della foresta si traduce in scenari suggestivi, la grafica pu√≤ risultare altalenante. Tuttavia, con colpi d'occhio suggestivi, il gioco riesce a catturare l'attenzione e creare momenti di vera bellezza visiva. Questo dimostra che, nonostante le sue limitazioni, Blair Witch pu√≤ offrire alcune immagini memorabili.

Parlando di ambientazioni, Blair Witch ottiene un solido 8,5/10. La rappresentazione della foresta nera e dei suoi misteri √® superba. L'uso intelligente della luce, degli effetti sonori e delle variazioni atmosferiche cattura perfettamente l'essenza dell'horror psicologico. L'immersione in questo mondo oscuro √® sicuramente uno dei punti di forza del gioco.

Il gameplay riceve un punteggio di 7/10. Sebbene ci siano momenti di tensione e momenti di vera e propria paura, l'esperienza di gioco pu√≤ risultare a tratti ripetitiva. L'utilizzo del cane come compagno √® un elemento intrigante ma potrebbe essere stato sfruttato in maniera pi√π approfondita per aggiungere ulteriore variet√† al gameplay.

[b]Un consiglio prezioso √® giocare a Blair Witch con le cuffie, in modo da immergersi completamente nell'atmosfera cupa e vivere l'esperienza nel modo pi√π coinvolgente possibile.[/b]

In sintesi, Blair Witch √® un gioco che cattura l'essenza dell'horror psicologico e offre un'immersione convincente nella foresta nera. Se riesci a superare alcune carenze grafiche, troverai un'esperienza che vale sicuramente la pena di essere affrontata per gli amanti del genere.
Excelente juego de terror, muy recomendable .

[h1]UN BUCLE SIN FIN... ¬øO NO?[/h1]

Estamos en d√≠as de Halloween, y para celebrarlo decid√≠ jugar un par de t√≠tulos, incluido Blair Witch, un juego del cual no esperaba tanto pero me ofreci√≥ un buen contenido y ¬°una buena dosis de horror! Voy a enumerar algunos apartados que considero los m√°s importantes de dicha entrega.

[b]Historia:[/b] Esta es una de esas tramas en donde cualquier m√≠nimo detalle que cuentes ya es spoiler, as√≠ que voy a tratar de explicar lo menos posible para no entorpecer la historia. Me pareci√≥ excelente el lore de este juego, te tiene enganchado todo el tiempo debido a los acontecimientos que van pasando, porque en muchas situaciones no sab√©s qu√© es lo que sucede, por qu√© estamos ah√≠ (dejando de lado el "objetivo principal") y, poco a poco, nos vamos a ir enterando de lo que pasa con nuestro personaje principal que junto con su perro Bullet (personaje incre√≠ble) ir√°n desenmascarando los secretos del bosque y del propio pasado de a quien controlamos. Es una trama muy enrevesada, que te puede perder por la cantidad de detalles que tiene pero cuando vas uniendo todos los eslabones te das cuenta de lo que realmente pas√≥ y pasa. Tiene varios finales posibles dependiendo de las decisiones que tomemos durante esta oscura aventura.
Cabe destacar que este juego transcurre en el a√±o 1996, dos a√±os despu√©s de los sucesos de la pel√≠cula del a√±o 1999 "The Blair Witch Project", y varios conceptos y detalles de esta obra se mantienen en la trama.

[b]Gr√°ficos:[/b] No es un apartado que destaque demasiado aunque es un motor gr√°fico que va muy bien por lo que ofrece el juego, los detalles se pueden apreciar y es agradable a la vista. Se disfruta mucho m√°s a altas resoluciones y tiene opci√≥n de ReShade que deja un buen sabor de boca a los aspectos del lugar en el que transcurre todo.

[b]Ambientaci√≥n:[/b] Bueno... el 85% del juego nos encontramos en el famoso bosque de Black Hills, en donde pasan la mayor√≠a de sucesos. En muchas ocasiones vamos a sentir esa sensaci√≥n de soledad constante, de no saber si alguien (o algo) nos est√° acechando desde las sombras, adem√°s los escenarios en algunas partes se vuelven un laberinto ya que avanzamos pero volvemos al mismo lugar de donde empezamos, y eso a√±ade un aura de misterio e incertidumbre. Tenemos tambi√©n la opci√≥n de investigar y recorrer los senderos para obtener pistas y objetos que nos ayuden con nuestra misi√≥n. El bosque, de todos modos, est√° muy bien recreado, es ENORME pero la linealidad del juego hace que este detalle no est√© tan presente. En el tramo final, [spoiler]concretamente en la parte de la caba√±a abandonada del bosque,[/spoiler] creo que consiguieron obtener un buen resultado, que va mezclando acontecimientos del presente [spoiler]con situaciones del pasado de nuestro personaje y ah√≠ entendemos bastantes aspectos de la trama[/spoiler]. Esta √∫ltima etapa, siento que estuvo fuertemente influenciada por la [spoiler]f√≥rmula adoptada por Capcom para lo que fue Resident Evil VII[/spoiler]. Tambi√©n hay que agregar que estamos en una puja constante entre la relaci√≥n tiempo-espacio, donde la realidad muchas veces queda perdida y no sabemos en qu√© situaci√≥n nos encontramos.

[b]Jugabilidad:[/b] Se nota que han tomado muchos aspectos de otros juegos del g√©nero, como por ejemplo Alan Wake y Outlast. Para derrotar a los enemigos tendremos que usar una linterna, ya que la luz es la "munici√≥n" principal del juego, y tambi√©n contaremos con una videoc√°mara que nos va a ayudar en situaciones concretas y para alterar el espacio-tiempo antes mencionado. Nuestro perro Bullet tiene ciertas funcionalidades que nos ayudar√°n con las pistas y a seguir el camino principal, pero son funciones bastante desaprovechadas ya que el propio t√≠tulo te va llevando casi de la mano hacia donde debes ir y en la mayor√≠a de las ocasiones el perro no nos sirve para mucho, s√≥lo para acompa√±arnos (y eso si, es una gran compa√±√≠a).

[b]Sonido:[/b] No es un apartado que juegue un rol fundamental pero est√° muy presente debido a muchos efectos sonoros repartidos por la aventura. Los sonidos nos pueden ayudar a evitar situaciones de peligro, nos permitir√° estar atentos a la actividad del perro para saber si encontr√≥ algo o si se perdi√≥, y tambi√©n jugar√° como herramienta para mantenernos en tensi√≥n en ciertas zonas, en donde algunas voces nos van a hablar, o tambi√©n para escuchar sucesos que sirven como flashbacks. 

[b]Factor terror:[/b] No es un juego que recurra a viejos trucos como jumpscares o screamers, pero pod√©s estar en tensi√≥n en varias situaciones debido a que no sabemos qu√© nos podemos encontrar, o porque estamos esperando que pase algo que luego no ocurre. El horror aparece a trav√©s de otros elementos o detalles m√°s sutiles que tambi√©n fui explicando, pero creo que lo que m√°s est√° presente es la duda, el misterio de lo que nos espera m√°s adelante o de lo que realmente est√° ocurriendo a nuestro alrededor. Pero en s√≠, no es un juego que genere miedo.

Por una extra√±a raz√≥n, el juego no me dej√≥ sacar capturas. No s√© si es un fallo del comando o si simplemente fue un error m√≠o o algo que imposibilitaba esta funci√≥n, as√≠ que por eso no comparto im√°genes de Blair Witch.

[b]Mi nota final: 7.5/10[/b]

column8: The game is mostly just a walking simulator with a dog. I love the dog, but it doesn't help that he's super buggy, the game play is super slow and the ending is lack luster for the four hour run time. Just another "mental health is scary" game. I was highly disappointed. I had to consult the internet a few times, just because the map looks entirely the same. The path for the good ending is super unintuitive and the game fails to innovate on any concepts introduced. I have some reluctant optimism for Bloober's Silent Hill 2 remake and this game didn't help.

If you're a fan of the Blair Witch movie, books or lore in general i do NOT recommend this game...2 hours in it's essentially been ruined by unnecessarily being merged with "PTSD ridden aggy ex-soldier douchebag gets lost in the woods" - it's hard to like the character you're forced into being because he comes across as a stubborn asshat who frankly deserves to be in the situation he gets in.  This game could have been so good if they'd just stuck to the original Blair Witch lore (which by the way they get facts wrong about in the intro in the game let alone minimally using anything throughout to keep actual Blair Witch fans engaged) - the monsters are VERY close to the line Alan wake styled and again mildly unnecessary so early on.  A build of tension would have been great, the base storyline minus the  main characters cliche back story is actually a pretty good leading start...but yeah, it just gets ruined by the military junk.  There's a place for that i'm sure but i'm not convinced a game mainly focused on hyping up hardcore Blair Witch fans to play it was the place for it.  

I may give the game a second shot at some point but on first run.....pretty disappointed.  ALSO the game doesn't work on my PC without making advanced edits to the computer, thankfully there's a really easy tutorial to fix that from a fan on here (thanks for that!)  So yeah...game doesnt work, story is ruined by heavy military dilution for absolutely no reason what so ever and the movie/book lore has not carried through into the game.  Super disappointed - would not recommend.

column8:
It's good, not perfect, but good. Almost dropped it in the middle, but I'm glad I didn't.

[h2]Audio and Visuals[/h2]

I really like how forest looked like, all locations looked nice and in place. And I liked there was no cheap screamers right in my face as in usual horrors.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]

Hard to deny it being walking simulator with occasional item and notes collecting but wouldn't expect anything else as it fits. Phone games is nice addition. "Play with dog" gimmick felt being present only on purpose to follow "you can pet the dog here" trend, also not very useful when searching collectibles if you're too far from them.

[h2]Story[/h2]

As big fan of source material - "The Blair Witch Project" movie, I expected more insight into story, but focus is definitely shifted more to main character rather witch herself or missing kid, which is quite anticlimactic.

Spoilers ahead:
[spoiler]Main character is being delusively optimistic of search, which make it hard to follow and believe it's actually happening. Everything that happens next makes me to believe it's dream, fantasy or act of unreliable narrator storytelling. After credits there's summary of results of our actions results, which makes you believe everything we encountered was real, but it never felt like it was. Perhaps it was witch after all, who knows.

Characters backstory popups from time to time and feels out of place. Yes, it explains where his PTSD comes from and why he wants to help to find specific kid, but generally, it's not that important to events in game, it could be replaced or removed and you wouldn't notice. If you do collect all psychiatrist notes it becomes more clear where's connection between main character and witch: events was set in motion long time before events of the game, it's very easy to miss.
[/spoiler]

If to ignore very blurry pre-rendered cutscenes, occasional soft-locks during tutorials and story being unbearable sometimes, I'd say I had quite good time in it.

column8: a

It's a pretty good game, worth picking up when discounted. Don't mind the playtime when trying to figure out it's length, with the time it took me I'd even say some sections are too long.  The collectibles must be a pain in the back, considering the locations, so if you're an achievement hunter I'd follow the guides at once, you wouldn't want to play this too many times to get all of them (altough that's a requirement most likely, at least the first playthrough won't be in vain). The forest is amazing, so is the sound design. Most of the locations are, actually. This doesn't have that many puzzles but those present are quite interesting, altough too easy. It's an atmospheric experience for sure, I hate the movies, but the game is pretty nice, quite unique (at least for my taste).

column8:
+ Strong points:
- A varied progression: investigation, puzzles, pursuit, surprises, etc...
- In the forest, the visual atmospheres are particulary successful
- The camcorder is well operated
- The last hour of the game, designed for fans of the films

- Weak points:
- A tension that struggles to settle
- Short game time ( Around 7 hours of gameplay )
- Some small visual bugs

Summary: By using the Black Hills Forest to summon the Blair Witch, the Bloober developers have done some good tricks without achieving a miracle. As expected, Blair Witch plunges the player into a disturbing forest where reason dies like leaves in autumn. The mechanics linked to the use of accessories, in addition to the dog's skills, add to the depth of play what they lose in tension. The agreed scenario and the big tricks in terms of staging barely detract from the good feeling that we have at the end of this tumultuous ride.

15/20

la historia si es interesante, somos un inspector que trata de averiguar que paso con un ni√±o desaparecido, mediante pistas se da a entender de que fue secuestrado , la clave del juego son 3 interacciones 1 el perro que buscara objetos y darnos gu√≠as para seguir los rastros , 2 ver grabaciones e informes y 3 la comunicaci√≥n por radio con los dem√°s del departamento de polic√≠a que algunos est√°n en el mismo caso que nosotros.

esos 3 puntos me parece que son geniales pero la IA del perro es algo torpe, le dices que busque  y aveces no encuentra el rastro , las cintas de v√≠deo son un poco desorientadoras , pasas por los lugares que te ense√±an y no se encuentran y fuera de eso te adentran en un peque√±o laberinto donde te desorientas, de echo los caminos no tienen mucho sentido, me gusta la historia que te presentan pero como juego fatal.

Amazing story and atmosphere! I'm a horror game buff and love me a good atmosphere that feels tangible and enveloping. I found myself wandering the woods aimlessly in search of clues that weren't obviously there. This was a welcome reprieve though as some horror games/games in general tend to hold your hand and make it so obvious and easy to play. Now vagueness and ambiguity can be difficult to sustain and portray without boring the audience or making the game not fun, but Bloober accomplished this level of mystery and creepiness with flying colours. I haven't played a game quite like it and want more! Horror games should look to Blair Witch for inspiration in the future. Thank you, Bloober, for creating such a gripping game that I could enjoy and look back on fondly.

column8:
I'm a dumb player so I was stuck in a walking simulation for about 2 hours. After finally making some progress however by actually using the mechanics of this game, I was able to have a lot of fun and enjoyment. The game is immersive and fun, plus it's super creepy, which is something I was looking for! I would definitely recommend picking up a copy, just be sure to use your dog to help you out with certain things, or else you'll end up like me. <3

PS - I did encounter one bug where my character fell into a black pit and I thought it was a part of the game (it was not) LOL

Blair witch ou Bruxa de blair √© um jogo de terror psicol√≥gico em primeira pessoa 
que se passa algum tempo ap√≥s os eventos do filme, aqui no game vamos jogar com 
Ellis um ex policial que se junta a uma busca por um garoto que se perdeu na floresta 
da black hills, aquela fat√≠dica floresta onde ocorre o filme.
O jogo foi desenvolvido pela bloober team que fez jogos como layers of fear e the medium,
e foi lan√ßado em 2019.

Eu quando mais novo assisti o filme antigo da bruxa de blair e na √©poca e at√© hoje muita gente 
acha que aquilo realmente aconteceu, a propaganda na √©poca do filme foi muito boa para ter 
o boom que ele teve, muito depois teve um novo filme da bruxa de blair que assisti tamb√©m e aqui no jogo senti 
muito a vibe do filme que irei comentar.

Aqui no jogo nessa busca por esse garoto, vamos ter em nossa companhia o nosso cachorro 
chamado Bullet e bom no in√≠cio do jogo nosso personagem est√° indo de carro para a floresta 
e paramos o carro em um lugar onde outros policiais j√° tinham come√ßado a busca pelo garoto,
ali conosco temos um celular, um walkie talkie que ao decorrer do jogo vamos nos comunicando 
com os policiais na floresta e depois encontramos uma c√¢mera que vai ser de grande uso 
tamb√©m durante a jogatina.
Bullet √© bem importante pra voc√™, ele encontra pistas, traz objetos perdidos, fareja e vai atr√°s 
de alguma coisa, late quando ver algo estranho, √© um grande aux√≠lio e √≥tima companhia, podemos fazer 
carinho nele e dar alguns petiscos al√©m de outras intera√ß√µes que possui.

O nosso personagem tem v√°rios traumas do seu passado al√©m de um conturbado t√©rmino de relacionamento
com Jess que conversamos bastante via celular durante o jogo, com o decorrer da jogatina vamos 
cada vez mais descobrindo mais coisas sobre Ellis.
As intera√ß√µes com os outros personagens basicamente vai ser dessa maneira via walkie talkie ou pelo 
celular.

E sobre o restante do jogo o que podemos comentar ?
Cara, o jogo tem uma atmosfera muito boa, o in√≠cio √© um pouco lento e voc√™ vai se sentir perdido 
em v√°rias partes, a floresta √© macabra e misteriosa e voc√™ n√£o ver nenhum animal ali √© como se 
a floresta tivesse afastado eles, o sentimento de ficar perdido e n√£o saber para onde ir √© meio 
que normal ali, e no filme tem muito disso onde a galera fica muito tempo andando para algum lugar 
para tentar sair da floresta e quando vai ver apenas andou em c√≠rculos e aqui acontece a mesma coisa, haha.
Me senti muito no filme, √© desorientador essa floresta.
O gr√°fico √© de mediano para bom, eu achei bonito a maior parte das coisas.
A parte do design de som colabora muito pra deixar voc√™ mais imersivo ali, isso junto com 
jogar de fone de ouvido e a noite... cara √© doidera viu, e foi exatamente assim que joguei.
A atmosfera que vai se construindo ao longo do jogo s√≥ vai melhorando e quando chega no cap√≠tulo 
final fica fren√©tico, a parte que voc√™ entra na casa da bruxa que √© no √∫ltimo cap√≠tulo √© insana,
√© praticamente 1 hora ali dentro naquela atmosfera claustrof√≥bica, tudo escuro e com v√°rios corredores 
pequenos e o som ambiente √© bom demais.
Levei alguns sustinhos e algumas arrepiadas no jogo, por√©m j√° estou meio acostumado a sustos 
por assistir e gostar muito de filmes de terror, mas com certeza pessoas que n√£o s√£o acostumadas com isso 
podem ter uma experi√™ncia bem mais aterrorizante.
O jogo tamb√©m tem legenda pt-br para entender melhor da hist√≥ria.

De negativo, o que posso falar ?
Eu n√£o achei muito intuitivo algumas coisas do jogo, 
apesar de ter poucos controles e ser meio simples tem umas partes 
que eu ficava rodando e rodando sem saber o que fazer ou para onde ir.
Talvez seja burrice minha, pode ser... Mas senti isso jogando.
Ficava vendo e revendo as fitas na c√¢mera andando pra l√° e pra c√° tentando descobrir 
o que era pra fazer, √© algo que queria falar.
A hist√≥ria tamb√©m achei meio confusa, teve partes que achei que tinha entendido e depois 
j√° n√£o estava entendendo nada novamente, li todas as anota√ß√µes e interagi com muitas coisas 
mas ainda assim n√£o sei se entendi tudo como deveria.
O come√ßo √© meio lento, mas depois engrena bem, ainda mais chegando perto do final.
A dura√ß√£o do jogo √© pequena, isso pode ser bom para algumas outras pessoas e para outras n√£o,
eu gostaria que fosse um pouquinho maior e com mais partes assustadoras desde mais cedo no jogo.
Terminei por volta de 6 horas ele.
E citando parte assustadora, assim como no filme, n√£o vemos tamb√©m 'a bruxa', mas gostaria 
de ter visto mais parte das criaturas que aparecem no jogo ou ter explicado um pouco mais delas,
o que s√£o, se s√£o parte da imagina√ß√£o dos traumas do Ellis ali na floresta que ficou maior, se s√£o cria√ß√µes da bruxa e 
etc, mas tudo bem.

Sinto que o jogo poderia ter sido melhor, n√£o que seja ruim, ele √© bom e gostei, mas poderia ter dado um tchan a mais 
deixando as coisas melhores explicadas e colocado mais partes tensas, sabe quando voc√™ ver algo ou faz algo 
que sente que teve algum desperd√≠cio de ideia boa ? Foi o que senti.
Recomendo o jogo e obviamente em uma promo√ß√£o ainda mais por ele ser bem curtinho, e se voc√™ j√° assistiu bruxa de blair vai ter lembran√ßas e uma experi√™ncia ainda melhor se teve contato com os filmes.
jogo bom mas se ta acustumado com terror ou ja jogou em outra plataforma, esse jogo n√£o da medo, tambem √© bem facil 100%, peguei em 11h.

column8:
Blair Witch : By Triple F

In the realm of horror games, few titles manage to capture the essence of fear and psychological torment as effectively as "Blair Witch." Bloober Team's interpretation of the iconic Blair Witch franchise is a roller-coaster ride of terror that successfully translates the eerie atmosphere of the films into an interactive and nerve-wracking gaming experience. While not without its flaws, this game offers a captivating journey into the heart of darkness, making it a must-play for horror enthusiasts.

"Blair Witch" nails the unsettling ambiance that defines the franchise. The game's forest setting is cloaked in an air of dread, with dense woods, misty trails, and eerie sounds creating an atmosphere of constant unease. The graphical fidelity is commendable, with detailed environments and a clever use of lighting and shadows to evoke a sense of impending doom. The transition between the familiar and the surreal is seamless, leaving players perpetually uncertain about what's lurking in the shadows.

The game's narrative is a worthy addition to the Blair Witch mythos, albeit occasionally convoluted. Players step into the shoes of Ellis, a former police officer searching for a missing boy in the Black Hills Forest. As the story unfolds, it delves into Ellis's troubled past, intertwining it with the witch's history. The psychological horror elements shine here, as the game blurs the line between reality and hallucination, forcing players to question their perceptions.

While "Blair Witch" excels in creating an unsettling atmosphere, its game-play mechanics occasionally fall short. The use of a camcorder to solve puzzles and reveal hidden clues is a unique touch, but it can also feel cumbersome and disorienting. The loyal canine companion, Bullet, is a standout addition, providing emotional support and assistance in navigating the forest. However, some interactions with Bullet can be hit or miss, leading to moments of frustration.

The core strength of "Blair Witch" lies in its ability to induce genuine fear and anxiety. The game capitalizes on psychological horror, often leaving players questioning their own sanity. The forest becomes a character in itself, breathing with a malevolent presence that preys on fears and insecurities. Jump scares are expertly timed, and the constant feeling of being watched adds an incredible layer of tension. In VR, this immersion reaches an entirely new level of terror, making it an experience not for the faint-hearted.

Lastly, "Blair Witch" is a commendable entry in the horror game genre, successfully capturing the essence of the franchise's eerie atmosphere and psychological terror. While some game-play mechanics can be clunky and the narrative occasionally confusing, the game's ability to induce genuine fear and its masterful use of atmosphere make it a standout title. Whether you're a fan of the films or a horror gaming enthusiast in search of a spine-chilling experience, "Blair Witch" will take you on a terrifying journey into the unknown that you won't soon forget. Just remember to keep your flashlight close and your wits even closer.

The psychological horror elements shine here, as the game blurs the line between reality and hallucination, forcing players to question their perceptions.

While "Blair Witch" excels in creating an unsettling atmosphere, its game-play mechanics occasionally fall short. The use of a camcorder to solve puzzles and reveal hidden clues is a unique touch, but it can also feel cumbersome and disorienting. The loyal canine companion, Bullet, is a standout addition, providing emotional support and assistance in navigating the forest. However, some interactions with Bullet can be hit or miss, leading to moments of frustration.

The core strength of "Blair Witch" lies in its ability to induce genuine fear and anxiety. The game capitalizes on psychological horror, often leaving players questioning their own sanity. The forest becomes a character in itself, breathing with a malevolent presence that preys on fears and insecurities. Jump scares are expertly timed, and the constant feeling of being watched adds an incredible layer of tension. In VR, this immersion reaches an entirely new level of terror, making it an experience not for the faint-hearted.

Lastly, "Blair Witch" is a commendable entry in the horror game genre, successfully capturing the essence of the franchise's eerie atmosphere and psychological terror. While some game-play mechanics can be clunky and the narrative occasionally confusing, the game's ability to induce genuine fear and its masterful use of atmosphere make it a standout title. Whether you're a fan of the films or a horror gaming enthusiast in search of a spine-chilling experience, "Blair Witch" will take you on a terrifying journey into the unknown that you won't soon forget. Just remember to keep your flashlight close and your wits even closer.

Bought this on a sale recently, and thought I`d give it a go, as I`m running out of horror games to play.
My thought?

Like the idea of having your dog assist you.

Unfortunately, there are too many times I`ve wandered around, wondering what it is I`m actually supposed to do.
The ending isn`t a huge boss fight, in fact when the titles go up, you don`t realise it`s ended.
Only buy this in a sale.

column8:
Every Bloober game I've played felt like I could almost recommend it, but ultimately I kind of hated it. The graphics are always quite good. The art style may lack personality, but Bloober certainly knows how to make a game nice and easy on the eyes. The gameplay is always minimal and inoffensive, unless you're the kind of person who can't abide any devs makin' them terrible walking sims. I don't mind a short, simple, narrative-driven game at all. The problem with Bloober is always the story. By this point they must realize that to some people - me included - they come across as absolute a-holes. "Blair Witch" might be the most glaring example of that because the player is essentially asked to sympathize with a white cop who 'accidentally' murdered an unarmed kid. I'll make an excuse for the writers: "Blair Witch" has been released pre-George Floyd, and was created by a Polish team. Say what you will about Polish police force, but it isn't yet known for rampant killings. (That's about all positive things I can say about them at this time.) So yeah, I'm going to say that Bloober just recklessly copy-pasted a known trope which they probably learned as kids from Hollywood films. However, our main dude has also done some other bad stuff that is revealed later in the game. If Bloober wanted us to empathize or get invested in the man's redemption, well, they maybe shouldn't have made him THIS awful. Now, this issue happens in other Bloober games as well: they generally write all people as either absolute a-holes or helpless victims, and on some occasions - both at the same time. What's new in "Blair Witch" is that they decided to punish the players for playing the game. What, you thought you are meant to interact with the environment, explore and pick up collectibles? Nah, you do that and you'll get a bad ending. As a matter of fact, I don't think many people will get a good ending without consulting a walkthrough. So, say you get one of the bad endings like me. What's next? Another playthrough to get a good ending, right? Hah, as if! "Blair Witch" is possibly the least replayable game you can imagine: it takes forever to get anywhere, it's slow, the gameplay is minimal, and the pacing drags a little even on the first playthrough. So no, you will likely just do what I did: read about the other endings, shake your head, uninstall, initiate the memory erasure protocol, never think or speak of "Blair Witch" ever again. Not because it was terrible, but because it wasn't fun enough.

P.S. Oh, the dog! The dog was cute. If we could rescue him and put him in a better game, that would be the best ending for poor Bullet.

[h1]Atmospheric and a total mindf**k... a TRUE horror game[/h1]
I gotta say, I thought this was brilliantly done, a true horror in every sense, the environment, the music, the sound effects... it was an experience. Play it in the dark and play it with headphones, if your gonna do it, do it right.
Like a few other reviews have mentioned, the ending did drag on more than what you'd expect it to. But overall a fantastic game and I highly recommend, you wont regret it, well done Bloober Team.

column8: Bloober Team has successfully adapted the essence of what makes the Blair Witch films and mythos so entrancing in video game form. From a visual standpoint, the game is absolutely gorgeous and somehow gives its primary locale, the Black Hills Forest, an identity of its own. Bullet, the videotapes, and Ellis cell phone work well as devices that introduce an appropriate amount of interactivity into what otherwise would be considered a walking sim type of game. Blair Witch is the best entry in the franchise since the original The Blair Witch Project.

column8: ≈õwietny horror, polecam. Gƒôsia sk√≥rka na plecach murowana:)
Un gran juego.

[h1] "Haustieren Sie den Hund, mein ehemals Geliebter" [/h1]

Zu Beginn muss ich gleich mal sagen, dass ich keinen der "Blair Witch"-Filme wirklich gut fand. Die Crossover-Spiele von [i]Terminal Reality[/i] aus den 2000ern hingegen, die irgendwie mit Nocturne zusammen hangen, fand ich damals aber ganz OK.
Dieses Spiel hat aber, bis auf diese komische erfundene Hexensage, keinen (f√ºr mich) erkannbaren Bezug zu beidem.

Ich mochte das lockere Gameplay, die Atmosph√§re und die Hintergrundgeschichte dieses Spiels.
Wirklich gruselig fand ich es zwar nicht, aber dass man einen streichelbaren Hund als Begleiter dabei hat, hat f√ºr mich grundlegend alles andere nicht so wichtig gemacht und passte dabei noch gut zu der Story.

Man sollte eine gewisse Toleranz gegen√ºber der verbesserungsf√§higen √úbersetzung der deutschen Texte mitbringen oder das ganze einfach komplett auf englisch spielen.
Lustigerweise wurde pet mit Haustier √ºbersetzt, was ohne jeglichen Kontext ja erstmal nicht falsch ist. Wenn man mit diesem Kommando allerdings als Belohnung den treuen Sch√§ferhund streicheln will, dann ist es halt schon irgendwie nicht wirklich richtig. Was zudem dazu noch besonders auff√§llig ist, da dies als Aktion im alle paar Minuten wiederkehrenden Ringmen√º auf dem Bildschirm auftaucht.
Zudem kann es auch mal passieren, dass die Hauptrolle von seiner ehemaligen Geliebten in den auf deutsch √ºbersetzten SMS gesiezt wird. Was entweder darauf hinweist, dass man einen Adelsabk√∂mmling aus dem Mitttelalter spielt oder dass halt auch der Google-√úbersetzter mal einen schlechten Tag haben kann.

Im gro√üen und ganzen fand ich das Spiel aber sehr unterhaltsam, auch wenn ich es nicht f√ºr die vollen 30 Euro au√üerhalb eines Sales kaufen w√ºrde.
50 TL √ßerez parasƒ± bence bu oyun i√ßin ideal alƒ±nabilir. Outlast tarzƒ± oyunlarƒ± seviyosanƒ±z bu tam size g√∂re.

column8: Horrible and buggy game. Aside from the clunky and non-intuitive game mechanics, you are burdened with obscene amounts of glitches. From the dog disappearing and not being able to progress, to freezing, and the camera being bugged (something that is indispensable to be able to continue with the story), it should have its genre changed from Horror to Bug Tester. If you don¬¥t believe me, go ahead and search various forums about the infamous bugs. Shame on the developers for failing at their core competencies (or rather incompetencies). My sincere condolences to anyone who bought this at full price and is unable to return it.

Una aut√©ntica decepci√≥n para todo aquel fan√°tico o siquiera simpatizante de la pel√≠cula original (la de 1999) Y es una l√°stima porque hoy en d√≠a con todo el camino recorrido de los juegos en cuanto visuales, mec√°nicas y atm√≥sferas, podr√≠an haberse decantado por algo much√≠simo mejor y mas fiel a lo que (en teor√≠a) deber√≠a tratar el juego.

De hecho, lo mas parecido a experimentar blair witch  en formato video juego lo pueden encontrar en titulos menores (y hasta independientes) como slender the arrival (menores) y the woods (independiente....y si asi se llamaba el t√≠tulo)
O, desde el vamos, pueden optar por conseguir los 3 primeros juegos que se hicieron sobre esta franquicia para PC en un formato mas resident evil/alone in the dark (trilog√≠a que tb se distancia bastante de la pel√≠cula...por no decir por completo....y sin embargo, en esos casos, la diferencia funciona mejor)

Caso contrario, lo que espera aqui (basado en el lore) un escenario de bosque, una camara de video que sera parte de nuestro inventario y peque√±os retazos de algun que otro detalle de la pel√≠cula (y, cuyos momentos, es donde uno se agarra la cabeza y piensa "porque no fueron x aca?" el resto, una historia que con el correr del tiempo se va tornando una mas del monton y mon√≥tona.

Como ya mencionaron en otros comentarios, si deciden hacerse con el juego por el nombre y lo que (deberia) representar...les espera un chasco. 
Si por el contrario, bajan las expectativas y lo juegan como un juego de terror mas de los que se pueden encontrar en steam, probablemente se disfrute un poco m√°s a la par que se olvide al muy poco tiempo despu√©s...

A quien quiero enga√±ar? no pierdan tiempo, haganse con el welcome to the game II o slender que (en mi opini√≥n) son mejores exponentes del g√©nero.

column8: By description I should love this game but in reality it just didn't keep me interested. column8:
The game is shit, and [spoiler] simply getting certain collectibles that are constantly littered throughout the map gives you a bad ending, which is fucking stupid. [/spoiler] Essentially a walking sim where you sometimes fend off enemies with a flashlight [spoiler] (this also gives you the bad ending lol) [/spoiler] or sneak past others without looking at them.

The story is lame and the depiction of PTSD was forced and distasteful. It feels like I am watching every other thriller or horror film with a less-than-graceful depiction of mental illness as a cheap plot device. Blair Witch was a found footage movie, but this feels like some very scripted straight-to-dvd/netflix thriller movie. The vibes suck. 

The game is also un-optimized and crashed when I unlocked the framerate. The dog glitches out very often and I've even experienced him getting stuck out of the map. The pre-rendered cutscenes bugged out on me multiple times, looping with different audio, getting stuck, and eventually just teleporting me forward to the next section of the game.

Since horror is subjective, some may find this game scary but I didn't find it to be very good at building suspense. There are a few decent jump scares, but the stakes never feel all that high and the wack game mechanics for dealing with enemies turns it into more of a discount Alan Wake situation. The enemies themselves look goofy so I found it difficult to be intimidated. 

The biggest positive was that it was pretty short so I got it over with quickly.

column8:
so... a bit of a mixed bag. 

I'll start off with criticisms to get them out of the way. 

1. The game by design at times will send you in a loop, this feels authentic within the blair witch lore. However at times its frustrating and the mechanics are a little messy. It's easy to get stuck in sections with the game giving you no clear way to progress. Not very gamer friendly , we all like a challenge but we need to understand the objective to. 
2. The game in my opinion throws you too much information story wise and without spoiling it lets just say the 'twist' isn't a twist at all and you literally see it coming from an hour or two in , leaving you feeling a bit unsatisfied by the end. 
3. it's too short to leave any kind of real lasting impression, and as mentioned above its unsatisfying by the end. So short and not very sweet. 
4. It's to easy difficulty wise, I didn't die once. The real difficulty is finding your objective and the correct path that is literally it. 

now the positives 

1. looks great and plays great.
2. is actually decently scary in parts , it can go from 0-100 quick and that gets the heart going. 
3. The dog is the best addition in the game and a safety net that grounds you through the entire experience. 
4. The final level is great , i feel as if the devs put in the most work there.

So 50/50 good experience , wouldn't pay anything more than ¬£10 for it though.

column8:
There are many elements done well here - such as decent pacing, great use of binaural audio, the camera puzzle mechanics, and especially Bullet being the best companion. On the flip side, the protagonist's personal story feels out of place and forced into the Blair Witch setting, and it lost much of its horror/atmosphere towards the second half of the game.

All things considered, it was thoroughly enjoyable and had me hooked from start to finish.
