column8: First and foremost if you don't like walking simulators this game isn't for you. If you are looking for a good horror game this is it. There isn't too much in terms of game play, but it does offer plenty when it comes to atmosphere. There is a few puzzles that aren't too difficult to solve so the game is just right to keep the story's pace moving along. The game is good at capturing the feel of the Blair Witch films, and its a huge plus if you've seen the films. Pretty good game if you're looking to get scared.

column8:
This game looks good, sound good and has a lot of potential. Eerie atmosphere, not really scary, but it's still ok for me. Also I love Bullet. But...
Story is... not that good. Interesting approach to PTSD, but I couldn't care less about the main character. Seriously, I was more concern about Bullet and I was many times (too many times) asking myself "ok... and why exactly are we doing this / going there / talking like that?" I could still give it a thumb up, seeing it as well done walking simulator with few scary moments. But...
The last chapter ultimately killed the rests of my enthusiasm. Too long, too boring, too much walking around with almost zero interactions, watching the same memories you already got from prevoius chapters. At the end I was annoyed and relieved. As probably most of us, I got the bad ending. I actually like the way game is tricking you into it, but I also have no intention to invest another 8 hours of my life to linear gameplay, knowing, what kind of grind awaits me in the end. 
[spoiler]I've found team Carver & The Witch Team much more interesting anyway, so why should I bother...[/spoiler]

Dommage que le lore de cette for√™t s‚Äôefface au profit des souvenirs et traumastimes d‚ÄôEllis, l‚Äôangoisse et la peur en sont r√©duits √† peau de chagrin. 
C‚Äôest √©galement bien trop court pour l‚Äôemporter (√† peine 7h...).

[b]TL:DR: Buy this game if you want to play a walking sim with good productions values and a cute dog companion. It has predictable story and not really scary. [/b]

I bought this game for 10$ CND which is what this 4-5 hour game should realistically cost. 

Now, I have never watched the Blair Witch movies and probably never will. I just know its about some kids doing a documentary on the woods or something, and weird shit happens and someone finds their tapes and that they went on to create a brand new genre of film or at least popularise it known as "found footage".  So I did not go into this as a biased Blair Witch fan.

So was I confused by the plot as someone who has never interacted with this franchise? Not at all, but only because the story is so predictable that any "plot twists" become obvious very early on. Basically you are a guy who has PTSD (horror character with mental issues? never heard that a billion times before), the whole game can be explained away as him having a mental breakdown.. even the supernatural stuff, random stuff happens cause.. mental disorder. So do not go into this expecting a mind blowing story. 

However, the game has really good production values, cant complain when it comes to graphics, sound or atmosphere. And what really peaked my interest about this game, is that you get a dog companion, which is as cute as it sounds, he follows you around, warns you of danger, leads you to places etc etc... that alone made the game for me. We haven't had a mechanic like this in a horror game since Rule of Rose and Haunting Grounds back in 2005ish. 

You also get a fully working retro cellphone which may make some of us older gamers a bit nostalgic lol ... you can even play snake on it!! 

Gameplay is okay I guess, its more of a walking sim than anything, puzzles are non existent, you sometimes have to look for an item or have to watch a video and pause it at the correct time, but its super obvious. The only frustrating part for me, was when I got stuck in a "loop" going in circles, one time for at least 10 minutes. But then I stopped and looked around for the item that I needed to pickup and I was fine, it had been my fault for not paying attention. Checkpoints are also very generous, spawning you a few steps away from where you died, so you don't pointlessly loose any progress. Not that this game has any difficulty....

I must say this game utterly fails as a horror game for me, there is like a single "enemy" you face the whole game which are these humanoid wooden people that kinda shake around a bit, but you can easily blast them with your flashlight Alan Wake style. And later on, the game just makes you not even look at them to pass by them, so your just staring at the floor lol
Aside from that, few jump scares, which as someone who plays a lot of horror games, I am kinda tired of by now. But I am sure someone who does not, may find random stuff jumping at you scary.
column9:

Good Production Quality of the Game. Intended to get the good ending, did everything right. Fed and pet the dog almost often, didn't leave bullet, didn't collect figurines anywhere except in the last chapter in order to open the door, didn't break any totems throughout the game, and neither flashed the light at the enemies behind the trees in the woods, nor did as the witch asked of me in the entire game, no killing anyone. Yet i end up getting the bad ending after spending so much time. Extremely Disappointed, most likely won't play the game again...but it's still a good horror game nevertheless excluding personal sentiment.

I have to admit the end of the game was kind of long, I wished there would be more buildings section in the game rather than spending most of it in a forest, as the end was so nice! 
Being alone in a forest is scary, but being alone in abandoned building kind of all surrounded is also definitively scary so I think it should be further used, maybe for a later game :)

The game has some good ideas, but they're all crammed into a final level so ridiculously long that I was genuinely bored by the time it was halfway done.
Everything else is just baffling design. Remember PT where the corridor repeated over and over? Imagine that but in the spooky woods where everything looks the same but also for so long that you start checking to see if the game is bugged. 
Good dog though.

One thing I do appreciate and the thing that stands out in this game is the process of how you start off completely sane, and then slowly, over the course of the game, very gradually, you start to become more and more insane.  Is it the Witch?  Is it the character more fighting with himself?  The descent into madness is what I appreciate about this game.

Visually, the game is just fantastic, plenty of atmosphere going on, plenty to see inside the forest, surprisingly.
If you loved the original Blair Witch film, I would say 100% that you can't go wrong here.

I got fumbled on a couple of puzzles and finding items a couple times, but that was due to my own foul ups and not the game's fault at all!  All in all, I enjoyed this experience, and is a worthwhile Bloober game.

I would recommend if you like horror games.  Not exactly what I expected, but the end (first play, so far) did a good job of making me more happy with the story.  More playthroughs will clear up the muddiness in my mind I'm sure.  Bloober does great with story content actually making sense.  I was extremely annoyed by Bullet all throughout the game tho.  When I'm reading docs he was the biggest distraction.  I also was kinda like, bruh, when the flashlight was attached to the camcorder.  I love my docs and I love my collectibles, but I was unable to view 2 of them I think because the room was too dark.  I don't know if these things were intentional.  If they were I can accept them as something that was meant to enhance the story line.  Now the hard part for me because I love yall so much.  I know how to play horror games.  They are my jam.  This shit was too dark.  Please no comments about graphics or brightness.  This game was too dark, with no point of reference and a flashlight that cuts out at key moments, I was left frustrated instead of scared.  It is too dark.  Also it felt slapped together, ran into a lot of shaky textures and bad physics.  Out of all of Bloober titles I've played this is the worst.  That being said I love yall and keep doing you're thing!

Rubbish.
With such a talent, they make such an indescribably stupid game.
And such long.
Absolutely empty walking, empty game.
And this genre is indefinitely stupid. 
There are no words what could be done and what they did. With the same meaning and originality.
The developers show psychos and human mistakes in the game, and they themselves make such an evil game. What do they give people? There is no any meaning, just walking in the dark and death 10 hours. In some places you have to go very slowly and have to replay. A very boring and empty "game". This game requires the eyes of an owl and the patience of an angel, that is, you pay for the torture. 
10 hours monotony and evil, all these hours running by pressing w shift in the dark, and at the end the stupidest ending. As if they laughed at the player. I am sorry for the money and time spent.
The slogan of the game - "the worst combination: not only boring, but also horror." Horror should be meaningful and interesting, interesting ideas, action-packed, balanced not annoying suspense plots and moral encouragement of the right qualities. otherwise it's just a first-person walking simulator in the dark. And darkness is not necessary at all, it only gets in the way and is annoying. Can you, a developer, walk in the dark in real life?? How is the game different? How long can you endure this?! Half an hour maximum. There is no witch, an explanation of where she is from, why, and something interesting, only a madman running through the woods with branches on the head and sick (he has post-traumatic injury according to the plot) fool with a dog who went to the forest alone like superman. It is clear that he will die there. It's stupid, funny and absurdity.
The most interesting thing is that in the beginning it seems that there will be a masterpiece because of the graphics, dog and mysticism with the camera.
At the end of the game, I looked like this nutcase with branches on the head. :)
I really love horror games and because of the game The Medium, I am very surprised that the other games from these developers are so empty and amateurish. 

Rise of the Tomb Raider has a cool witch, even though it's not even a horror game.

By the way, I played your game Layers of Fear. I liked the idea, but by the third hour I thought that I can not do it anymore, the same thing. You go, the door is closed, you turn, the door is open, etc. infinitely the same thing. You have to do something about the monotony and nonsense and meaninglessness in your games. And fill the plot with something smart, sane, useful. With interesting gameplay. In addition, the first person, in my opinion, is boring, this is the 90s. Better to do realistic control and movements view, convenient and comfortable. Realistic but fast, without delays etc. 

By the way, the character has a mobile phone, a Nokia from the early 2000s with games, there is a game called Snake. It is interesting. Why? Because you can see progress every second. The downside of the game is that you quickly lose and there is no point. Even from this game you can understand that your game is boring. 

The game is actually very easy to fix - cut the darkness and walking, especially in the cabin at the end, make a clear ending and a way to get it, and make navigation and fix a couple of puzzles. So that the game lasts about 4 hours. And it will become a first-person atmospheric horror game with great gameplay ideas somewhere around 7 out of 10, because there is a bit of a plot, it will be nice to play it at a discount and of course add a witch in a game about a witch, some kind of story about her and a reward for correct clear decisions. But the developers are asleep.. 

I always recommend buying games at a discount and, if possible, where you really buy it, and not rent while Steam exists or has not sent you to hell. Besides, there is no demo, you might not like the game, etc. And we play most games once, or not at all, why pay tens of dollars - nonsense. And if you play several times a week, you can get into debt within a month. Two hours of play or 14 days will pass and you won‚Äôt be able to return it. Plus, many games deceive the buyer, for example, on soulslike it says adventure or impossible to complete without paid modifications, on coop it doesn't say only coop in a franchise that had a single player campaign, or the game is just very boring hackwork with cool advertising or there is an agenda instead of a normal plot with normal characters, etc. The game is easy or well optimized for the first 2 hours, then problems start and you can't return the game. Reviews are bought by game companies. And you agree to some rules, a rule book, who reads that? When you buy food, do you also sign something? Food is even more serious. You write so much so that no one will notice that we have no rights to the goods we bought?! Creatures. Agreement to view some personal data, a microphone, etc., what is that? And if you don't agree, you can't play, it's violence. And how can we filter mixed content, block absolutely everything?? Make censored content, censored versions. So, this is not a kind store, but real thieves, you can‚Äôt be generous with them. Instead, they should be judged.
column9:
Rubbish.
With such a talent, they make such an indescribably stupid game.
And such long.
Absolutely empty walking, empty game.
And this genre is indefinitely stupid. 
There are no words what could be done and what they did. With the same meaning and originality.
The developers show psychos and human mistakes in the game, and they themselves make such an evil game. What do they give people? There is no any meaning, just walking in the dark and death 10 hours. In some places you have to go very slowly and have to replay. A very boring and empty "game". This game requires the eyes of an owl and the patience of an angel, that is, you pay for the torture.

Das Spiel ist meiner Meinung nach nicht wert gekauft zu werden.

Beim ersten Blick sieht es ganz gut aus und die Atmosph√§re wird mit der Zeit auch immer "grusliger".
Manche Ideen wurden auch ganz gut umgesetzt, das spiel ist oftmals kreativer als ich dachte.

Das Problem ist, dass es zu 90% der Zeit einfach nur langweilig ist weil man A. entweder nicht in einer Gef√§hrlichen/Dramatischen Situation steckt oder weil man B. mittlerweile verstanden hat wie simpel die genannten Gefahren zu umgehen sind. 
Das einzige was mich im Spiel so weit gebracht hat war die Story die ohne eigentlich ziemlich langweilig ist aber sie war halt das einzige was den Spielfluss noch so zum laufen gebracht hat.

Im gro√üen und ganzen ist das Spiel einfach langweilig und nicht das was man von einem Horror Spiel erhofft. 
3/10

column8:
No spoilers here.
Before playing I knew that Blair Witch was a horror game involving you having a dog and you being a former cop. Didn`t know ANYTHING about the plot. The game takes some time to put you in the game`s mood and atmosphere. The forest you explore is really good looking and the game overall has some nice visuals. Also nice music (nothing memorable but its fine). For a horror game it felt a lot like an adventure game if I`m being honest, not that this is a bad thing. Game wasn`t THAT scary IMO but had some good scares.
Worth checking this out!
(NOT SPOILERS BUT SOMETHING REGARDING THE ENDING)
.
.
The game has multiple endings. It`s next to impossible to get the good ending going blind in this. I looked online and the things you have (or maybe don`t have) to do are laughable. Still a good game.

column8:
The game is not exactly original. It got elements from The vanishing of Ethan Carter, Alan Wake, Silent Hill and Outlast, in my view. Above all it reminded me of The Obsverer on several occasion. So, nothing particulary new here but the way it combines these elements is quite remarkable. Pretty well excecuted I d say. 
Plenty of jumpscares, stunning environments, intriguing plot and interesting mechanincs. 
Quite compelling game! 

Well done!!

column8:
[h1] A game doing justice to the movie [/h1]

Bloober Team is known for their story-rich, unique horror games that are meant to terrify you in many unconventional ways. To me, it seems like they tried to launch a more conventional survival horror game and stepped out of their craftsmanship. Blair Witch isn‚Äôt groundbreaking in its execution or idea but it definitely has potential. The truth is that the entirety of this game isn‚Äôt as great as it seems, just like the reviews say - and I started it with high hopes. But it doesn't deserve all the hate either because the more you play, the better it gets. The price could be a couple of euros lower to match its quality better but I understand that developing games is costly. 

Blair Witch introduces some nice mechanics such as the walkie-talkie and the multipurpose camera, the story is on point and the forest feels unwelcoming as intended. Plus, Bullet is such a lovely dog! Some of the game‚Äôs weaknesses can be forgiven because of a few genuinely creepy moments and the mind-blowing way it deals with mental illnesses. The encounters with the monsters are adrenaline-pumping since you must either defend yourself with your flashlight or evade them. 

But overall, is it that scary? Maybe not. Personally, I expected a bit more. Is it worth playing? Depends on your preference; some people might find this bland, others can be scared mindless. It‚Äôs hard to tell unless you try! I enjoyed it.

TLDR;
- I'd advice you to spend your money on something else... It's mediocre at best. Perhaps worth 10 euros, as long as you don't crash every 15 minuttes like me ofc.

This game ran fine for the first 40 minuttes or so, then it started crashing randomly. The auto save function is far inbetween progress in the game, so I've just had to replay the same 15 minuttes of gameplay 3 times, cause it isnt possible to manually save? - Just why???
I usually dont have games crashing on me, so I think there's something wrong with this product. So far storywise it seems pretty mediocre.

Crashing aside, if the game was actually interesting storywise, or with good gameplay mechanics, I'd probably bother to look further into whats causing my crashes, but honestly, I can't be arsed, cause it doesn't feel like a good game overall.

The idea of having a companion is alright, though it does feel clunky at time ordering your dog around. Besides that, your interaction will the dog have those awkward animation moments, where both of you just stares at eachother. It's the same 3 "petting" animation and the interactions, while feeling "cool" at the beginning, gets old pretty quickly.

I know it's a bit early to make up your mind about a game after about 2 hours, but the crashing just really puts me off. The story didn't really seem catch me, which is odd, considering how the game smacks 8.8 / 10 and 9 / 10 critics scores on the front page. At that score range, I'd expect to get caught onto the story after 2 hours. The characters doesn't really feel interesting, nor does the story really interest me that much so far. I wonder how much they paid to get those scores. - This game is nowhere near a top quality game.

It might ahve more scary moments later on, but I've encountered what the game calls combat, and seen some of the "creatures" or "creature" that lurks in the forest, and to be frank, it wasn't really scary, nor did it feel intense at all.

column8: viel zu kurz, das ende hat sich gezogen :-(

I finally decided to write a positive review of Blair Witch, after having completed approximately half of it. I was really in two minds whether to recommend this game or not, since I couldn't enjoy the gameplay that much. Being in the middle of a forest, chasing a dog who barely follows my orders...well, that can be frustrating. 

Moreover, most part of items that can be collected just doesn't bring anything to the gameplay, with the nice exception of video tapes. Fightings are also not particularly well designed.

Technically I could enjoy the graphics and sound effects. I unfortunately experienced a game crash, but that was the only one so far and did't impact on the game experience that much.

Moving forward through the chapters, I started really loving the atmosphere. Although the game has important differences from the films (main character's flashbacks, the dog, no human mates, everything starts like a rescue mission), it still makes to reproduce that atmosphere of being lost in a evil, dark forest, in which time and space are not the same any more and our worst nightmares come true. To me and probably to every fan of those films, this alone makes this game worth a buy. 

Still, Blair Witch is far from being a masterpiece of the genre and I wouldn't recommend it to everyone unconditionally. In order to enjoy the game, one has to really want to experience everything that is typical of the movies. Being lost in the forest in which evil can be felt more than really seen, without having a clue of what doing next: that's what you can expect from this game. If you want to try this experience, go for the it. Even in this case, you may want to look for a decent discount, since longevity doesn't sound like a strenght of Blair Witch.

If you look for action, powerful weapons, fightings you'd better search somewhere else. Also don't expect an open world game. Even though one has the feeling of walking in circles, the game is very linear.

column8: This is a horror game that is better than amnesia a machine for pigs but worse than outlast. The enemies will try to kill you but they can't because of your good boy dog. The puzzles are too complicated for my ape brain and I got lost in the woods between puzzles a lot. All in all this is a pretty good game that holds up until the last part where you dick around in ptsd land for like 30 minutes that part was kind of dragged out for too long. If you want an atmospheric horror game I would recommend this to you. I give it a solid 5 cups of soda and 3 bags of popcorn just an amazing film.

COULD CONTAIN SPOILERS

Honestly this feels like what PT could have been like if it had ever been released. Don't think it is as good or intense as PT  could have been like so incomparison of what i would have expected from PT, I would give it a 70% run for it's money when it would come to getting close to my expectations of PT. RE 7 Biohazard made me jump most of the time and had moments where the chills would run down my spine but this gave me chills for the last hour or two till you hit the finale. Btw to much emotions when it came to your dog.... The Trauma Ellis encountered was perfect for this story which sort of makes you wonder, is it the forest/witch or is it all PTSD. I know what they aimed at but just the idea of not knowing for "sure" makes it so much more interesting. Fantastic game and shoutout to the developers for making a horror game not like the rest. In my personal top 10 best horror games i have played. 9.5 out of 10

I honestly wish I could give it a positive review. On the basis of the game alone, it's pretty good, it has a cool mechanic that ties together the horror of blair witch with the investigative aspect of the game. I wouldn't say it's scary as much as creepy, the 'battles' get repetitive, but are simple enough yet still make you feel helpless.

The only issue is that it crashes SO much. Steam says I have played this game for 1.3 hours at the point of review, and my game has crashed 4 times. Always at either key, or peak horror moments, and really takes the flow out of the game to reboot it constantly. To be clear, my computer is not top tier, but it is also not bad, and other games DO NOT crash so its on the game's end.

I got the game on sale, if you find it on sale perhaps get it, the game itself is not bad, but its crash heavy. Save often, and pre-prepared.

column8:
I'm sad to say I was disappointed by this game. The tension that builds up to your first encounters is pretty solid but it quickly goes away as you realize exactly how to avoid the AI within a minute. The dog mechanics became tedious almost as quickly and the dog is liable to glitch out and force a reload. The story behind it was interesting at first but has little to do with the Blair Witch at all.
  I honestly think that if they had just made a game about this concept and left the Blair Witch IP out of it and used a setting that allowed for more of the atmospheric environments that made Layers of Fear great they would have been better off. 
 That said I haven't finished this game just yet and I doubt I will as where I last left off my dog was glitched and I was really bored.

The gist- was able to get amazing results on a quality 1920x1080, plays like a brick ****house on 42‚Äù 4K. Newb PC gamer so idk. This game was great on Xbox, bought the blooberteam 4 pack for pc after being expectedly pleased by Medium. I think the negative reviews stem from an inability to grasp a game outside one‚Äôs comfort zone. It‚Äôs sad because these games are huge on story and ambience, and ****ing scary as ****. I was almost ready to refund the four pack because Blair Witch was playing terribly on my decked out new PC, turns out playing pc on a 42‚Äù screen 4K was getting me a framerate of like, 2. Interesting because I could play re7 no problem on mostly high settings. So I grabbed my computer monitor and switched the video setting to 1920x1080, game plays beautifully, every lead and blade of grasp at smooth framerate. For some reason neither Xbox nor the third party hardware app will show my frame rate other than as a graph, but after switching the monitor I was running at like 25% of the computers capabilities. I guess that‚Äôs just what I‚Äôll use from now on. Highly recommend all bloober games, if you‚Äôve played them all on Xbox there are tons of extras and dlc, Observer looks ****ing amazing now, handles better too.

I think the negative reviews stem from an inability to grasp a game outside one‚Äôs comfort zone. It‚Äôs sad because these games are huge on story and ambience, and ****ing scary as ****. I was almost ready to refund the four pack because Blair Witch was playing terribly on my decked out new PC, turns out playing pc on a 42‚Äù screen 4K was getting me a framerate of like, 2. Interesting because I could play re7 no problem on mostly high settings. So I grabbed my computer monitor and switched the video setting to 1920x1080, game plays beautifully, every lead and blade of grasp at smooth framerate. For some reason neither Xbox nor the third party hardware app will show my frame rate other than as a graph, but after switching the monitor I was running at like 25% of the computers capabilities. I guess that‚Äôs just what I‚Äôll use from now on. Highly recommend all bloober games, if you‚Äôve played them all on Xbox there are tons of extras and dlc, Observer looks ****ing amazing now, handles better too.

column8: The game was very intense and definitely scary. I love it a lot and it was for sure my type of horror game. However, the game ended so abruptly and short, it felt as if the ending was very rushed. I read online that there are 4 separate endings + 1 "secret ending", but this does not justify anything. I would still recommend this to many horror game lovers, but beware, you may be disappointed at the end. I feel like I received no answers.

column8:
An excellent short horror game, one i enjoyed replaying as much as playing, since the major twists of the game make the foreshadowing really enjoyable to re-experience, there are a number of intriguing secrets/easter eggs, and there's more than one way to play the game, with endings that each reflect those playstyles.
My only downsides would be that the section in the house kinda overstays its welcome, and stumbling around an unreliably laid-out dark forest, trying to figure out the next bit of literal magic that'll make the plot advance, can be a little frustrating.

But those tiny gripes aside, it's a solid puzzle game and a genuinely scary horror game, even for a seasoned horror fan like me, with an interesting and confusing plot (in a good way). Definitely a game I'd recommend picking up and playing at least twice if horror and puzzle games are your jam.

Amazing game, like every other from these developers. Immersive atmosphere, unique gameplay and interesting story.
The game is so good that I first beat it when it was free on Epic games, and then bought again on steam. 
Really worth it, especially if you enjoyed other games from same devs like Layers of fear and Observer.

column8:
I am abit torn appart by this game - I like the Blair Witch Franchise and Lore but I can't recommend this game 1. Visuals are Great 
2. it's fun to have a dog companion but since he will warn you it takes away from the tension and horror part 
3. I took 6 hours to finish is so it's a short game thus only buy it when it is on sales. 
4. The Forest Section is very good but there is a section where you are in a house - the camera is not optimal for playing in small corridors.

If you are looking for a good horror game this might not be it - if you like Blair Witch in general give it a shot and play it!

column8:
This game had its ups and downs.
Some parts of this game - specifically more towards the end - were rather tedious, something that could be exaggerated partly by the not-so-sprint sprint mechanic (a feature in a lot of horror games, so while inconvenient, i can semi-pass it on that). 
The plot also became rather predictable by the end, and veered away from its initial opening; finding missing boy Peter Shannon. It instead turns into a character development/backstory exploration, and the objective of finding the boy gets "pushed" to the back of the "mind" of the storyline and becomes basically irrelevant.

Much of the horror aspects of the game relied on jumpscares, and although "atmospheric", this more or less worked to make those scares more viable. Of course, if you're content with jumpscares as a part of your main horror "fix", then there should be no problem here.

However, that being said, the overall plot was interesting, despite pushing one of its main elements to the back. The growth and change of Ellis is interesting to watch, as is the depth into his backstory that makes him a viable "target" for the subject of horrors within the forest.

I'd also say the studio did quite well with what they were given, and though I don't consider only relying on jumpscares as scary, or "proper" horror, the Blair Witch movies have been little more than that, and I can imagine it would be hard to build proper atmospheric horror off a franchise that itself relies on cheap scares. For example; Never seeing the "Blair Witch".
In my opinion, they have done quite well at creating their own spin from the main franchise, with what they could and without intruding too far into the "canon" set by the movies. As of course, I can imagine that people would be quite bored with a game that directly follows the suit of the movies themselves. 

The game itself stayed as true as it could to its film predecessors, while managing a game that, unlike the former, only had one main protagonist compared to the average "teens in the wood" trope the film set, where many of the "scares" there played off of interactions between them. This, as such, created a fleshed out villain to provide for an interesting antagonist to avoid creating a game that simply involved walking around the woods getting scared by the unseeable paranormal being in the woods.
And, of course.. It lets you pat the dog.

tl;dr, the studio worked with what it could to try to create an intriguing, unique game, while trying to keep the format of its predecessors.

column8:
Game includes lots of modern-day horror tropes that have been complained about, and pointed out many times over the past few years. 

I do feel like a lot of effort was put into the ending, but the beginning and middle felt a little phoned-in.

Good for a one-time experience. I wouldn't recommend much replay time though as the multiple endings are easy enough to get but the experience did not warrant a second go.

column8:
It's an Amazing game. Made with passion and still paying tribute to the old Blair Witch AND the remake. 

Pro's: it's graphics are amazing.
It is a real mental horror game.
The environment is stunning and plays it's part well in guiding you through the game.
The story is actually pretty good.
You have a Dog!!

Con's: Not enough jumpscares in the middle of the game.
The game is a little short in runtime, even for a horrorgame.

If you are curious to see the game first, check out my Youtube Channel: CheeseDipper
Here you can find the series i made of it: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wsf26HXN8ew&list=PLiiUI3L3jU8250g02fiDZnXVCYJgVExoA

Overall i'd definitly recommend it if you look for a short, nice story based, horrorgame!
good psychological horror game that held my attention from beginning to end

In the beginning, me and a friend had high hopes for a nice game night. Which we had. But not because of the game itself. The Blairwitch theme and the design of the forest (which is beautiful imho) raised our curiosity. But after we got lost immediately at the beginning (first time with the tent) we started to increase the brightness value. Not because it was scary, but because we wanted to speed up the sometimes annoying search.

The story may somehow make sense, but has nothing or hardly anything to do with blair witch and is hard to get into.

Maybe I would have left a positive review ... or a neutral one. But because of the worst ending to a game for me so far, the impression remains negative. You are basically forced to look at the ground for a long time and sneak around. I was about to quit close to the end, but just hoped it would be over soon. And finally it was.

And the place where you carry the dog was so long that at some point we turned off the sound and looked away until it was finally over before we suffered smth like an epileptical attack.

column8:
I would recommend this game, to say highly recommend would be pushing it. I played the game for 8 hours, enough to beat it once. I wouldn't play through it again. Personally, it gets too repetitive. The running around in circles, what feels like aimlessly, gave me a headache. The story up to chapter 17 was interesting because I started to feel like I was reading my characters story and not the story of the boy I was after. However, it just didn't get under my skin like some of the other horror games I have played. There were plenty of "jump scares" but only about 3 of them got a reaction out of me. 

All in all, I would say - Get it on sale, play it once, and uninstall it. Just enjoy the fact that you were able to get through it without putting it down entirely.

column8:
Good graphics - quite atmospheric.  Voice acting and animations are pretty good too.  Overall, the story isn't a bad one, with the main character (Ellis) dealing with personal tragedy, feelings of guilt, and serious, unresolved PTSD - said PTSD being a result of previous stints in both the military and police.  Ellis' mental stability is pushed to its limits when he enters the forest to find a missing boy by the name of Peter Shannon.  

For the most part, this game is a walking simulator and there is no combat to speak of.  You do use your flashlight to ward off "witches" etc, but other than that, it's walking/running, picking up trinkets and clues and moving forward from there.  You are paired with your trusty companion dog named Bullet.  You can give Bullet basic commands too, like "heel" or "seek;"  the latter option sometimes allows Bullet to pick up a scent and lead you in the right direction.  For the most part, these elements works nicely and are a joy to play.  

You are also expected to solve puzzles, which - for the most part - are straight forward, but can occasionally become frustrating or tedious as it's not always clear where to go; and because you're in the forest and can cover a lot of ground, frustration can set in while you aimlessly wander around.  On two occasions, I had to Google the game to figure out how to proceed, as I was sick of wasting time.  

Perhaps more problematic for me is the end of this game; not necessarily how the story ends, but how it unfolds.  Sure, there are some decent jump scares, but for the last 1-2 hours, you're covering the same ground time and time again, while doing the same things over and over again.  Needless to say, it just became repetitive and wore out its welcome.  

In the end, if you are a big horror fan and like story driven, borderline walking simulators, you should check this game out - especially if you can get it for 20 bucks or less.  For me, it took me about 8 hours to beat.  I'd say, for about 60-70% of that time, I was mostly engaged and curious about the story and where it would lead.  Couple that with the solid graphics and a creepy atmosphere, and you have yourself a decent horror game.  Just keep your expectations in check.

Having just completed Blair Witch, I have to say that Bloober Team is my favorite developing team ever! Your games have all the elements of a nightmare I love to experience during gameplays. Blair Witch may not give you the extreme scares you would expect from a horror game, (it has scary moments for sure and how scary a game is, is subjective in my opinion) but it gives you constantly the mysterious and eerie atmosphere of the forest and the situations Ellis (you) is experiencing. I have to say that the presence and company of Bullet, the dog, made me feel safer! That really, has played a major role on how I felt during the game. He was a solace in this scary, ghostly forest. The graphics are awesome, as well as the ambient sounds and music, so playing it at night, with headphones is highly recommended. I love the fact that you're giving extra care and attention to the soundtracks and the ambient sounds you will use guys!! You're just great! Music adds so much on putting the player in the mood of the main character and create feelings, make you being deeper in to the game. My personal highlight, due to extremely eerie and mysterious atmosphere, was the night exploration and challenges of the old camps and huts, as the lighting of the environment from the old, lighting poles is just awesome, so natural! Concludingly, Blair Witch is a must have game for all the psychological horror fans, it will give you the creeps, it will make you love dogs and wanting to have one, it will give you goosebumps, you will enjoy it until the end, you will wish it to be longer! 

Bloober Team for once more, you have my respect!!!

The game follow the classic Blair Witch lore and you quick get the feeling of become lost in the wood, sadly this also becoming annyoing at some point because you feel that you are in a endless loop and cant progress future because you don¬®t know what path to follow. However, graphics and both the sountrack and ambient sound effect are well made.

Pros:
- Decent Story/Plot
- Fair soundtrack
- Great graphics
- Interesting game mechanics

Cons:
- Easy puzzle solving
- Walking simulator
- No custom key config
column9:
The game follow the classic Blair Witch lore and you quick get the feeling of become lost in the wood, sadly this also becoming annyoing at some point because you feel that you are in a endless loop and cant progress future because you don¬®t know what path to follow. - Great graphics

Cons:

column8:
I have mixed feelings about this game, but it's well-made enough to earn a positive recommendation since there is no option for a neutral review. 

It's a good horror game no doubt, the graphics are great and they do well in placing you in what feels like realistic forest environments. Of course, this adds to the scare factor, as a lot of the horror comes from the tense atmosphere of navigating the eerie and low-lighted Black Hills Forest. Anyone with Xylophobia would definitely find this game terrifying and would do well to avoid it. Or maybe they'd want to play it even more. You do you.

The game is also as much a story about psychological trauma and terror as it is about actual horror, exploring the depths of PTSD and the consequences of your actions (which include pushing away those around you). Expect a lot of hallucinations and trippy sections regarding these mental issues faced by the protagonist. 

The gameplay is also pretty interesting and unique at times, with some creative mechanics dealing with the video recorder we find early in the game. Some parts of the game become very scary as a result of it. 

Unfortunately my ambivalence stems from the final act of the game but I won't delve into that. It's hard to explain but part of how I evaluate every media I experience is whether or not I feel like I appreciate the amount of time I have used for it, and whether I have received value for having consumed it. I'm not sure if I can say that for this game, but I definitely appreciate what the developers were going for. It is by no means a bad game, as the horror and gameplay aspects are very solid. So if you want it just for those, then it won't be a bad pick.

Overall I felt like it was a 6.5/10 for me.

[h1] Story : [/h1]
Zu Beginn des Spiels f√§hrt man mit seinem Hund zu einem Waldgebiet, in dem auch die beiden Filme spielen. Dort beteiligt man sich an der Suche nach einem vermisten Jungen. Die Polizei ist schon im Wald und man folgt ihnen allein mit seinem vierbeinigen Begleiter. Die Geschichte des Charakters erf√§hrt man erst Nach und Nach durch Telefonate, Gespr√§che √ºber das Funkger√§t mit den anderen Mitgliedern des Suchtrupps und Visionen, die im Laufe des Spiels immer abgedrehter werden. Mehr m√∂chte ich aus Spoiler Gr√ºnden an dieser Stelle nicht verraten.

[h1] Gameplay : [/h1]
Ich w√ºrde es als Horror Walking Simulator bezeichnen. Bedrohliche Wesen kann man zum Teil mit der Taschenlampe vertreiben, aber auch nicht alle und auch nicht immer. Es √§hnelt z.B. "Layers of Fear" oder "Outlast". 

Dabei ist der Wald der gr√∂√üte Schauplatz. Man kann sich im Wald zwar frei bewegen, aber die Wege sind sehr stark begrenzt. Man merkt das man sehr schnell durch Unterholz oder kleine Erh√∂hungen, die man nicht √ºberwinden kann aufgehalten wird. Das ist meiner Meinung nach aber auch n√∂tig, da man dadurch einige gruselige √úberraschungen einbauen kann, die bei einer freien Bewegung nur sehr schwer zu realisieren w√§ren. Der relativ feste Weg erm√∂glicht halt intensivere Effekte. 

Ist das Spiel zu Anfang noch etwas altbacken und tr√§ge, wird der Wald und die Ereignisse um einen herum im Laufe des Spiels immer abgedrehter und intensiver. Es gibt einige sehr tolle Ideen und gruselige Effekte. Welche genau das sind m√∂chte ich aus Spoiler Gr√ºnden aber ebenfalls nicht verraten.

[h1] Grafik und Sound: [/h1]
Die Grafik wirkt teilweise etwas veraltet, ist aber noch v√∂llig OK. Gerade der Wald wurde sehr gut in Szene gesetzt. Ist er zu Anfang noch einigerma√üen Idyllisch, wird er im Laufe des Spiels immer d√ºsterer, dunkler, verst√∂render und ihr werdet es selber sehen, was noch alles daraus wird. 

Der Sound wurde speziell f√ºr Kopfh√∂rer entwickelt und es macht schon Laune wenn man nur mit dem Lichtkegel der Taschenlampe durch die Finsternis wandert und das Knacken des Unterholzes glasklar ert√∂nt und einem vorgaukelt, das sich etwas in den Schatten bewegt.

[h1] Fazit: [/h1]
Mir hat "Blair Witch" als Spiel sehr viel besser gefallen, als die Filme. Kein √ºberragendes Spiel, aber f√ºr mich als Horror Fan sehr gute Unterhaltung. Die Entwickler haben ein paar tolle Grusel Effekte und Ideen eingebaut, die einen gerade in der letzten H√§lfte des Spiels immer wieder √ºberraschen. 

Vorrausgesetzt man l√§sst sich darauf ein. Wenn ich so ein Spiel in einem hellen Raum mit mehreren Leuten und entsprechender Ger√§uschkulisse spiele wirkt es einfach nicht und die Atmosph√§re ist zerst√∂rt. 

Es gibt aber auch etwas Kritik. Das Spiel ist relativ kurz. Ich habe f√ºr einen Durchgang knapp 7 Stunden gebraucht. Da es aber noch ein weiteres Ende gibt und auch den ein oder anderen Erfolg, werde ich es noch einmal durchspielen. Ich denke wer alle Enden sehen m√∂chte und alle Erfolge sammelt ist etwa 10 bis 15 Stunden besch√§ftigt. Ich pers√∂nlich bin auch mal froh wenn ich keine 200 Stunden in ein Spiel versenken muss und mag auch mal, dank Zeitmangel, die kleine Unterhaltung zwischendurch. F√ºr den Ein oder Anderen mag das aber zu wenig sein. 

Auch muss ich sagen, das trotz der knappen Spielzeit manche Schaupl√§tze und Ereignisse etwas in die L√§nge gezogen sind.

Trotzdem ganz klar von mir eine Empfehlung. Wenn euch das Review gefallen hat w√ºrde ich mich √ºber eine positive Bewertung freuen.

Gru√ü Gecko
10/10. Amazing experience

column8: Being lost in the woods with no direction during the night can be unsettling to say the very least. Amplify that with creaking trees, gnarled branches clawing at the sky, and a lanky towering witch constantly stalking its prey. For the creepiness factors, I think they checked a majority of the boxes. Being a fan of the original Blair Witch Project I was enthralled when hearing about the project. Watched some reviews about the game and the reception honestly didn't seem very favorable. After my dive into the game, I've come to a couple of conclusions that seem a bit fairer...I think. Condensed down this takes place two years after the filming of the first movie. You follow Ellis in his search for a 9-year-old boy that goes missing.  All the main elements that made up the witch are left completely intact with basically no changes as much as I could tell. As your search continues further into the woods strange anomalies begin to happen. This was the beginning of my favorite part which was the world constantly shifting around on itself. While typical the world moves around trapping you in the indefinite loop you'll receive these tapes. These videos are hints/puzzles that are a wonderful joy to figure and unpack. A side note and this just might be me the dog overall didn't feel too helpful instead it tends to feel scripted more than anything. It's not a bad thing but with the explanation of how the dog is supposed to work, it doesn't happen that way. The majority of my experiences tended to be just walking and Bullet would randomly find items without my intervention. Still, I have to admit the dog is a great addition later on when defending and leading you through the woods. Another part I found to be enjoyable had to be the imagery and visuals. Blooper tends to hit all the right notes when it comes to this for me. The Blair Witch would show Ellis something he deeply fears and makes into reality. All of this was done seamlessly and tastefully without pulling you out of the immersion. Granted the walking aspect got a bit tiresome around the 5th hour but the ending sequence does a great job picking up. The Blair Witch I felt was a great addition to the series overall honestly edging out everything except the original movie at least for me. Please check this game out and Blooper their way of storytelling feels unique and well crafted from every game I've played from them.  82/100

column8: Es un juego con unos puzzles un poco complicados, que hacen ponerte de mal humor. En cambio la ambientaci√≥n provoca tensi√≥n en todo momento. Es un juego considerablemente bueno, pero con algunas dificultades.

This game is just...not good. I'm not even sure why the Blair Witch IP was used because the game is just a generic 'lost in the woods'/'inner demons' game with the Blair Witch name slapped on it. Don't even get me started on the tired and overused ending of [spoiler] "I was the monster all along!!?" [/spoiler] which, by the way, you get by actually...playing the game. Like, the game basically leads you in the direction to do all of these things and then punishes you with a 'bad' ending. The only pro i can give this game is that you can pet the dog and give them treats. That's it.

column8:
[quote] [h1] [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/38770110/] Follow my curator page for various in-depth reviews on other games! [/url] [/h1] [/quote]

The Blair Witch game is a psychological and teemingly atmospheric horror game that has many similarities to the found-footage movie series but doesn't really follow the canonical plot. You wander through the Black Hills forest as part of a search effort for a 9 year old boy named Peter Shannon, and you do this mainly guided by your Belgian Malinois dog who's name happens to be Bullet (you can also customize him in the beginning). Despite this, the story seems to focus more and more on the main character Ellis' past, and less on the young boy you're looking for and the Blair Witch in general...

You navigate through the dark woods equipped with a camera recorder that lets you manipulate reality, a low quality flashlight, an old Nokia phone that you can play games on and call people with, and a walkie-talkie that you stole, all while fighting off stick monsters and being lead on by your dog. The game's progression relies on puzzles about changing the environment itself with the cam recorder and finding things in a spooky forest where you can easily get lost and fall into seemingly endless loops. My experience involved streaming to my friends and speaking to them vocally, but I think if I had played alone I would've developed more feelings of anxiety and fear. 

My playthrough also ended because the entire game is a buggy mess littered with game breaking glitches and horrible artificial intelligence. The game is supposed to be about six hours long, but mine was cut short because Bullet refused to go into the small hole and grab what I needed so I could progress onwards during my trek at the decrepit mining camp level. I really wanted to give this game a good review if I were able to finally get Bullet to do what I wanted, but I was never able to continue without restarting from the beginning. I unfortunately just cannot recommend this game in good faith. Along with everything else I've said, about the only "collectibles" are small wooden idols that you sometimes find, literal garbage, and Peter's belongings. [spoiler] The story almost entirely relies on how you treat your dog and whether you kill the stick monsters and break sticks (which scare the dog but can give you a bad ending; which is nonsensical). [/spoiler] It is objectively repetitive in its puzzle mechanics & the frustration devolves into boredom, eliminating any real fear you had while playing. 

Regardless of all of its faults, I'd say that the graphics are pretty nice, and the unnerving/haunting atmosphere is probably the game's best quality; that is if you can get past the increasing lack of enthusiasm as you play. If you want this game, I suggest buying it discounted because the $30 price tag just isn't really sensible considering how poorly optimized and short this game is. They really could've done something better with this IP and kind of came up short... I mean, at least you can pet Bullet and give him treats.
column9:

column8:
Ich w√ºrde das Spiel f√ºr einen sehr viel geringeren Preis empfehlen, wenn er im Sale ist f√ºr 10-15 Euro. 

Pro:
- Das Spiel hat tolle Elemente, die ich in keinem anderen Horrorspiel selbst bisher erlebt habe. Dass man jederzeit auf seinem Handy die verschiedenen Nummern anw√§hlen kann, selbst so winzige Details wie Handyspiele (Snake z.b.) spielen zu k√∂nnen, oder den Pizzalieferanten anrufen zu k√∂nnen.. Ist zwar nicht sehr wichtig so ein Krimskrams, fand ich aber trotzdem toll :) 
- Die Tapes die man finden kann, und mit denen man die Realit√§t vor sich ver√§ndert, indem man an die richtige Stelle spult und stoppt, finde ich, sind ein tolles Element.
- Der Hund, Bullet, macht einen Gro√üteil der Atmosph√§re aus. Ohne ihn h√§tte das Spiel so m.M.n. nicht funktioniert. Die Sorge um den vierbeinigen Freund, seine √Ñngste und seine Unterst√ºtzung machen schon sehr viel Atmo aus.
- Auch wenn das Spiel meines Empfindens nach nicht gruselig ist, ist das Szenario im Wald nach einem Kind zu suchen und sich pl√∂tzlich unbeschreiblichen Gestalten gegen√ºber zu sehen und sich an sein Licht (und seinen Hund) klammern zu m√ºssen schon teilweise recht spannend. 
- Die Story ist nicht bahnbrechend und neu, einzelne Aspekte sind berechenbar, aber alles in Einem sch√∂n schl√ºssig. [spoiler] Was ich hier besonders sch√∂n nachzuempfinden fand war die Darstellung einer posttraumatischen Belastungsst√∂rung wie sie im Buche steht; mir wurde bereits nach dem ersten Anfall von Panik klar, dass es sich um eine handeln wird. [/spoiler] 

Contra:
- Das Spiel gaukelt einem mit verschiedenen Enden vor, dass es sich um ein Spiel mit freien Entscheidungen handelt, doch wird kaum einer (es sei denn er spoilert sich im Vorfeld) wirklich auf die zig Umst√§nde kommen, die dazu f√ºhren, dass man ein gutes Ende bekommt. Es ist quasi vorgeschrieben, dass man es mehrmals spielen muss und mit allerh√∂chster Wahrscheinlichkeit das d√ºstere Ende bekommt. Ich habe aktiv versucht dagegen anzuwirken, dass ich ein "b√∂ses" Ende bekomme. Vergebens. 
[spoiler](So findet man Dokumente erst sp√§t, die einem √ºberhaupt er√∂ffnen, dass man die "Monster" mit der Kamera sehen kann und sie umschleichen k√∂nnte, statt sie mit Licht zu t√∂ten) - (Erst am Ende des Spiels erf√§hrt man, dass die h√∂lzernen "Totems" die man die ganze Zeit zerst√∂rt hat [weil der Hund Angst vor ihnen hat!], nicht zerst√∂rt werden sollten, und das auch nur indirekt) - (Weitere Faktoren f√ºr ein Gutes Ende bleiben verschleiert)[/spoiler] 
- Die Passage gegen Ende, die im Haus stattfindet (ohne weitere Spoiler zu nennen) ist extrem z√§h gewesen, hat mich meiste Zeit eher genervt und wurde nur selten spannender. Besonders, dass ich die - ich nenne sie mal Monster - nur umgehen konnte, in dem ich mich mit dem R√ºcken zu ihnen gewandt und mit Licht aus durch das Haus taste, hat mich immens genervt. Das hat sich gezogen wie Kaugummi. 
- Ich habe mich nur ein einziges Mal erschrocken in diesem Spiel und das war mir f√ºr ein Horrorspiel doch etwas zu wenig. Vielleicht h√§tte man mehr Stimmung, mehr Grusel aufbauen k√∂nnen oder zumindest mal ein, zwei wirklich gute Jumpscares einbauen k√∂nnen? Ich bin eine sehr schreckhafte Spielerin und es hei√üt f√ºr mich schon etwas, wenn ich kaum Anspannung in einem Horrorspiel versp√ºre. 

Fazit:
Mit ca. 5 Spielstunden ist es ein kurzes, nettes Game, das man sich schon mal f√ºr nen 10er g√∂nnen k√∂nnte. Wer das Spiel mit allem drum und dran mindestens 2 mal durchspielen will, kommt sicherlich auf 10 Spielstunden gesamt. Doch wirklich lohnen tut sich ein 2. Durchlauf nicht, nur um ein paar Sekunden andere Szenen am Ende zu haben. Es hat meiner Meinung nach keinen Wiederspielwert und es √§tzt an, dass Spieler*innen in den meisten F√§llen direkt das schlechte Ende haben werden.

column8: Ê∞õÂõ¥ÊòØÂæàÂ•ΩÔºå‰ΩÜÊòØÂÖ®ÈªëÊòØ‰ªÄ‰πàÊÑèÊÄùÔºåÊ∞∏ËøúÈÉΩÊòØÈ¨ºÊâìÂ¢ôÊòØ‰ªÄ‰πàÊÑèÊÄùÔºå‰ªéÊù•ÈÉΩÊòØÊ≠ªËÉ°ÂêåËΩ¨Ë∫´Âä†ËΩΩË∑ØÊúâÊÑèÊÄùÂêóÔºåÁé©ÁöÑÁúüÊÅºÁÅ´
Slu≈°n√° atmosf√©rick√° hra. 8/10

I don't leave reviews for games often but this has got to be one of the worst, most pointless horror games I've ever played. Super disappointing as I'm a big fan of the Blair Witch movies. The IP feels completely wasted on this game - save for the stick figures you find around the world, there's nothing about this game that would suggest that this couldn't be any other generic "lost in the woods" type horror game.

Most of the game has you exploring the "spooky" woods, which loses it's fun the first 10 minutes in, with clunky movement, leading to you getting stuck by what appears to be invisible walls, only to look down at your feet and see that your movement was halted by a twig that you could easily have stepped over. This combined with the game's attempted to simulate the feeling of being lost in the woods, and eschewing typical visual cues to lead you from one destination to the next, makes the game feel like an exercise in futility. 

Things get even worse when it gets dark, with your character's dollar tree flashlight illuminating a generous 30% of your screen, with your surroundings being near pitch black. Combine this with the absolutely terrible environmental layout and plenty of false paths, you won't be feeling any fear - just nausea and frustration. 

Gameplay is woefully lacking. The only sort of "puzzle solving" in this game revolves around a camcorder with which you play and pause the tapes you find scattered around the world. Pausing the video at the right time with change something in your surroundings to allow you to progress, so once you've done this once, you know exactly what to expect each time you find a tape. Not very interesting past the second or third time you do this. Other than that, everything else is standard fair - look around the environment, find a code for a padlock, collect gears to fix a machine, etc. There is "combat" in the game, which just revolves around you shining your flashlights on enemies (a la Alan Wake). When the enemy takes a hit it scrambles around the trees, requiring you to look around and shine it again. It loses it's charm after the first encounter, as you're going to be "fighting" the same enemy throughout the entire game. 

Main character is serviceable, dialogue and sound is ok, the dog is cute. But other than that, the actual gameplay and environments are bland and boring. At the point of this review I am on Chapter 15 (out of 17), so not completely done with the game. I've heard that the final stretch takes place in the legendary house, so hoping that'll provide something new. Just had to come and vent right now after playing a sequence in the game where it had you walk around the same loop in the dark for literally 5 minutes straight without any indication of what you're supposed to do, leading to your character eventually just collapsing and passing out to progress the story.


Updated: Finished the game. The final sequence at the house is novel for the first 5 minutes, but goes on forever, to the point where it feels like an absolute slog. The same impact could have been had in a quarter of the time - it feels like much of what goes on was made to pad the playtime. The sequence entirely revolves around reminding you that the main character isn't a good person, which the game has already been doing from the very beginning. It feels like the developers are beating you over the head - each flashback or reality distortion had me rolling my eyes and just eager to move on to the next room and get the game over with as quickly as possible. Also warning for those that get nauseous in games - the entire final chapter has liberal use of a "shaky cam" effect - that coupled with the extremely limited FOV (which the game doesn't let you change), and sequences where the game forces you to look down at the floor, may make you sick. I haven't gotten sick from playing games in years - this was the first time where it made me feel physically ill towards the end. 

Story wise, the game's ending was about what I would expect - not very satisfying. Short to say this isn't a game so much about the Blair Witch as just another "psychological horror" about a generic main character with a troubled past.
column9:
I don't leave reviews for games often but this has got to be one of the worst, most pointless horror games I've ever played. Super disappointing as I'm a big fan of the Blair Witch movies. The IP feels completely wasted on this game - save for the stick figures you find around the world, there's nothing about this game that would suggest that this couldn't be any other generic "lost in the woods" type horror game.

Most of the game has you exploring the "spooky" woods, which loses it's fun the first 10 minutes in, with clunky movement, leading to you getting stuck by what appears to be invisible walls, only to look down at your feet and see that your movement was halted by a twig that you could easily have stepped over. This combined with the game's attempted to simulate the feeling of being lost in the woods, and eschewing typical visual cues to lead you from one destination to the next, makes the game feel like an exercise in futility. 

Things get even worse when it gets dark, with your character's dollar tree flashlight illuminating a generous 30% of your screen, with your surroundings being near pitch black. column8: One of the best horror games I've played. I've played a lot of horror games (mostly not on steam) and this is one of my favorites. Now to be fair I really didn't get scared, the voice acting was kinda meh, and the story is good but doesn't have much to do with the witch herself, it's more about your character his life and past traumas. Its really good and in top 3 of favorite horror games and in my top ten of favorite games. Does a great job at portraying PTSD (coming from someone with C-PTSD).

column8:
One of the best horror games I played so far!
Combine psychological horror, with screamers, gore, and allows you to write your own story from making certain decisions.
It's outlast style, you're a normal person who barely defends himself with a flashlight.
The graphics of the forest, the environment and the sounds are excellently achieved. 
Immerses you in his world and makes it seem like you are really trapped in that forest and the experience is great.
it's impressive, the truth is very cheap for everything it offers and the ending is just great, 10/10.
Buy it without hesitation.

Das Jahr 1996: In dem Black Hills Forest in Maryland verschwindet ein neunj√§hriger Junge. Dem Polizei-Suchtrupp schlie√üt sich Ellis Lynch, der fr√ºher selbst einmal Polizist gewesen ist, an. An seiner Seite ist sein Hund Bullet, ein treuer Begleiter mit guter Sp√ºrnase. Ellis wagt sich auf eigene Faust in die tiefen W√§lder - doch dort erwartet ihn weitaus Schlimmeres als Dunkelheit und wilde Tiere...

Blair Witch kam bereits 2019 als Download heraus und wurde 2020 als Retail-Version nachgeschoben. Wie der Name unschwer erkennen l√§sst, hat das Spiel seinen Platz in der Welt der Blair-Witch-Filme - wobei ich pers√∂nlich finde, dass das Spiel wesentlich besser als die Filme ist, um das gleich mal vorwegzunehmen. Au√üerdem hat die Story des Spiels nur minimal etwas mit der der Filme zu tun: Bis auf den Schauplatz - der Black Hills Forest sowie im sp√§teren Verlauf das Haus, dem aus dem 2016er Blair-Witch-Film nachempfunden ist - und der Legende um die Hexe, die im Spiel aber keine √ºbergeordnete Rolle spielt, gibt es keine Gemeinsamkeiten.

DER HORROR

Blair Witch (das Spiel) setzt voll und ganz auf psychologischen Horror: Fast alles spielt sich im Kopf des Protagonisten ab, der mit seiner Vergangenheit zu k√§mpfen hat. Unter anderem leidet Ellis als Kriegsveteran unter PTBS (Posttraumatische Belastungsst√∂rung) und erlebt Flashbacks, in denen er sich in den Krieg zur√ºckversetzt f√ºhlt. Doch es geschehen weitaus ungew√∂hnlichere Dinge: Die Zeit scheint Spr√ºnge zu machen, im Wald treiben unheimliche Kreaturen ihr Unwesen, √ºberhaupt scheint der Wald nach seinen eigenen Regeln zu spielen. Vom Prinzip her erinnert mich das an Silent Hill, besonders den zweiten Teil.

DIE SPIELMECHANIK

Gemeint ist damit aber nur die Komponente des psychologischen Horrors, nicht das Gameplay. Gespielt wird Blair Witch n√§mlich in First-Person-Perspektive, Waffen gibt es im herk√∂mmlichen Sinne keine. Dennoch ist das Spiel viel mehr als ein Walking Simulator, denn man muss mit vielen Gegenst√§nden interagieren und sein Inventar benutzen. Dazu geh√∂rt auch eine Taschenlampe, die in Alan-Wake-Manier als Waffe gegen die an bestimmten Stellen im Wald umherhuschenden Monster eingesetzt werden kann. Diese "K√§mpfe" sind nicht besonders schwierig, aber aufgepasst: Will man das gute Ende erreichen, darf man die Monster nicht t√∂ten. Diese werden durch das Licht der Taschenlampe √ºberhaupt erst aufgescheucht, also l√§sst man die Lampe am besten aus.

Okay, dann ist es w√§hrend der Nacht-Sequenzen nat√ºrlich stockfinster, aber es gibt eine Videokamera, die man statt der Lampe in die Hand nehmen kann - und die Kamera hat einen Nachtsichtmodus. Mit dessen Hilfe kann man sich an den Monstern vorbeischleichen, was allerdings schwieriger ist, als sie zu bek√§mpfen. Au√üerdem sieht man trotz Nachtsichtmodus im Dunkeln nicht gerade viel, also anders als bei Outlast, bei dem es eine √§hnliche Mechanik gibt. Daf√ºr muss man in Blair Witch keine Angst haben, dass einem die Batterien f√ºr die Kamera ausgehen, das Teil hat unbegrenzt Saft.

Die Kamera hat aber noch eine weitere Funktion: An manchen Stellen findet man Videob√§nder, die auf der Kamera abgespielt werden k√∂nnen. Diese beeinflussen die Realit√§t: Zum Beispiel steht man vor einer verschlossenen T√ºr. Guckt man sich ein Video an, auf dem diese T√ºr erst offen ist und dann geschlossen wird, spult man das Band zu der Stelle zur√ºck, an der die T√ºr noch offen ist und pausiert dann - schon ist die T√ºr auch in der Realit√§t offen. Von diesen Video-Puzzles gibt es im Spiel mehrere, dar√ºber hinaus gibt es ein paar weitere R√§tsel, die aber alle nicht besonders kniffelig sind.

Ein Problem ist oft die Wegfindung, denn das Spiel versteht es, das Gef√ºhl zu vermitteln, sich in dem riesigen Wald zu verlaufen - obwohl das Spielareal selbst gar nicht so gro√ü ist. Der Trick ist, dass bestimmte Areale sich einfach wiederholen, man ger√§t also in einen Loop, wenn man den falschen Weg nimmt. Zum Beispiel rennt man von einem Punkt aus immer geradeaus und kommt irgendwann wieder am Ausgangsort an. Erkl√§ren l√§sst sich das aber nicht nur durch das Verlaufen, sondern auch den Spuk in Ellis' Kopf. Zum Gl√ºck hat man seinen Hund dabei, der einem oft dabei hilft, den richtigen Weg zu finden. Mit Bullet l√§sst sich per Tastendruck auch interagieren und man kann ihm Befehle geben. Au√üerdem warnt Bullet vor nahenden Gefahren.

Das Spiel ist die reinste Abw√§rtsspirale in Ellis' Psyche, denn je weiter man vorankommt, desto abgedrehter wird Blair Witch. Der Gipfel ist entsprechend der finale Abschnitt, bei dem die Realit√§t sich fast v√∂llig verabschiedet hat. Hier bewegt man sich in Layers-of-Fear-Dimensionen, soll hei√üen: Wenn man einen Raum betritt und sich dann umdreht, ist nicht garantiert, dass da immer noch der Raum ist, den man gerade eben verlassen hat - dort k√∂nnte etwas v√∂llig anderes sein. Kein Wunder: Die polnischen Entwickler von Bloober Team, von denen Blair Witch stammt, haben schlie√ülich auch Layers of Fear kreiert.

DER UMFANG
Allzu umfangreich ist Blair Witch nicht, innerhalb weniger Stunden ist man durch mit dem Spiel. Daf√ºr bietet es, wie schon erw√§hnt, verschiedene Enden, die man erreichen kann (eines kann man sogar erst beim zweiten Durchgang freischalten), au√üerdem punktet es mit seiner dichten Horror-Atmosph√§re, die mit erfreulich wenigen Jumpscares auskommt. Die Story mag zun√§chst ziemlich verworren erscheinen, doch setzt man ihre Puzzlest√ºcke zusammen, ergibt alles einen Sinn. 

Blait Witch spielt sich recht intuitiv und fl√ºssig, die Optik ist gelungen und auch der Sound ist, passend zur Atmosph√§re, stimmungsvoll. 

Mein Fazit: 
Ich hatte sehr viel Spa√ü mit Blair Witch und kann das Spiel auf jeden Fall zu 100 Prozent empfehlen. Wer sich f√ºr psychologischen Horror erw√§rmen kann und schon immer mal wissen wollte, wie wohl ein Mix aus Layers of Fear, Outlast, Silent Hill und Alan Wake ist, sollte Blair Witch auf jeden Fall mal antesten. :)

[h1] Auch ohne Hexe gut![/h1]

Grundlage des Spiels ist der Film "Blair Witch Project" aus dem Jahr 1999 (die eher zweifelhaften Fortsetzungen lasse ich mal au√üen vor). Vorab sollte man wissen: das Spiel erz√§hlt eine ganz eigene Geschichte und die Hexe von Blair dient bestenfalls als bessere Randnotiz. Wenn man nach dem Spielen aber ein wenig mehr in die Materie einsteigen m√∂chte, kann man durchaus ein paar Bez√ºge finden. Optisch wird Kennern des Films auf jeden Fall etwas geboten, was die N√§he zum Film deutlich macht.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2379697661
Allgemein ist Blair Witch atmosph√§risch ein echtes Brett! Der Wald von Burkittsville wird sehr gut dargestellt und wer die technischen M√∂glichkeiten dazu hat, sollte unbedingt HDR aktivieren, da die Spielwelt dadurch nochmals immersiver wirkt (meine Screenshots wurden ohne HDR aufgenommen, da Steam allgemein Probleme mit Bildern im HDR-Modus hat). Des Weiteren solltet ihr den Tipp zu Beginn des Spiels beherzigen und Blair Witch mit einem Kopfh√∂rer spielen. Die Tonaufnahmen wurden mit binauralem Audio aufgenommen, so dass eine wirklich schaurig sch√∂ne Soundkulisse entsteht, die manche Ger√§usche wahnsinnig "echt" erscheinen l√§sst. Allerdings liegt das Qualit√§tsniveau des binauralen Audios nicht auf dem Niveau eines "Hellblade" oder "The Suicide of Rachel Foster" - bei den beiden Spielen war es ein noch intensiverer Genuss!

Was man von Blair Witch auch nicht erwarten sollte: es handelt sich um kein dezidiertes Horrorspiel. Diesbez√ºglich ist das Spiel stimmig zum Film, Dinge werden prim√§r angedeutet und nicht gezeigt. Aber so oder so d√ºrften auch die meisten Spieler vor dem Horror gr√∂√ütenteils verschont bleiben. Nat√ºrlich ist sowas rein subjektiv, aber trotz sehr dichter Atmosph√§re kam ich nie an solchen Stellen, bei denen ich dachte "nein - ich will nicht weiterspielen, ich will nicht durch diese T√ºr gehen", oder etwas in dieser Art. F√ºr mich war der Aspekt nicht negativ, aber man sollte es vorab wissen. Es gibt durchaus ein paar Jumpscares (speziell zum Ende des Spiels hin), aber im Genrevergleich sind selbige recht harmlos. 

Blair Witch ist auch kein Actionspiel, "bewaffnet" sind wir lediglich mit unserer Taschenlampe und unserer Videokamera. Wir spielen eine sehr pers√∂nliche Geschichte des Protagonisten und dieser durchlebt im Spiel seinen eigenen Horror. Das Spiel w√ºrde auch ohne den Blair Witch-Kontext gut funktionieren, aber als Freund des ersten Teils war es f√ºr mich durchaus sehr sch√∂n, nach rund 20 Jahren mal wieder in dieses Universum abzutauchen. Die Handschrift des Entwicklers Bloober Team ist dem Spiel √ºbrigens deutlich anzumerken. Gerade wer Layers of Fear gespielt hat, d√ºrfte die Mechaniken wiedererkennen. Diese werden in Blair Witch gr√∂√ütenteils aber deutlich subtiler eingesetzt und man merkt die Ver√§nderungen anfangs fast gar nicht - wirklich gut gemacht!

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2379697715
Alles in allem hat mir die Story ziemlich gut gefallen und auch die Idee dazu finde ich sehr gelungen. Allerdings kann ich dazu nichts sagen, dies w√ºrde zu viel verraten. Speziell die Sache mit dem Grund, warum der Protagonist √ºberhaupt in den Wald geht, verr√§t im Nachhinein viel. F√ºr alle, die das Spiel bereits durchgespielt haben und die √ºber den Grund gar nichts gefunden haben, hier ein bisschen mehr dazu (Achtung Spoiler zum Ende des Spiels): 

[spoiler]Seid ihr am Ende entt√§uscht und fragt euch, was nun mit Peter geschehen ist? Dies l√§sst sich herausfinden, wenn man aufmerksam spielt - auf eine interessante Art: im letzten Kapitel kommt ihr an eine T√ºr mit dem Blair Witch-Symbol. Bevor ihr dem Spiel weiter folgt und durch die T√ºr geht, schaut einmal etwas weiter rechts von der T√ºr: dort findet ihr einen Tisch und darauf liegt eine Batterie. K√∂nnt ihr euch an den Bunker im ersten Drittel des Spiels erinnern? Die Bunkert√ºr konnte man noch recht einfach knacken (notfalls bekommt man im sp√§teren Verlauf eine SMS mit dem Code) und im Bunker steht ein Funkger√§t, welchem die Batterie fehlt - hier kommt man im ersten Spieldurchgang nicht weiter. 

Ihr m√ºsst also einen zweiten Durchgang starten und habt die Batterie beim zweiten Spielen direkt am Anfang im Inventar, sofern ihr sie gefunden habt. Wenn ihr den Weg kennt, kommt ihr auch recht schnell zum Bunker. Erwartet da keine zu gro√üe Erkenntnis √ºber Peter, aber die Idee dahinter (die Batterie im zweiten Anlauf zu haben und die Erkenntnis, dass die Sache schon vor zwei Jahren passierte (daher auch das verfallene Zelt)) finde ich ziemlich clever. Sie zeigt, dass sich Ellis/Carver in einer gedanklichen Zeitschleife befindet und die Geschehnisse immer wieder durchlebt und auf Erl√∂sung hofft. [/spoiler]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2379697689
[b]Wer die Spiele von Bloober Team mag, kann wohl bedenkenlos zugreifen. Speziell Layers of Fear-Fans k√∂nnen wohl kaum etwas falsch machen. Man darf sich eben nur nicht zu viel von der Blair Witch-Thematik an sich erhoffen, ansonsten k√∂nnte man entt√§uscht werden. Ich habe f√ºr mich einen intensiven Trip in menschliche Abgr√ºnde erlebt - auch ohne gro√üe Schockmomente. Aber bitte nicht falsch verstehen: f√ºr sehr schreckhafte Spieler k√∂nnte Blair Witch durchaus nicht ganz ohne sein. Speziell am Ende gibt das Spiel ordentlich Gas und l√§sst auch technisch seine Muskeln spielen. [/b]
the Blair Witch horror series does not deserve this masterpiece but Team Bloober was kind enough to create it anyway.

Still going to leave a thumb up since I really liked the game up to that point: the atmosphere, the puzzles, the enviroments, the tension and release, the little details; anything a good horror game must have done right.

column8:
Spoiler Alarm:

Blair (Scotish for (Battle-)Field) Witch from Bloober Team (Layers of Fear, Observer, LoF 2 & now with The Medium on January 2021)

It has many Potencial. The first Level is a mid great Forest Area with a few Trails. You feel a little bit lost. You dont know what to do first, what you searching. You have your Dog Bullet with you who can search things, if he get a Trace. Then you get deeper in the Woods. You lost your Dog for a while &  get Panic beeing Alone in the dark Wood. You find a Video Camera with you can partly manipulate your Reality. 

You play 17 Chapter (most are very short, with a few riddles/ puzzles & last one is a little bit larger playing with your Psyche, with your Traumas from War & Past as Deputy. 

It has some parts that remind me a little bit on Resident Evil 7 Demo (Old House), Layers of Fear & Outlast. Dont get to high Expectations.

The War Trauma isnt really gone suits this game. The Game Length is much to short even if you collect everything & play it Twice for Good & Bad Ending. The Good Ending is okay, but could be better with a 3rd very good Happy Ending, its a little bit disappointing.

+++ for a  AA+ Game good Graphics & really matching Level Design
++ nice creative Ideas for last Chapter 17
++ good Sound
++ If you play without killing Monsters Level 8 is really intensive at the Shed & Camp Side B avoiding Monsters

--- to short (if you dont collect everything & replay it a 2nd time its can be done in a few hours Rush)
-- Good Ending is okay, could be better or a 3rd Ending with Bullett & Jess Happy Ending
-- many potencial unused

Good for Achievement Hunters & People who like psychodelic Horror Games. 
Not Layers of Fear 1 Level, but still worth to be played & tested (buy with Discount/ Support Developers)

A 2nd Blair Witch Game with same Level Design & much more Content/ Game Length is on my WIshlist.

I hope you enjoy it like me  <3 (Cant wait to play Observer & The Medium int his Year). 

Thx 4 Reading.

column8:
It has been a while. I lost my ability to be scared, seemingly right around the time the first Blair Witch movie came out. Since, there's been a long line of ineffective jump scares and obvious plot twists. I haven't felt the genuine chill of fear run up my spine in a very long while. Bloober may have just ruined me. Stunning game from an awfully amazing developer. I've played most of their stuff so far, and I've got to say, they just keep getting better. 

Great horror game here. One you will not regret. Mostly. Now, where's my blankie and night light?

column8:
Simply wicked. Lives up to the Blair Witch lore and atmosphere,  while further exploring and expanding it in interesting and spine-chilling new ways.
A bit rough on the technical side, including one bug that required a reload, but otherwise kicks ass on the audio/visual atmosphere front.

Legitimately terrifying, doesn't overstay it's welcome, and greatly encourages repeat playthroughs in order to fully experience the story and its different endings.

column8:
[h1] [i] While having its fair share of errors, Blair Witch if definitely one of the most interesting horror games out there [/i] [/h1]

Blair Witch is based on a movie that made popular the found-footage genre and takes place few years after said movie. Taking a role of a former officer from a small town with dark history, demons in his head and loyal canine companion by his side, you will set out to explore the dark forest looking for a missing boy. While its premise is quite simple, the execution is really interesting. The game is linear with possible changes you can make during your walkthrough to get different ending, however, it has some non-linear elements such as letting you decide, how you treat your dog, Bullet, who you call and how much and more. 

The game is unfortunately suffer√≠ng from a variety of issues such as too many situations, scripted in a way that makes you think you have no control over anything. I get that the game intentionally coerces you into not knowing what is real or what is not, but here in certain passages it is almost nonsensical and it does detract from the experience a bit.

Despite this, Blair Witch is a great game to play, if you are in the market for psychological horrors.

[b] Pros [/b]

+ Gorgeous graphics - Unreal Engine really shines in this game
+ Amazing level design which replicates beautiful (and at times ominous) nature of Maryland
+ Great sound design. both with soundtrack and surround sounds
+ Relationship with Bullet that you can influence
+ Options you have outside of main story - calling various people, playing games on your phone...
+ Monsters
+ Characters
+ Animations
+ Endings
+ Voice acting
+ Lighting
+ Atmosphere

[b] Cons [/b]

- Bugs
- It is simply not possible to obtain the other main ending without the use of a outside guide as there are very specific instruction
- Some sequences which feel pointless

Honestly this game is fairly solid right up until the end where it feels rushed and silly. I made sure to check out the other endings as well and none of them offered a fulfilling conclusion either. This game is also quite lack-luster on good scares apart from a small notable few. The environment is the real horror aspect here and once that wears off the game becomes one big push until you reach the final area (that without any spoilers) is a big call back to the films that the film fans will enjoy but again once that nostalgia wears off it becomes a drag and tedious with the ending being the final nail in the coffin. If they make a sequel i hope they improve on the areas that are lacking because this has the potential to be a fantastic horror game it just needs some changes to the story most notably the poor ending which i think most people are on agreement with and combat could be more prevalent and expanded upon as well.
